I don't get this film. It wasn't terrible, but well I can't understand it. My take aways were
1. Punish people who can't afford medical (it's the American way after all).2. Splitting someone from his support network is the best plan (he'd been with her for 4 years and clean from heroin for 4 years, so yeah - that's the problem).3. When you don't take the support network along (yes, it's not as big a problem for them on many levels, but I'm sorry - it is a big life changing event for them as well - and you know, they may need support) the outcome is, well, what you get in this film.4. When you have a comedy health system, punish the person who tries to improve their situation. Tell them they are letting down the poor people, or those who don't believe the silence when they try to improve their situation and evict them from the group. Is this to make Americans feel better that they can't get what would be standard care in most countries unless they are rich?).5. Speaking of this, why was the whole community so isolated? Is there intent to live separate from the rest of society. Kinda make the "it's not a disability" thing... well, totally untrue.I wanted to like it, but it only made me glad I don't have to suffer the American "health" system.

reviews.review_title: The brilliant sound mixing takes you on a journey
reviews.content: I love a film that puts you in the shoes of the lead character. I love going on the same journey that they are going on, experiencing things exactly as they experience them. 'Sound of Metal' is one of the best films I can ever remember at doing this (possibly only second to fellow Best Picture nominee in 2021 'The Father'). The sound mixing in this movie is close to perfect. It's nowhere near as simple as just turning the volume up and down in certain scenes. I was incredibly impressed by how it was all done and if the film does indeed take home an Oscar for Best Sound it will be well deserved.Riz Ahmed and Paul Raci have been nominated for Best Actor and Best Supporting Actor respectively, at the Academy Awards. Both are indeed terrific. Ahmed is who we follow for the entirety of the film, so it was crucial that he was likeable and relatable, but also troubled and with clearly more going on than the surface would suggest. He finds a really good balance here. Raci is a standout in all the scenes he is in though. He seamlessly commands the room and has you hanging on his every word. His real life dealings with the deaf community clearly came in handy with playing this part. Left out of the nominations was Olivia Cooke. I couldn't go without mentioning her. She is terrific and her snub was very unfair.I liked this film, but I felt like the potential was there to really pull at the heart-strings at certain times in the movie and it never fully took them. I don't look at it as a missed opportunity though, I just think the film didn't want to emotionally devastate its audience as much as it wanted to enlighten and inspire them. I liked the up-lifting elements of the movie the most and if this encourages even one person to go out and learn sign language then everything after that is just icing on the cake.

"But one must take their own sweet time to reconcile with one's fate, for Ruben, the ability of hearing, granted by the implant, is not what it used to be, the sound he receives is warped, uncanny and metallic. During the third act, where he goes to Belgium to reunite with Lou, it dawns on him that aurally the world will never be the same to him, the most painful loss for him is Lou's singing voice and their relationship, to which Marder manages to add a whiff of classism (Amalric has a peculiar cameo as Lou's wealthy father), though their breaking-up scenes overtly avoid stating the obvious. For what it is worth, SOUND OF METAL is so therapeutically conceived and conscientiously wrought that it is far too easier to overlook its foibles (like its commonplace, innocuous treatment of handicapped people, or on a lesser extent, its tedious application of emphasizing the environmental buzzing and humming). Finally, a big shout-out to Ahmed, the heart and soul of the film, fine-tunes Ruben's every predictable step and swerve in such facility and devotion, his first Oscar nomination might not be a pipe dream!"read the full review on my blog: cinema omnivore, thanks

Some things trouble me about this movie. I think the acting was not an Oscar performance. I would like Ruben to have some trouble with controlling his voice level while he is talking. However, I liked his performance in a way. He handled to demonstrate his hopes about his condition and inner conflicts without directly showing it to us. I can say that Riz Ahmed did a great job at that.I did not like the story. I like it when movies have strong beginnings and calm endings. But, in this movie, nothing happens in between (Act 2). I did not also understand what it really tries to tell the audience. I now it shows us the deaf community and how Rubert's life changes. But it was just so long and slow that you can't really follow after a moment. I did not also understand Lou. I do not want to give spoilers, but I just didn't understand what is her deal. I guess this movie just isn't for me.

reviews.review_title: Superb performances all around, with themes that resonate
reviews.content: Listen to yourself think, as there is lyrical and melodic beauty in seeking one's own peace. This and other weighty questions are asked and even pondered in Sound of Metal, an extremely well-conceived film from Amazon Studios. While Riz Ahmed has received much-deserved accolades for a tour-de-force performance as a drummer with rapidly progressive hearing loss, the supporting cast members should also be praised. Among them are Olivia Cooke (Me and Earl and a Dying Girl), who appears to have successfully transitioned from teen indie darling to first-class talent, Mathieu Amalric and especially Paul Raci - whose performance was strong enough to literally create tonal shifts in the film. With limited concert footage, Sound of Metal is recommended for those who seek a contemplative character-driven drama.

How would you react one of your primary senses began to quickly deteriorate and fail? This story was a nice character study of a heavy metal drummer who quickly begins to lose his hearing. Quite a dramatic event for anyone especially a youthful musician. What effect will this have of career and relationship with his wife. Watch as this guy goes through realistic scenarios dealing with this unfortunate life challenge. Will he drown in sorrow or learn to adapt? This film had many nice moments putting the viewer in the mind and ears of this dude to hear the world as he does. Solid and well-scoped story with a raw and independent feel.

reviews.review_title: Thoughtful film that makes you appreciate what you have
reviews.content: Tackling something that has always been one of my worst fears and pulling it off with grace. Riz Ahmed expresses his grief with restraint without resorting to Nicholas Cage-esque freak outs. The deaf community is showcased with compassion. A slow ride but a valuable statement.

reviews.review_title: 4 and a half decibels out of 5
reviews.content: Brilliant film.Perfectly captures the nuance of time and the cause of the human condition when effected by it.Pre-covid and more importantly, pre-kids. I went to a lot of gigs. This might have prepared me slightly to the screams and cries of 2 newborn babies in isolation. What it did though, was make me appreciate the silence whenever I had the chance to experience it. It was comforting to adjust to the dramatic change in lifestyle. Felt like a natural progression.I may not see 1% of the live music I once enjoyed, but I now see 100% of the beauty of raising children in this world.Enjoy this film as it's a journey / experience that should be rewarded for it's commitment to life in general.Props too for casting Riz Ahmed & Olivia Cooke. They were prefect.4 and a half decibels out of 5

reviews.review_title: If you leave too much to the imagination, you're not telling a story...
reviews.content: It's not a bad film by any stretch of the imagination, it's a decent film & I enjoyed it while messing around on my phone, in fact it's perfect for that, it doesn't require full attention.The acting is superb, but the overall experience was tepid. They did zero research around what makes a good drummer, added cliche scenes they just didn't need to & left gapping emptiness at the end. Some people love that, I think it's really overused tool in film making.Basically, what happened next?? Give us hint at least. Well there might of been a hint, but for me it was a massively unsatisfying conclusion.

reviews.review_title: Effectively terrifying film about hearing loss
reviews.content: One of my biggest fears is losing my hearing. This film handles the subject incredibly well. Provides perspective with moments of terror, anger, frustration, desperation and peace.It easily deserves awards for sound design and acting. Riz Ahmed was great in Nightcrawler, and he's even better here.Easily recommended if the topic interests you and you're in the mood for a drama.7/10.

Sound of Metal is a good film for people who love music or to ones who used to be part of some band cause they can relate the most to problems that our lead character is having and how the thing that he loves is also destroying his normal life and his body expecely ears.Riz Ahmed here give role of his carrere and it would be shameful if his isnt at least nominated at academy awards cause he absolutly killed this role.Sound in this film was also very goody shown and mixed and it is maybe the best oy year in that department.Sound of Metal is one of better films of this year

It's very thoughtfully made , very detailed screenplay and the audio is fantastically connected which was the extra mile . Can not say much apart from what you get from the movie as an individual.From my perspective ' sum up all your insecurities/nightmares and they all came knocking Right Away ' and now it's only you who have to deal with it at the end of the day .Nobody is prepared for worst but the 'worst' makes your 'best' better . :)

reviews.review_title: An exquisite character study powered by Riz Ahmed's performance
reviews.content: A film about loss and grief, and what we do with ourselves when our lives change irrevocably, 'Sound of Metal' is an extremely well-structured and consistently interesting character study powered by Riz Ahmed's nuanced, naturalistic lead performance. The film's phenomenal sound design drifts effortlessly back and forth between loud clarity and a more subjective experience from the perspective of its main character's deteriorating hearing. It's amazing, intense, and powerful.

reviews.review_title: Riz should have won the Oscar?
reviews.content: While I have not watched all the nominated performances I have watched The Father and find it pales in comparison to Sound of Metal and in particular Riz Ahmed's performance may be the best of that year. I felt through it all the way with him. The despair, the anger and frustration trying to find his new place in the world. Trying to find that place of peace and stillness was his real journey.

reviews.review_title: Was this supposed to be Inspirational?
reviews.content: A drummer goes deaf, joins a community of deaf people to learn how to cope with his deafness then does everything he can to get back on tour. During his stay he meets some nice people and some cute kids who help him cope but in the end he's more interested in getting back with his girlfriend than he is in living with deafness. Is that supposed to inspire us or get us to empathize with the struggles people who have lost their hearing have to go through? You must be joking!They did have the courage to go off piste from conventional film stories and tackle a subject few people understand. But other than that it was a boring waste of time that had the potential to be so much better. I give it a 10 for creativity and a 1 for execution to make it another drearily average Best Picture nominee in a horrible year for decent movies.
Totally meaning less movie ,I was expected good sound of metal tough..or good story or good ending there was nothing there

Sound of Metal is a drama about a young couple that is facing numerous challenges. Ruben is a former drug addict with a sucidal side who has found salvation in being the drummer of a metal band and being in a relationship with the only other member, guitarist and singer Lou. She has some problems of her own as she had to deal with her mother's suicide and mutilates herself. The couple is on a tour through the United States of America in a van when Ruben realizes that he is losing his hearing. After consulting a doctor, he is told that he has to stop being exposed to loud music and that potential surgery might cost several tens of thousands of dollars and isn't covered by any insurances. Ruben struggles to accept his fate but ultimately joins a rural shelter for deaf recovering addicts. His girlfriend isn't allowed to stay and ultimately returns living in France with her father. Ruben has come to a point in his life where he must ask himself several important questions. Should he accept becoming deaf or try the expensive surgery? Should he stay in the camp or return home? Should he continue his relationship with his girlfriend in France or start a new life in the United States of America?This movie convinces on several levels. The acting performances by Riz Ahmed and Olivia Cooke are excellent. The former portrays a desperate but resilient young man that is easy to empathize with. The latter incarnates a tough young woman with a soft core who is still trying to figure out her identity. The numerous side characters in this movie are also interesting, especially the war veteran in charge of the rural shelter played by Paul Raci who becomes a father figure for the film's protagonist. This film shows that there is always hope in desperate situations and that it's possible to have a decent life even after going through difficult medical issues.Sound of Metal however also has several flaws. The two lead characters face too many struggles at once. Combing borderline personality disorder, deafness, drug addiction, family issues and suicidal thoughts is a little bit overwhelming. The way the heavy metal scene is portrayed in this movie is filled with unnecessary stereotypes. I have been listening to this type of music for several decades and know many friends who have done so as well and nobody we know has any of the psychological troubles shown in the movie. Making loud music doesn't mean that you are trying to fight some inner demons. The message that the female protagonist returns to France and lives with her rich father and now performs boring French piano ballads in the key of Brassens, Brel and Dassin with him makes her happy is quite strange to say the least.In the end, Sound of Metal is a decent drama but portrays the metal scene quite negatively as the story is filled with closed-minded stereotypes. The concept and message behind the movie are very positive but the scripwriters overloaded the characters with personal and psychological issues. The bottom line is that this drama is emotional and engaging but the story could have been more balanced and simplified to make this movie even more efficient.

It took me four times to get past 45 minutes and I was so bored. I watch as many Oscar-nomines as possible every year and the only thing I can say about this movie is that Riz Ahmed did a really good job. It can't be easy to ignore sounds around you that you automaticly react to.

reviews.review_title: Another Oscar-bait movie that's gotten some
reviews.content: I think I'm beginning to understand what kind of movies are being selected for Oscar nominations: movies for critics, not for common folks. None of the pictures I've seen that were nominated this year I liked and this one is no exception.To begin with, Sound of metal is not about metal music at all; I was hugely disappointed with that fact as I'm a big fan of rock music but all I've heard in the movie was some avantgarde screeching sounds made to look like metal but it's absolutely not the case.Second, I totally don't understand why it received an Academy award for Best Sound - the movie is mostly soundless anyway and all we do hear is silence and distant noises from a perspective of a deaf person. Call me crazy but isn't it necessary to have the best sounding picture to be even nominated for it? Because if it isn't then we should have had given Chaplin's City lights the statuette for Best Sound as well at the 4th Academy awards ceremony.But the third and the most important complaint goes to the script - it is featherlight and too simple and it gives you almost no reason to empathize with any of the main characters. The dialogues are pathetic and lifeless and they don't make you feel anything; sure the sounds do place you into the deaf person's shoes but it's the way he wears them that's supposed to stand out and I didn't see it here.Maybe my expectations got in the way of enjoying this movie from start to finish but it doesn't justify its shallow nature and one-dimensional characters and the main thought of being who you are and not trying to be someone you're not is just plain dull. I think 15 years ago a movie of such low calibre wouldn't even be recognized as good enough for any accolades but I guess this is the way the world is now.

Riz Ahmed and Paul Raci give Oscar worthy performances in what's easily one of the best films of the year. The sound design is also incredible.This movie really reminded me of The Wrestler, and that's something most movies should aspire to.

reviews.review_title: Tedious & Worthy Movie, Quite A Bore!
reviews.content: Sound of MetalThe story was very simple, man becomes deaf following lifestyle choices, man becomes incarcerated in a deaf community, man rejects that community and find an acceptance of where he has arrived at in life.Like other Oscar movies this year where "by proxy" is the latest fashion trend, (The Father - dementia, Nomadland - homeless underclass) here we were deafness by proxy. Did this achieve an understanding of deafness by the viewer the answer must be yes.The acting was pedestrian method style in a worthy issue, I remain unimpressed by its lack of emotional variety and there was just no chemistry between Ruben and his girlfriend.The preaching and evangelical approach declaring deafness is not a disability is sustainable in a deaf world, however surprise surprise in a hearing world it is a major handicap. Not to mention in the movie Ruben rejected this community as "passing" time and going nowhere. Also I am not sure it anyone spotted it but the leader of the deaf community who was so strident in his viewpoint had a "hearing" dog, a dog that covered for his own disability, if hearing was not a requirement in our hearing world he wouldn't have needed a dog. Of course the piano scene in the movie was a demonstration of sound in their hearing community.Overall this movie was much about practically nothing, I did enjoy understanding about cochlea implants.At best this tedious movie is a weak 6 out of 10.

Maybe I don't appreciate message movies. I saw all of the raves reviews and was excited to see this move. Unfortunately, I found it to excruciatingly slow moving. Worst yet, I found it boring. Not much in the way of a plot. Just boring b.

reviews.review_title: Liked it, maybe the best performed movie of 2020
reviews.content: The unique sound of this movie took me along from the start until the last wonderful moments, simple but beautiful way to look at the life of a depth man, and how he get along with his life, and how he struggles to hear, and how he tries his best but life is what it is. Great performance by Riz Ahmad and Paul Raci, the scenes between the two of them are great, hope they get nominated, one of the best movies of 2020.

For a long time now I have heard great things about Sound of Metal and with 6 Oscar nominations the hype intensified. But due to the Coronavirus it has only just come to Amazon and I watched it this morning and here is my review for it. The premise of the film sees a drummer's life changed when he starts to lose his hearing.Main Character
Riz Ahmed has always been an actor I have liked but I never saw this performance coming as he is absolutely amazing in this role. This is easily the best performance of his career and he truly deserves all the praise that is coming his way. You really see the tragedy of his character as he starts to lose his hearing and you feel a connection with him here and the real life changing journey that he has to go through in the film.Supporting Characters
Olivia Cooke plays his girlfriend in the film and she is also really good, there relationship is really well presented and you see how they care for each other and react to the situation that he has been put in. She isn't in the film a huge amount but she plays a very key role and she realises that very well indeed. Paul Raci plays a sort of mentor figure to Ahmed and he is also fantastic which is crazy because he hasn't really acted that much over the last 10 years. You can see this is a film and character that was important to him and he gives it his all having an interesting and great chemistry with Ahmed that carries a large chunk of the film. Lauren Ridloff and Mathieu Almaric have small roles and are both good, with Ridloff probably being the most high profile deaf actress that there is, her presence felt appropriate and added some real depth to the project here.Story
The story is really good, if you want to watch this film for loads of cool music scenes then you are going to be disappointed. This isn't a film about music, it is a story about one mans journey and how a life changing experience affects him and the others around him and it does an amazing job of that. Riz Ahmed sells it so well and you really see his journey play out and you care so much with an ending that is equally thought provoking and rewarding in its nature.Script
The script is really great, the drama is really well presented and handled differently to what you expect from movies with a serious subject matter in there. There are also some nice bits of humour that adds some levity to the whole film and what is going on. Also the film has plenty of sign language and I really like how it was handled and made it something that an audience member such as me would be interested in learning.Style
The style is good but mainly the sound design which is incredible. The film does an amazing job of making you feel like you are going through this crisis with Ruben our lead character. The lack of sound and ability to hear other characters is equally uncomfortable and tragic but adds so much depth to the characters and the film. But literally the only thing holding this film back from a perfect score is the pacing, it just drags its heels in at times and the subject is interesting enough but I think a slightly quicker pace at times would have really helped.Overall
Overall, Sound of Metal is a fantastic film that everybody should see. It's also amazing that this is a directorial debut by Darius Marder so expect a big future from him. This film has to be in contention to win the Oscar categories its in and deserves the two hours it takes to watch.Rating - 9/10.

reviews.review_title: Nice movie, but plot is kind of absurd
reviews.content: I like the acting and the sound work is really great (these alone make the movie worth watching), but without delving into spoilers (this is something that became clear to me early on), I think the movie argues that by trying to find a cure for a condition you're betraying those that have no option but to live with it.

A film about the loss of something essential such as hearing without which life is very difficult. Especially if you live and earn as a musician, then the handicap is even bigger. The sound here is exceptional, acting almost like an extra character in the film. Sound manipulation as well as its absence in certain scenes also tells its own story and has its own purpose. Although the film has a good and clear message that I understand, unfortunately I have to state that I did not remain delighted with the film. Some things were left unsaid and left to the viewer to infer for himself what might be. The supporting characters are virtually non-existent (except for Joe who introduces him to the world of the deaf, but also tries to learn one valuable life lesson).

I watched this based on a recommendation, and I'm so glad that I did! A terrific movie about hearing loss, recovery, relationships, and life in general! I was really drawn into it! The noise distortions made such a powerful impact on me, and really brought me into the main character's world! It also hit home a bit, as my own hearing has deteriorated over the years, but nothing like poor Rueben. It's scary to think that it could happen like that. And I loved, loved, loved the character of Joe (played wonderfully by Paul Raci) ! I wish I had a person like him in my life!Awesome ending! Nearly perfect!

I'm very wary when it comes to screenplays, specifically when a first-time writer knocks it out of the park because I then find myself having a preconceived notion that they will always be that good. To me, one of the absolute best films of 2012 was The Place Beyond the Pines. Until now, writer/director Darius Marder hadn't really done anything of note since his contribution to the screenplay for that aforementioned film. Well, he has now made a film of his own, both writing and directing, and he's now two for two in my book because Sound of Metal is a fantastic piece of indie filmmaking. Now available on-demand, here's why Sound of Metal more than warrants your time.Beginning with a concert scene that expresses just how passionate Ruben (Riz Ahmed) is about drumming, it doesn't take long before the film sends his life into a downward spiral. Losing his love of music due to his now gradual and rapid hearing loss, Ruben must come to terms with the fact that he may never be able to hear again. Trying to find peace and solace after years of drug addictions, this is the final, and biggest test of his life yet. From the very first moments, I was sucked into this film, but Ahmed's performance also helped with that, because it's honestly one for the ages. I have seen him many times over at this point, but his commitment to this character floored me. There were multiple occurrences, even though I couldn't relate to the character, that I felt the pain he was going through. This also leads me to the use of sound design.From the overly loud opening to the near-silent portions of the film, the sound design was one of the biggest characters here. I have to give major props to the entire sound department. There are times where it seems natural that we would be hearing things the way Ruben is, but then the film shifts back and forth in order to show the difference. On top of that, there are moments where not a single noise or music queue is heard at all, which made for a much more engaging film in my opinion. His performance, along with how the sound design reflected it, was simply perfect.Films that revolve around a likeable character who has to overcome insane odds are very difficult for me to dislike unless it's just poorly made, so I'm slightly biased for stories like these. With that said, as much as a loved this film, I can't quite call it perfect because the portions of the film that were dead silent are both the best and worst parts of the movie in terms of pacing. Yes, I was engaged from start to finish, but the quiet elements sometimes brought the film to a halt. In retrospect, I still enjoyed all of those moments as well, but that, in particular, is what is keeping me from giving this one a perfect score.Overall, Sound of Metal was easily one of my most anticipated films of this year simply due to who was writing and directing. This is the type of film that has talent littered throughout. Whether you're talking about the wonderful central performance by Ahmed, Olivia Cooke's great supporting role, or even the calm and collected performance that Paul Raci gives as Joe, never once did I question the acting here. Although I haven't had the chance to see a lot of editor Mikkel E.G. Nielsen's work, I will absolutely be keeping an eye on him in the years to come, because his work here inspired me. I loved nearly everything about this film and it's easily one of my top recommendations for this year. Sound of Metal is a home run.

reviews.review_title: "The world does keep moving, and it can be a damn cruel place. But for me, those moments of stillness, that place, that's the kingdom of God."
reviews.content: I don't like to overhype movies, but this might be my favorite of the year. You can tell that Riz hung out with the deaf community to get a feel for what it would really be like to lose your hearing, and his connection to them makes this feel special. While I do agree that Riz Ahmed was amazing in this, I also give major kudos to Paul Raci. I would want a mentor like him in my life.

Putting your character in so much pain and then judging every single one of his actions? WOW!
Acting and Sound Mixing are fantastic, though.

reviews.review_title: Sound of Metal (2020, Darius Marder) I sense the message, but I also see a flawed moral stance
reviews.content: 'Sound of Metal' is one of the critical darlings of 2020. It has landed on over 50 critics' top ten lists and has been nominated for six Academy Awards. It is directed by Darius Marder who also co-wrote the screenplay with his brother. His most notable project outside of this was writing the Ryan Gosling film 'The Place Beyond the Pines'. 'Sound of Metal' features Riz Ahmed in an amazing performance as the drummer of metal band who loses his hearing and thereby has his entire world turned upside down. This film has some superb elements in direction for not being an extremely directed film if that makes sense. It isn't a story that demands flashy direction, but you still get some very excellent shot selections. The script is well written and wonderfully acted by all. Sound editing is also very apparent as we, as the audience, are privy much of the time to how Ahmed's character Ruben's hearing is functioning in a given scene. While I think this film is constructed well, and executes its intended plot with a great degree of acumen I had a much different experience watching this film than most of the critics who adored it. I struggled greatly with the moral stance the film took and ultimately it made me appreciate this film less.The plot here is fairly simple and straight forward without too much in the way of nuance. Ruben is a drummer in a metal band named Blackgammon along with his girlfriend Lou, played by Olivia Cooke, who fronts the band. Rather suddenly Ruben's world is thrown into chaos when he loses his hearing. Ruben struggles briefly trying to continue to perform but after a visit to a doctor realizes he requires a different path. Ruben is also a recovering addict so there is fear that he could revert to that although it is an avenue that is never really explored. Through his sponsor though Ruben is taken into a shelter for recovering addicts who are also deaf. Many have built a life their and Ruben finds a place of sorts, and learns to start adapting to his deafness rather than just cursing it. Ruben secretly still longs for life with hearing through cochlear implants. He decides to sell everything he owns and get the surgery. Upon discovering this he is turned out of the deaf community as if he is a leper because he is no longer one of them. Ruben's implants are activated and from the first moment his hearing is dissonant and discordant. He journeys to Paris where Lou has become comfortable with her new life as she has reconnected with her wealthy father. Ruben realizes their time has passed and he leaves and the final shot shows him on a park bench, and he takes off the hearing aids and the harsh noise vanishes and he smiles bathed in the now welcoming silence.Nominally I get it. It is trying to impart a message that nothing is inherently wrong with deafness and that only once Ruben embraced his new reality did it look like he was on the path to some kind of inner peace. The problem is that the film seems to take an extremely rigid moral stance against hearing, or more specifically deaf people who seek to hear. I understand that the general principle demonstrated at the shelter that deafness is not an illness or something to fixed is staunchly held by the deaf community and admirably so, but I believe in embracing deafness you don't have to denigrate anyone who feels like wanting to hear like it is a morally reprehensible or evil action. I believe this would be true for anybody, but it is especially true for Ruben who's passion and livelihood was directly connected to his ability to hear. He was ostracized from the deaf community when they learned he had gotten surgery to "fix" his hearing. The head of the facility even compares Ruben's behavior regarding wanting to hear again to his addiction. So wanting to regain his lost sense is somehow comparable to heroin use? It would be one thing if it was just that deaf community who treated Joe this way, but the movie also inherently takes that stance as they make it apparent his cochlear implants aren't functioning like he wants them too, and they never revisit the doctor to figure out anything. You are just led to make the decision that the surgery was clearly a poor decision which is rectified when, at the end, he removes the glorified hearing aid presumably accepting once and for all his new and all encompassing deafness. The more I think about about it the more it actually annoys me, and it wouldn't be bad if Ruben came to this decision via free will but instead the movie itself is plotted to make the decision for him. I actually have a friend who had degenerative hearing all his life and got cochlear implants, and never once have I heard him lament that decision. I am all for deaf people feeling included and empowered and concur that the ability not to hear is not the debilitating handicap that most hearing people would perceive it to be, however, this film rather than being a celebration of that life takes a moral stance that places it more in the realm of reverse discrimination as it points a judgmental finger of recrimination. Ultimately I would give this a slightly positive review for the things it does right, but also can only go so far for all the things I believe it fumbles.Eric's Grade: C+

reviews.review_title: Powerful, strong performances, and giving you the insight when one loses there hearing.
reviews.content: 4 out of 5 stars.Sound of Metal is a good drama film about a metal drum player losing his hearing. He cant hear sounds. He goes into a deaf community to learn and coop without the use of sound.Strong plot. Ruben (Riz Ahmed) is a drum player. And a former drug addict. Stubborn once he discovered he lost his hearing. Desperate to get the hearing implant device but at an expensive cost. He joined a community where he meets a group that teaches him the other way of living around it.Great performances by Riz Ahmed. Olivia Cooke. And Lauren Ridloff who plays a teacher for a class of deaf children.One thing i did not like was the movie was a bit slow moving in the third act. Dragging out the exposition. Spending more long camera stills.

Riz Ahmed. Note this name. Riz Ahmed stars as Ruben in this unique story about a man who experiences a life crisis. Rarely have I seen an actor who masterfully manages to show all aspects of experiencing a personal tragedy. The film is spiced with supporting roles that give Ruben and us who look for hope and insight. The film also challenges; What would you do if the person you loved got a serious diagnosis?The film is strong and very engaging, but never tends to be melancholy or tear-jerking. I thought it was a great experience to see this one! It will be exciting to follow Riz Ahmed's career further. Hope he gets roles like this.

Not a lot of movies focus on the deaf community; this might even be my first movie about the deaf community. And after watching Sound of Metal, I can now say that I really liked this movie. It has really solid acting performances, especially from Riz Ahmed. It has great sound design and the editing is smooth.Sound of Metal is a movie about one specific character, Ruben. And there's great character development, and what I love so much is that there's character development up until the final scene. The story is simple enough, but it has a really calm pace to it, which gives it a melancholic vibe. The directing and cinematography also has this melancholic vibe; the whole film had that atmosphere, so if you don't like sad movies, then this probably isn't the movie for you. And the ending is great. I feel like a lot of movies struggle to have a meaningful, emotional ending, but here, the ending is simple and easy to understand. Sound of Metal is a great movie. It might not be for everyone, but I really enjoyed this movie, and it deserves a watch if anyone is interested.

I'll start out saying that I'm a sober, frequently touring rock musician and I didn't find any of the stuff about those subjects to be lame or unrealistic. That being said, this movie isn't about being a musician, and that's probably why it didn't come off as cheesy or lame. I thought Ruben being four years sober to be a nice addition and almost a necessity to tell this other road to recovery story, that's pretty gut wrenching at times like all good recovery stories are. The acting is superb here, mainly by Riz Ahmed and Paul Raci. I loved Paul Raci in this film... his farewell to Ruben was very heavy and so well acted. It felt like I was watching a documentary. Ahmed was fantastic and really did his homework here. This movie was written for an actor to take home an Oscar, and if Riz Ahmed gets it, it would be very well deserved. Honestly, I think Paul Raci would be a great pick for best supporting actor as well. This is a heavy drama, but a beautiful movie. Some people have issues with the end... well, those people clearly missed the entire point of the movie and have probably never thought about anything in life with any sense of real depth. The ending is beautiful. And perfect. It's a great story with fine acting. Great movie. And I also wanna give a shout out to Surfbort's cameo at the merch table, nice little touch there... Made it more believable. Hi guys.

I thought this movie would live up to the hype, but I was totally bored for most of the two hours. Ahmed's performance is good, but not amazing. There's just not much holding this movie together. I felt let down because it sounded like the movie would be very emotional and fulfilling.

Sound of Metal starts with rock/metal duo Blackgammon at a concert.No wonder with all that noise passing for music, drummer Ruben (Riz Ahmed) loses most of his hearing.Music being Ruben's livelihood. Going deaf is catastrophic not only for him but singer and his girlfriend Lou (Olivia Cooke.)They have been together for four years and both have help each other to work through their personal issues.Ruben is a recovering heroin addict. Lou used to cut herself due to past trauma.This setback could push Ruben back to his addiction issues. Cochlear implants may be beneficial but it is not covered by his medical insurance.Possible help comes in the form of a rural retreat for deaf recovering addicts. It is run by Joe (Paul Raci) who lost his hearing in the Vietnam War and became an alcoholic.It means he has to leave Lou behind and lose touch with the outside world. Soon Ruben learns sign language but he wants his old life back.Director Darius Marder serves away from the easy options these kind of dramas take. The film is really a character study about Ruben. You expect that somehow either Ruben or Lou will have a serious relapse.Riz Ahmed gives a mesmerizing performance by utilising his skills of minimal acting. There is a lot of stillness and portraying mood with his eyes.The film does lose touch with Lou and that diminishes the movie when she is not around.The retreat was a strange place. There is a nearby school where Ruben goes to spend time with the children. He learns sign language and he teaches the kids how to drum. I just kept wondering whether all these recovering addicts have been vetted by the police?What was the deal about the people in the retreat not being able to contact loved ones? Ruben and Lou are interdependent on each other and as Ruben mentions, she would have nowhere to go. It turns out that Lou has somewhere to go, but it is thousands of miles away.I did have issues as to why Joe thought Ruben wanting implants was a bad thing. He is trying to mitigate his disability. It is like saying that a man who has lost a part of his arm should get used to the loss of his limb and not get a prosthetic.The film has a coda set in France. Ruben realises that his old life of touring with Lou has gone. Lou starts to become anxious and itch her old wounds when he mentions touring again.The film is left open ended. Ruben realises that he might have to get used to his new silent world.

I saw "Sound of Metal", starring Riz Ahmed-Venom, Rogue One:A Star Wars Story; Olivia Cooke-Ready Player One, Bates Motel_tv; Paul Raci-The Glimmer Man, Dragon:The Bruce Lee Story and Lauren Ridloff-The Walking Dead_tv, Wonderstruck.This is a great depiction of someone loosing their hearing and how it feels to be them. The movie uses captions at the bottom of the screen-throughout the whole film-to show a representation of what Riz is experiencing. Riz plays a heavy metal drummer that begins loosing his hearing because of his profession and the gradual way his deafness gets worse and worse is very detailed. Riz actually learned to play the drums and how to use sign language for the role. Olivia plays his girlfriend and the lead singer of their band-which, as far as I could tell, consisted of just the 2 of them. After Riz tries to push through and continue playing with his handicap unsuccessfully, he seeks help from a group that teaches deaf people how to manage using ASL-American Sign Language. Paul is the leader of the group and Lauren is a teacher, and they both try to help Riz learn to deal with his anger. There is another option put to Riz, having ear implant surgery, but it can be expensive-anywhere from 40 to 80 Thousand dollars.It's rated "R" for language and nude images and has a running time of 2 hours.Although it is a great showcase for Riz-he is really good-it's not one that I would buy on DVD to watch over and over again. It would be a good rental.

Excellent movie with great acting, how actors are made for certain roles like Denzel in Training Day. Riz Ahmed is born to play this part truly carries the movie. His presence on the screen is definitely worth to watch. I hope he gets recognition for this role even maybe a gold statue but it's unlikely.

reviews.review_title: Worthy of the hype, no question
reviews.content: Highly recommend!Riz Ahmed gives an incredible performance as Ruben, not only did he make me care immensely for the character but he also makes Ruben feel like a real person. You can tell he put a tonne of effort into this and it really does show.Away from Ahmed, Olivia Cooke (Lou) and Paul Raci (Joe) are also very good performers, while it's nice to see Lauren Ridloff (Diane) involved - she's great in 'The Walking Dead', while she is soon to be in the MCU's 'Eternals' as well.So much heart to this. I couldn't possibly say with 100% certainty for obvious reasons, but it seems to do a terrific job at telling the story that it intends to. That's not always the case, so the filmmakers deserve praise for that - as well as for the sound design et al.'Sound of Metal' is worthy of the hype, no question.

Great idea for a movie but once again, very poor execution. This is the last Amazon Prime original movie I am going to watch. They have all been so awful - a mix between HBO and Lifetime. I have lost hope in the possibility of millennials creating a movie with positivity, a plot that makes sense, and the need to use token SJW characters.

Riz Ahmed is magnificent in this tale of a young drummer who begins to lose his hearing. Paul Raci is superb also as the "teacher" who tries to help him to adapt to this life changing challenge. A sensitive and intelligent film that after a slow start grabs your attention and your emotions.

reviews.review_title: Stressful, powerful and extremely well made
reviews.content: Great performances and sound and the story moved forward with confident pace. The characters reacted and developed incredibly realistically and you could feel the desperation, panic and confusion in the early stages. The film showed some harsh realities but never judged its characters and skillfully presented them on their own journeys, independent of the protaganist. Overall I found it a stressful watch at times but it was powerful and extremely well made.

Greetings from Lithuania.To say that 2020 was a weird year for cinema is like to say nothing. What emerged from ruins of 2020 were some good movies, and overall i would say that it was pretty good year to find some descent movies. And just now i watched "Sound of Metal" (2019) which so far i could say is my favorite film from 2020. Well technically film was made in 2019 but still."Sound of Metal" (2019) is a superb movie that has lots of things going for, and i think it succeeded on them. Its not a perfect film, yet I'm still giving it 10/10 because i enjoyed it very much. Performance by Riz Ahmed was his best one so far. Its a terrific performance that glued this story. Also this film was a superb character study drama. And it also showed us a bit of what its like to loose hearing. Like in "The Father", another kinda similar movie in its theme and tone this movie puts you in a shoes of a person with disorder. But while "Father" had no light at the end of the tunnel so to speak, "Sound of Metal" does have one. When Ruben finally accepted his fate and found comfort in silence, then i knew that this movie has accomplished something great - it left me to believe that that there is hope when dealing with this kind of problem.Overall, "Sound of Metal" is a superb movie that works as a great character study movie, superb portrayal of a hearing disorder and even one that is a bit inspirational at the end. As one character putted in this movie - "you have to learn to be deaf".

reviews.review_title: Riz Ahmed's performance is this film
reviews.content: I'm a little lost for words to describe this film... it is a journey for both the protagonist and the viewer. It is evocative and intimate. The acting is powerful. It really is an actor driven vehicle. It is not about Metal music, so if you are not a metal head, be patient with the opening minutes of noise, turn down the volume and wait. It actually becomes somewhat of a study of silence. It was nominated for 6 Oscars (2021). I don't think it will win Best Picture but it is definitely worthy of its nominations. If the competition wasn't so stiff for Actor in a Leading Role, Riz Ahmed would be a contender. His performance is a 10. But, for the whole film, I give this an 8 (very good) out of 10. {Drama}

Another film in competition for the Oscars 2021 with a great theme, but rather poorly realized, by an author completely unknown to me, Darius Marder.First of all, let's clear up a few untruths that are presented in the movie, namely, most medical insurances, even in the US, cover operations in cases of hearing loss. Then, the implant placement operation is always performed first on one side, never on both at the same time. And most importantly, couples in such situations are most often encouraged to go through together e.g. Learning sign language, and not being forbidden to do so for some mysterious reason.On the other hand, criticism of the plot, according to which it is illogical for the main actor Riz Ahmed to continue making noise immediately after receiving the diagnosis (a couple of months of rehearsal is not enough to call even the most talented actors drummers), really doesn't stand, because it is natural for each of us, and especially the character as presented in the film, to need time to accept and face the new facts in our lives. It is these moments that are, in my humble opinion, the greatest value of the story. Unfortunately, the film did not go any further than that, and that is also the biggest complaint, because it has obviously long ago become a trend to shoot stories without any messages and conclusions.The biggest praise goes for the supporting female role of Olivia Cooke, who, in addition to inspiring acting, allegedly performed all the music scenes live on her own.In any case, the film deserves a passing grade, unlike some other nominated works, which did not manage to come up with the topics they set out to do. Sometimes it is better no ending at all, than one indulging in the mere commercial taste of the audience, with an extremely illogical plot and maximally stereotypical male characters, using "subverted expectations", as in the so-called revenge-feminist "Promising Young Woman", which is also in competition. We will see who will do better at the awards ceremony in April.

reviews.review_title: Superb storytelling on the absence of sound
reviews.content: It sounds strange to talk of the serenity deafness may hold for some, but Darius Marder's new project "Sound of Metal" is both a cathartic and stressful insight into the lives of those living without the gift of hearing.Brilliantly channeled by Riz Ahmed, Ruben's rapid decline into silence is a great watch, balancing the abject lows of a drummer losing his gift against someone finding his purpose.Ruben and his girlfriend Lou (Olivia Cooke) have no time to comprehend nor stem his hearing's demise; a brutal wake-up call for both members, throwing their business and relationship straight under the bus.This is not, however, where the story decides to meander: instead, an inspired move to take the characters out of their comfort zones and into a new community is where the plot grabbed me.Riz Ahmed has received serious award attention (and deservedly so), but Paul Raci dominates his scenes. His benevolent but principled mentor role curtails Ruben but still inspires him - not an easy thing to convey on screen in a limited timeframe. His chemistry with Riz is great, propelling the centre of the film and was my favourite element.Deafness is a tricky principle to translate meaningfully to the screen, but "Sound of Metal" takes great care with the audio. Silence, noise and music are all core concepts and treated respectfully, and this movie is all the better for it. Furthermore, sign language scenes are unusual but entirely warranted and fascinating to watch. Fortunately, the quality elsewhere is equally high, and the cinematography is itself compelling and uniquely shot.As this year's fairly limp offering of films goes, "Sound of Metal" comfortably rises above the white noise of Hollywood dramas we've been inundated with. Don't avoid this movie if you feel like heavy metal will alienate you: it is such a minor part of this film that you will be lost in the compelling characters faster than you can think.

This is a pretty important movie, I think it may be very helpful for people with recent hearing loss. Other than that, in itself, it is a pretty good drama about a forced complete change of lifestyle and adaptation to it but it wasn't extraordinary in comparison to similar films. I must say that I'm kind of disappointed by the fact that there was barely any metal in the film, I'm a metalhead myself and for a film with such a premise I expected a lot of metal music, but there was very little of it. I know metal music is not the point of the film, but still.

reviews.review_title: Interesting idea, but eh.....I thought it was a bit over the top
reviews.content: Just an FYI.....anyone who plays drums like this dude will be deaf in 30 minutes. He plays drums like every moron who sits behind a kit at any Guitar Center in the world. The movie is riddled with stereotypes and cliches that doesn't make it stand out in any significant way.

So I just finished watching this movie and while it is very good, I do think that a lot of things don't really get explained like how Ruben lost his hearing in a matter of seconds, how much time he spent in the deaf community, if it was a short time it seems like he picked up on everything strangely quick and if it was a long time why did his hair never grow any longer especially since it was shot chronologically, where did he get the money to spend 4 weeks in a motel after barely being able to afford the surgery, or even to keep buying packs of cigarettes for that matter. Maybe I'm just being nit picky and in the grand scheme of the movie none of that stuff really matters too much but it does leave a little to be desired. Overall though I did very much enjoy the film and it really gives a new perspective on something I had never given much thought to.

First off I'd like to thank the great Pete Tong & Michael Dowse for making the original version of this film detailing the story of Franky Wilde as he struggles with drug addiction & the horrors of going def & being an electronic music producer & international DJ. Second of all, we'll, no actually that's it. Stop hailing this movie as one of the greats of all time. Watch: It's All Gone Pete Tong & see a truly great film that was made almost 20 years before this play-for-play rip-off with slight not so shuttle changes to attempt to come off as original.
Definitely this movie isn't for everyone. May be silence is good but not for everybody.

This movie avoids every cliche. Every time I thought I knew what was coming next, I was wrong. After the first ten minutes, you wonder - where can it go from here? And where it goes is beautiful and feels authentic. All the performances are outstanding. Riz Ahmed can do so much with just a look. The script has such wonderful moments, wonderful lines. I could keep going, but you should just watch it. Find the stillness for yourself. ;)

This film is about learning to live with your limitations. I'm a disabled vet and it took me decades to accept it. Now, I'm just thankful to be alive in any physical state as long as I have my mind intact. Every breath is a gift.

Probably the most notable thing about 'Sound Of Metal (2019)' is its masterful sound design, which is used to fantastic effect in order to put you in the perspective of its recently deaf protagonist. It keenly conveys an experience that most members of its audience won't be familiar with, proving that cinema really does have the power to put you in someone else's shoes and promote a proper sense of empathy. It's brilliant to behold. The sound isn't the only good thing about the film, though. The isn't really about being deaf, although that does play a large part in it. Instead, it's about an addict who has to overcome yet another hurdle in his quest to stay sober. The character development at the core of the piece isn't about 'curing' deafness or even overcoming it and that's incredibly important. The piece is really good when it comes to representation, with actual deaf actors and proper use of ASL, which is really refreshing - even inspiring - to see. Ultimately, it's an uplifting affair. Its lead performance is absolutely phenomenal, too. It's a masterfully made character study that's compelling, energetic and, even, quietly affecting. 8/10.

reviews.review_title: Deaf People Shows Us How To Live...
reviews.content: A heavy metal drummer's life shatters when he starts losing his hearing and now he has to live a completely different life as a deaf person. A poignant yet powerful story about the journey that deaf people go through but still they make the best out of their life. Riz Ahmed gives a fantastic performance as this guy with past demons who found a girlfriend and meaning in his life but everything falls apart with this new revelation, and how he struggles to adapt to his deafness. Exceptional sound design gives the viewers a very immersive experience of how deafness affects oneself. The relationship Ruben shares with his girlfriend is beautiful, passionate & heartbreaking. A lesson in how to live life and accept it for what it is.

reviews.review_title: Fine performances, plodding pace, somewhat predictable for Act 3
reviews.content: It took me picking up where I left off to finish the movie. It is a very good movie. Just not so much to my liking. It was nominated for awards and justifiably so. Nevertheless, not my taste. That said, WATCH THIS MOVIE!

reviews.review_title: Affecting take on the overcoming physical adversity genre
reviews.content: I watched Sound of Metal the day after I watched The Father, and this may have colored my view of the film. I was expecting The Father to be a well-done but conventional drama, and it turned out to be wildly original.Sound of Metal, on the other hand, is a well-done but conventional drama.The movie follows a punk drummer who loses his hearing and goes to a retreat for deaf people who are also in 12-step recovery. Riz Ahmed is excellent as he moves through denial and fury and the like with the help of a stern but nurturing father figure.The film has excellent sound design, letting you experience the quick hearing loss and the muted world it leaves behind.It apparently cheats for dramatic effect from time to time - for example, insurance *does* cover the surgery he's desperate for. It also makes it seem like no one is properly explaining anything to the guy, which, like the insurance thing, lets the movie go for big dramatic moments but doesn't ring true.This is a good movie, but outside of the sound design it's a very conventional one that follows a well-worn path with some slight variations. It's worth watching, but don't expect anything new in the genre.

Sound of Metal is a great watching both because of the themes explores and because of how it is crafted. In particular the movie is about the acceptance of a sudden disability and this fight is really interesting to watch. But what makes this movie memorable is how it is done because it mixes the sounds in order to somehow try to let you feel the struggle of the protagonist, it tries to let you experience deafness like him. I have to say that this movie was really memorable to me because of its original nature. Sound of Metal is a movie worthy of watching, at least it will be a something different to experience.

Movies about losing one of the key senses related to the art form intrigue me. Most commonly, from "City Lights" (1931) to "Bird Box" (2018) or "The Invisible Man" (1933 and 2020, among other adaptations), it seems at least, that sense is sight, as motion pictures are primarily a visual medium, but they've hardly ever been entirely silent--not even silent films were silent, accompanied as they tended and tend to be by musical accompaniment and occasional sound effects or live narration. I've been tagging such use of "sight-analogy" on Letterboxd, it's such a frequent reflexive device. All the better, then, when art is featured in the picture. In the case of "Sound of Metal," the art is heavy metal music (hence the title, which also takes on something of a double meaning when the protagonist later drums with his palms on a metal slide in a key scene that a deaf child feels, or listens, to). Similarly, this music is not entirely audial, as there is an unmistakable look to the rock scene. Shown stereotypical pictures of how one dresses--what sort of tattoos or blonde highlights, e.g.--one might do well at guessing what sort of music they prefer. Nevertheless, "Sound of Metal" is about a drummer who loses his hearing and at least partly because of playing music. The consequence of which is to focus one's senses on the distinctive qualities of the art, whether music or, by extension, cinema.It helps that it's well acted, led by a standout performance from Riz Ahmed and a good supporting cast headed by Olivia Cooke, and well dramatized--even the drug addiction and scratching works--which makes for a nice conflation that the movie isn't just about what's important to art but also what's important in life--there being considerable crossover of both. If this doesn't get an acting Oscar nomination, it better at least get something for the sound. Few films feature such an acoustic focal point. "The Conversation" (1974) is an obvious exception, but not to compare this to what's probably the greatest exploration of sound design in film history, it should be indication enough of how good "Sound of Metal" is that the comparison even comes to mind. Featuring deaf characters, including some real-life deaf actors, draws attention to the picture's sound design, as well as to the image when the picture becomes silent as well. In general, I especially appreciate the shifts here between subjective and objective camera positions and the accompanying varying degrees of silence and sound and of seeing. The last silent scene is perfect. I don't think a better ending could've been made.

reviews.review_title: If you're over the superhero CGI crap you will enjoy this movie
reviews.content:
Again if you read any of my reviews, I don't repeat what's in the title.And I like real movies.The only thing I didn't like in this movie was the, few and far in between music.I grew up in NYC, I was raised at CBGB's, I did all the concerts, and I still go to music festivals, Dj's, clubs, you say music, I'm in it. I also have earplugs in every item of clothes I own. I always bring serious earplugs, but as a backup I have cheap earplugs everywhere. If I'm in a car with any family member, I have minimum one year plug in, with my mom...two. At home I have the earmuffs that they wear at the airport when they're directing jets, I wear those over earplugs at home if people are too loud, or if I'm over the music or background noise. For almost a year my friends or family thought I was listening to music... not, I was just tired of listening to them. But that's not why I liked it. This movie had great acting, story development, was innovative, smart, emotional, a new take on life, love, and how to be better.And it was ORIGINAL not some other take, on some played out concept like "The Map of Tiny Perfect Things" aka, "Ground Hog Day" number 6 or 7...
If you're not someone that thinks Marvel movies are great, you will love this!

reviews.review_title: It's not very good if we are being honest.
reviews.content:
This place is flooded with critic reviews from people who don't watch the movies they leave strong reviews for. This is one of those.
This isn't a good movie. It isn't emotionally compelling and it isn't good storytelling. It just kind of goes along. Riz Ahmed is great of course but you can't watch this movie just for his performance as it doesn't carry the movie. Just kind of a disappointment in every sense. You will leave feeling regretful that you watched it but little else.

reviews.review_title: Very good use of sound, good acting
reviews.content: The title wants to be a double play - him being a metal drummer and him hearing metallic/screechy sound after his surgery. The main actor plays the main character very compelling, his lack of acceptance of the new situation, having to forfeit his career as a musician. The movie shortens the way to a Cochlear implant to an online matter of a month or two - at the very least much shorter than the procedure would be in real life. After having used his resources and alienating the people from the church group by choosing to overcome his handicap, rather than accepting the common fate, it turns out to him, that the promise of the surgery is far from true and he can only find peace in silence, since the sound is so unnatural.Throughout the movie, the use of sound and especially muffled sound is very good. Other movies would have made him just act not understanding and hearing things but this way, people get a better idea how it is like. The only thing missing in my home cinema is some bass, so I don't know whether the movie tries to establish some bass sound that tickles the membrane and the belly, since that is something a deaf person should still feel.

reviews.review_title: Makes you appreciate how important our sense of hearing is when so many others don't have it so lucky
reviews.content: "Sound of Metal" is a drama film directed and co-written by Darius Marder. Starring Riz Ahmed, Olivia Cooke, and Paul Raci, it makes you appreciate how important our sense of hearing is when so many others don't have it so lucky.After remaining sober for four years, Ruben Stone (Riz Ahmed) travels across America in an RV with his girlfriend Lou (Olivia Cooke) playing the drums in their heavy metal band "Blackgammon". One day after performing at a gig, Ruben discovers he has permanent hearing damage from the frequent exposure to loud noises made from his band's music on stage. As it is too expensive for Ruben to undergo medical treatment to restore his hearing, Lou suggests he join a community for deaf people to help him deal with this new handicap. Despite some initial reluctance, Ruben eventually agrees and settles in with a small group of deaf people led by a former alcoholic Vietnam War veteran named Joe (Paul Raci).As we live our lives one day at a time, it is easy to take for granted each of the five senses we have at birth, with our sense of hearing being one of the most important of all. Without it, we wouldn't be able to properly converse with other people or experience some of the wonderful sounds of the world around us. "Sound of Metal" clearly aims to remind us of how we should be thankful to still have such a gift as there are many people out there like Ruben who would do anything just to get even a fragment of it back. From the moment his hearing is impaired, we can feel the frustration of what Ruben must be going through, especially considering that he is a musician whose livelihood is based entirely around audio-related matters. The perpetual ringing in his ears and faint vibrations echoing throughout his auditory nerves signify that his days of making music are numbered, and as a result, he is frightened of what lies ahead of him. As someone who has attended several concerts right up close to the front, I can say that the feeling of having your ears constantly ringing for days afterward is not a pleasant one, so it must be unbearable to someone who has to be around loud musical instruments all the time. This film does a solid job of placing its audience into the perspective of those individuals, and it does so in a respectable manner that never feels like it is mocking them or romanticising their plight for the sake of entertainment.Director Darius Marder gives us an authentic look into how deaf people cope with their affliction by not viewing what they have as a crippling disability but instead as a trait a select few are able to find common ground in. We watch as the members of this small community enjoy life through their four remaining senses, like the teaching sign language to hearing impaired children or demonstrating their artistic abilities through activities like drawing. It's nice to see someone like Ruben try to fit in with these people, as when he learns from them, we the audience learn something too. One scene in particular that I really liked was when Ruben showed his rhythmic drumming skills to one of the deaf kids by tapping his fingers on a playground slide they were sitting on. Although the two of them are unable to actually hear anything, the vibrating echoes are more than enough for the both of them to understand how impactful such an impromptu composition truly is. To further prove that the sound doesn't matter, the camera then zooms out to show that the real audio is simply light taps on metal that no one else would otherwise notice, emphasising that their sense of hearing isn't important for living in a moment like this.In a role that suits him well, Riz Ahmed demonstrates both his musical and acting abilities by playing the character of Ruben as an emotionally vulnerable yet strong-willed individual who is determined to not let his deafness define him as a person. Ahmed actually wore auditory blockers in his ears during most scenes of the film to give a sense of realism to Ruben's annoyance at his worsening hearing difficulties and it definitely shows at some points. At first, Ruben stubbornly refuses to take the doctor's advice of avoiding situations that place him near loud noises but as he comes to terms with his hearing loss, he becomes a more humble person over time. Even though this type of character arc is nothing new, it does help draw more attention to the very community it has our hero mingling with throughout the film. Paul Raci did a fine job as well playing Joe, the community's leader who also has his fair share of obstacles to overcome in addition to his deafness. Interestingly, Raci is actually an American Sign Language interpreter in real life so this is a good example of how the filmmakers have gone to a lot of trouble showing respect to the very group of people they made this film about in the first place.Overall, this film has successfully showcased the lives of those whose hearing difficulties are often overlooked by the general public. The very possibility that all of us could go deaf at some point in our lives, whether we're young or old, is certainly a cause for concern. However, what I like most about this film is that it shows we can still live happily in spite of these impairments and people like Ruben are there to remind us that we should always treasure moments like these because it's easy to forget how good things are until they're gone forever. In other words, you only get one pair of ears in life so use them wisely.I rate it 8/10.

Watching a musician lose his hearing is terrifying, & Ahmed is amazing. Not only does he lose his purpose, but he suddenly becomes utterly dependent on the care, kindness, & faith of others...including those he doesn't know (Raci is also amazing). You're constantly reminded of the extreme, inescapable life transition you're going through & the immense grief that comes with the loss. Marder deftly nails all that, but more impressive are his profound moments of serenity & joy that come from acceptance.

I liked it but I wouldn't heap the praise on it like others. It's good, it's got gravity to it and the performances are good but I wouldn't say it's a Oscar worthy movie in a society where there is so much available. It's got the 2000s vibe to it. With lack of ambient sound, grey tones and minimal music. Good but not great.

reviews.review_title: A solid movie with a little convulated second act
reviews.content: I liked the rawness about this movie- not relying on technicalities of filmmaking but on the natural aspects of it. Second act brought the air of obnoxious although most of the dialogues there were pretty distorted to not get a whiff of that upper class life. Still thought that moving the movie from where it started to that place seemed out of place and uppity. The whole French song scene and the duration of it was damning. The ending was beautiful and somehow made me feel good about the whole ordeal. A good movie with Riz and Paul Raci about a man losing his hearing and still finding his place in the world. Cheers.

Not worth the time. Some good character acting but the pacing is disjointed and the story was the weakest idea they could have gone with based on the title. Had this been about a metal band and built on the idea of the overly macho atmosphere pushing someone to the brink it would have been much more interesting. Instead we get a couple who enjoy...wailing? As their form of "music" (way to carry on the Hollywood tradition of misrepresenting Metal) and they don't really know how to communicate with one another, deaf or not. Shame, expected far better. Some nice scenes in rehab but that's about it.
It's like the writer had one basic idea and had to drag it out for 2hours. The lead is a good actor but the film is such a grind.

reviews.review_title: Messy. out of place and noise
reviews.content: The movie starts with noise - there is no music - it not metal. It is noise. No wonder the actor goes deaf. By 30 minutes you know how the movie is going to end; although there are no mystery turns that aww you or any prime points that would make you revisit the movie.The acting of Riz Ahmed is - out of his character. He is trying very hard to play deaf and failing. Over the top acting (rest of the character), missing substance and poor dialogues sums up the movie. The story could have been more if told differently, but it is not.There was a reality check situation in the story that made sense, but not to redeem the movie. The whole of the movie is in bits and pieces, and they do not find their right space until the end of the movie. Although the sound of metal is not the genre metal but the implants and static, the actor hears, or at least the director wanted us to listen to.

reviews.review_title: If you're in the audiology field don't watch
reviews.content: So many issues with the unrealistic portrayal of audiology and malpractice I've seen in awhile. As an audiologist, I unfortunately couldn't get over the major errors to give the movie a chance.

We all have a rough idea what it is to be physically deaf . Or do we ?
This brilliant film gives us insight into what impact sudden deafness can be like and also how people who live perfectly normal and happy lives having never been able to hear .During a series of adrenaline-fueled one-night gigs, itinerant punk-metal drummer Ruben begins to experience intermittent hearing loss. When a specialist tells him his condition will rapidly worsen, he thinks his music career - and with it his life
In a very poor year for movies thanks to Covid , this movie comes along and gives us hope for 2021.
Riz Ahmed is fantastic as the Ruben . Ahmed has proven what a versatile actor he is over the years and this is probably his best performance to date .What I love about this film is that questions the audience to whether sound is all it's cracked up to be.
You really do get to experience what it's like to lose your hearing and to be in total silence and sometimes that silence is beautiful.I really hope this is recognised in the awards season and Riz Ahmed in particular.

reviews.review_title: From one universal language to another...
reviews.content: The "misfortune" of "Sound of Metal" is to come so shortly after "Whiplash", the film that not only changed the general perception of drums as a background instrument but set the bar very high for music-themed films. I'm sure I'm in no minority if I say that I expected Darius Marder's film to be a companion piece to Damien Chazelle's debut as the story of a man who overcame the progressive loss of his hearing and learned to find his own tempo through the contact between the beater and the cymbals.Why else would you title the film "Sound of Metal" after all?I wouldn't go as far as saying there was a deliberate attempt to mislead viewers, I checked the trailer and the line between not saying much and false advertising is never crossed, but "Whiplash" left such a vivid mark and today's audiences are so demanding of movies about triumph over the handicap that I wish "Sound of Metal" could be a sort of "Miracle Drummer". In fact, it's just a straightforward and minimalist drama about a man named Ruben Stone (Riz Ahmed) learning to cope with deafness. That doesn't diminish the story at all but something with the main character being a musician kind of heightened my expectations. The film was good the narrative kind of let me down.Ruben was a heroin addict but lives in a RV with his girlfriend Lou, a singer played by Olivia Cooke. Ahmed is convincing as the street-smart underground itinerant artist, he's not exactly transcending but it's the kind of performances that get noticed when they come from new faces. His acting naturally blends with the intimate style of Marder's camera work that show the couple sharing a detoxicating smoothie, dancing together and discussing life, death and artist resemblances during a road trip across the Midwest. And then the 'everything's fine' chapter is interrupted by Ruben's sudden loss of hearing, that not only isolates him from the rest of the world -including his girlfriend- but forces him to isolate himself further more in order to fix it.I don't want to use the word 'handicap' out of respect for the film's message but I think it contradicts the very purpose of the first act. Marder shows deafness as anything but a handicap, if not medical, at least social in the way it sets obstacles that interfere with the steps of life we take for granted: communicating, working, shopping, hell, even telling someone you've got a problem. On that level, "Sound of Metal" is certainly among the best movies to deal with deafness and the sound department did a wonderful job as we could literally 'hear' the stressful silence at time and the more annoying stifled noises, not to mention the echoes and some "drop the mic"-like sounds occasionally bursting from the deadly silence. You could feel all the alienation and desperation in Ahmed's acting. And in that ordeal, you've got the sound of metal that resonates a little louder and allow Ruben to 'feel' the sounds and even communicate with one kid in the deaf people community.And yet the film insists that it's not a handicap and to be honest, I'm a little perplex about it.I understand that the film isn't there to make us feel sorry for deaf or hard-hearing people but by focussing on the 'emotional' journey, it kind of lessened Ruben's personal achievements. I guess it's all explained in a very insightful scene where the head of the community, Joe (Paul Raci), a former Vietnam vet who lost hearing during the war, tells Ruben that's it's all in the head, that he lost his family because of alcoholism not deafness. Probably meaning that most troubles we attribute to a handicap are due to our incapability to embrace it as a natural or normal thing that "happens" and that can bring new challenges or opportunities in life. I approve that idea, to a limit.It's one thing not to associate handicap with pathos but something that does prevent you from at least keeping on performing your job or having a normal life is handicapping. I don't think "handicap" is an offensive word. I have perfect hearing but my lousy vision forces me to wear glasses the size of goggles: when I drive, when I wake up in the dark or I keep my lenses for more than 12 hours, I can say it's a handicap. That I overcame it doesn't make me less envy people who have a good vision. Ruben kind of resigns himself and ends up teaching kids drums, which is a fine character arc closing.
