But maybe I expected more: Ruben learning to play by memory, be his own drummer, or being tempted to plunge back to drugs, there were many opportunities for the script to push the stakes a little higher but in the end, it's just about Ruben going through the various stages of acceptance and learning the language signs, befriending other kids and their teacher (Lauren Ridloff), collecting money for cochlear implants and meeting Lou again.While the film does make the learning of sign language captivating (it might be the one and only universal language, besides music), its conclusion is emblematic of a sad symptom of today's cinema where films choose the easy way. What lacked in the film was more bravura, the performance of Paul Raci is good but lacks some energy and never rises beyond the proverbial typical tough but lovable mentor-figure. He seems like he doesn't care and at the end we get to some scenes with Mathieu Almaric playing Lou's father as if we were supposed to care. I gather the point was to see her having changed too but I'm sure it could have been better than that depressing French upper class celebration... how about some drums anyway?"Sound of Metal" has a deep resonance of its own but as far as posterity goes, I'm not sure about the wavelength.

reviews.review_title: Profound and Real, 'Sound of Metal' feels a lot like life.
reviews.content: My Rating : 7/10It's a wonderful movie - just finished watching it and can say that it's very real to the harshness and unpredictable nature of life - the pain and agony of just bad luck - Riz Ahmed and the entire cast give a solid performance and while it's a slow-burn movie, it's fantastic to watch.Keeping it real, thanks guys!

I remember seeing clips of this film and the review by Mark Kermode on BBC News, I didn't know what it was about until I read more about, and with its multiple nominations during Awards Season, there was no missing I was going to miss it. Basically, Ruben Stone (Oscar, BAFTA, and Golden Globe nominated Riz Ahmed) is a professional drummer and one half of the metal duo Blackgammon, along with the singer and his girlfriend, Lou Berger (Olivia Cooke). They live in an RV while travelling across the United States to perform gigs. During a performance, Ruben suddenly starts to lose his hearing. He goes to a pharmacy seeking a diagnosis, and the pharmacist (Michael Tow) refers him to a doctor. An audiologist (Rena Maliszewski) performs a hearing test and finds that Ruben can only make out 20-30 percent of words he hears. His hearing will deteriorate rapidly, and although cochlear implants may benefit him, they are highly expensive and not covered by insurance. The doctor suggests that Ruben eliminate all exposure to loud noises and later undergo further testing, but Ruben continues to perform. Lou learns of Ruben's condition and wants to stop performing for his safety, but he wants to continue. Lou is also concerned about Ruben's sobriety, being a recovering heroin addict. With Ruben's hearing continuing to deteriorate, he is taken to and accepted into a rural shelter for deaf recovering addicts. The shelter is run by recovering alcoholic Joe (Oscar and BAFTA nominated Paul Raci) who lost his hearing in the Vietnam War and lipreads. They leave, as Lou is not allowed to live with him, and he only wants to get implants. Lou, anxious for his well-being, leaves and persuades Ruben to return to the shelter. Ruben attends meetings to learn sign language, bonds with the other members, and eventually settles into his new life at the shelter. He also spends time with teacher Diane (Lauren Ridloff) and her class of deaf children to participate in lessons and activities. Despite a shaky start, Ruben eventually finds peace, is comfortable to communicate in silence, and connects with the children and the rest of the community. He gives the children and Diane basic drumming lessons. Ruben's stay has been sponsored by a church, but Joe offers him a permanent residency, as an employee of the community, and tells him to think about it. Ruben periodically looks online to see what Lou is up to, discovering her to be experimenting with her own music in Paris. He gets his friend Jenn (Chelsea Lee) to sell his drums and other music equipment, and sells his RV. He uses the money to pay for the cochlear implant surgery. Ruben asks Joe to loan him money to buy back his RV while he waits for his implants to be activated. Joe refuses, commenting that Ruben looks and sounds like an addict. Joe is disheartened and asks Ruben to leave the community, as it is founded on the belief that deafness is not a handicap. Upon activation, the implants allow Ruben to hear, but the sound from them is heavily distorted and not what he was hoping for. His disappointment disrupts his attempts to regain his old way of life. Ruben flies to meet Lou at the house of her wealthy father Richard (Mathieu Amalric) in Paris where she has settled into a new lifestyle. Richard welcomes him and allows him to stay. Richard confides in Ruben that he did not used to like Ruben, but he recognises that Ruben has made Lou happy. At a gathering, Lou and her father perform a duet, and Ruben's finds that he cannot clearly hear the music with his implants. Ruben and Lou discuss the possibility of playing music and touring again. Lou anxious, but they both comfort each other. The next morning, Ruben decides to go for walk, leaving Lou sleeping. Bothered yet again by the distortion of sounds, he sits on a bench and removes the implant processors from his head, becoming comfortable with the silence. Ahmed gives a highly convincing performance as the former drug addict who finds his sense of sound disappearing and all the life-changing elements that follow, Cooke is good as his devoted girlfriend, and Raci (who learnt to sign because his parents were deaf) also stands out as the community shelter leader. Besides the great performances, and an emotional and authentic story of the devastating impact of someone becoming deaf, this film boasts a brilliant use of sound design, with moments of clever sound flickering and sometimes complete silence, assisted by good cinematography and the score by Nicolas Becker and Abraham Marder, a well-crafted and most watchable drama. It won the Oscars for Best Sound, and Best Film Editing, and it was nominated for Best Motion Picture of the Year, and Best Original Screenplay, and it won the BAFTA for Best Sound, and Best Editing. Very good!
This movie has a interesting story, but to me it doesn't pass emotion. A point that I liked is the sound, that keep up what the main character hear. It has potential to be much better.

IN BRIEF: Riz Ahmed is terrific in this emotionally charged drama about deafness.JIM'S REVIEW: (HIGHLY RECOMMENDED) Ruben is a drummer, one of the boys in the band who is slowly losing his hearing and trying to adjust to this hardship in Darius Marder's gripping drama, Sound of Metal.Although I am not a drummer, I can attest to this slowly-creeping silent world. Notching up the decibels on the radio and television or trying to understand simple conversations in these masked days of COVID are a few of the tell-tale signs for me and Mr. Marder brings his insightful observations to this dilemma. In his directorial debut, he creates a deaf world by using sign language captioning and modulating the sound from moments of silence to ear-piercing noise. His insightful approach allows moviegoers to become immersed in Ruben's physical crisis. (Kudos to the sound design by Nicolas Becker, a major player in the film's success. His skillful sound mixing takes us into the mind of a person going deaf and reimagines those sounds of silence.) The director also casts his film with mostly deaf actors, bringing an air of authenticity to this movie, even though his nebulous ending fails to complete his storytelling. The compelling screenplay by Derek Cianfrance and the director is filled with dialog that not only informs but draws one into its well-written characters and their relationships.Riz Ahmed plays Ruben. The actor creates a compassionate fully-dimensional character coming to grips with this new physical malady. He is simply terrific in this role. He conveys all the the rage, fear, and heartbreak that his character encounters. One hopes this intense performance is not overlooked by Academy voters. Providing strong support are Olivia Cooke as his loving girlfriend Lou and Paul Raci as Joe, his deaf mentor. (Mr. Raci is an accomplished actor/musician and a CODA, Child of Deaf Adults, and his background of this subject provides the counterpoint for those refusing to see deafness as a handicap.)The issue of hearing loss and its impact are never sentimentalized in Mr. Marder's movie. We watch Mr. Amhed's emotional performance as he travels to the beat of a different drum. And so does this riveting film. (GRADE: B+)

I waited to watch this movie and I don't know why, it seemed like it might be a movie that you need to be certain mood to appreciate.I was blown away.Riz Ahmed is incredible.... I don't remember seeing a performance better than him in this movie. I was mesmerised the entire movie and am struggling to find the words to describe the characters courage and anguish throughout the film.All actors are wonderfully cast and this is a movie that will stay with me for a long time.Amazing movie.

When I read the glowing NY Times review, my first thought was: "I don't like heavy metal; serves him right." But I know nothing at all about the lives of deaf people. This movie is an extraordinarily passionate description of what that is. I simply could not get it out of my mind.

reviews.review_title: Riz Ahmed excels in this haunting tale of a musician coming to terms with hearing loss
reviews.content:
In chalking off the 8th and final Oscar nominee for Best Picture, I stumbled upon one of the best lead performances I have ever seen in the film.Sound of Metal is all about Riz Ahmed as the British-Pakistani actor and former rapper takes us along on a musician's gut-wrenching journey in coming to terms with his deteriorating hearing.The way he portrays the character's mental and physical breakdown as he goes through the various stages of grief is astounding.Up for 6 Academy nominations this year, the sound design is so impeccable that it is just a foregone conclusion that the Amazon Prime original will land the Oscar for Best Sound.Hats off to director Darius Marder for this unique narrative style where he gives us an in-depth POV perspective of hearing loss.While Hopkins' portrayal in 'the Father' as well as Boseman in 'Ma Rainey's Black Bottom' will both be a cut above this for me, Riz Ahmed deserves all the plaudits he is getting and more.A career-defining performance. Prepare for an impactful, unsettling
watch that is sure to haunt you.

Loved everything about this movie. Becoming deaf or having any handicap is really not a "handicap." You just do things differently. Love love love the ending bc he figures out what is really important in life and follows through on it!!

"Sound of Metal" is a Drama - Music movie in which we watch a heavy-metal drummer losing his hearing and has to deal with his new reality. He needs to adapt and embrace himself along with understanding what happened. He needs to comprehend a lot of things and of course he needs time and space to do it.I liked this movie very much because it presents with a very good way a sensitive subject from different perspectives. This movie reminded another similar movie, "It's All Gone Pete Tong" of 2004 which is based on the life of the famous DJ Frankie Wilde who lost his hearing. The direction which was made by Darius Marder, it was very good and he presented very well his main character and his story along with how his life changed due to hearing loss. The interpretation of both Riz Ahmed who played as Ruben and Paul Raci who played as Joe were simply outstanding and they made the difference. The combination of both actors worked very well and the result was two nominations, one for Best Performance by an Actor in a Leading Role and another for Best Performance by an Actor in a Supporting Role, respectively. To sum up, I have to say that "Sound of Metal" is an amazing movie and I strongly recommend everyone to watch it.

Indispensable and vital message for everyone who doesn't know how to embrace themselves. Either you got certain physical disabilities or not, this picture brings up distinctive postulates that make people think outside the box. In fact, this film genuinely portrays our perplexity and embarrassment as regards self-recognition and self-acceptance. I'm not a big fan of Riz Ahmed, but I gotta acknowledge that he really killed it! He def deserved an Oscar nomination for this role, and I looked at him from a completely different perspective.

I used to prepare more focus to watch drama movie since it usually take more "thought". This one surprisingly make me go with the story pretty easy..tbh, I really amaze about the story. It so powerful and light at the same time. Riz ahmed do an incredible performance, powerful.Great ambiance, it take something more to make the set this quiet to delivery a story. This movie will not entertain you, it will teach you.

reviews.review_title: SOUND OF METAL is one of the best films of the year!
reviews.content: If you enjoy reading my Spoiler-Free reviews, please follow my blog :)With moderately high expectations, Sound of Metal genuinely surprised me. Darius Marder and Abraham Marder's exquisite screenplay is the absolute standout, at the same insanely good level as Riz Ahmed's impressive performance. The former holds a meaningful, enlightening story about not only the deaf community but also about accepting our limitations as something that's a part of us instead of taking it as a handicap. Except for a couple of unnecessary scenes that could have made the movie a bit shorter, the two-hour duration is quite fair, boasting a very captivating narrative.Countless storytelling technical details elevate this film into one of the best of the year. From an apparently simple yet extremely clever use (or absence) of subtitles for sign language to emotionally compelling dialogues, an outstandingly realistic atmosphere surrounds the movie throughout the entire runtime. Never, not even for a second, the viewer needs to deal with an over-the-top reaction, cheesy conversation, or a typical Hollywood, overdramatized moment. Darius Marder has terrific control of the tone, keeping it exceptionally grounded.Riz Ahmed delivers what I believe is his career-best display, incorporating his character's hearing disability in a seamless fashion. His subtle facial expressions and body movements are essential for the performance that can easily guarantee him dozens of nominations. Olivia Cooke (Lou) is also excellent in her role. Technically, huge praise to Daniël Bouquet's cinematography, which insists on an almost documentary-style composition by applying standard camera angles and shots often seen in this type of feature, helping to generate the before-mentioned authenticity.One of my absolute favorite films of 2020.Rating: A

What to say about this one..... well acted with the material given, but sheesh it is your basic Oscar bait formulary drama. VERY slow paced. Lead loses his hearing, gets angry about it, finds redemption, falls from grace, finds redemption again, realizes he prefers the silence and his new life. I swear I've seen this movie a dozen times before, and somehow it keeps winning awards despite being the same rehashed story. Certainly not original, but I've seen worse. Middle of the road drama at best.

reviews.review_title: It looks amazing and sounds amazing
reviews.content: I liked how all sounds were so well done from most silent to the loudest ones.Great acting.I appreciate how much dedication this movie had taken.How Riz Ahmed learned sign language for his role.Olivia Cooke was good as always.Heartbreaking story.I couldn't imagine how hard for me would be lose my hearing.It would definitely be even harder if you needed your ears for your job, thing you love.Music.

reviews.review_title: "We're looking for a solution to this (pointing at 'third eye'/mind) not this (pointing at ear)"
reviews.content: Sound of Metal is a heart-warming film filled with a great message, acting performances, directing & cinematography, and sound mixing & sound editing. This film has everything. It has drama, romance, music and more.When something gets taken away from someone's life or when something gets to an end in someone's life, it could mean the beginning of a new thing, a better thing, a better life. A life where you will find yourself, your true self, you will start to feel every little detail around you, you will start to be grateful, you will see things differently, you might start to like things that you always thought that you might not like. Being deaf or blind or whatever doesn't mean your life stops or ends there, it doesn't mean that something is wrong with you, it doesn't mean that you can't do anything. You don't have to fix it, you just have to fix your "MIND" if you think that way. THIS IS SOUND OF METAL and that's why I love this film. The film is about life, love, accepting & loving your life whether it was good or bad, being grateful, feel and absorb everything and every moment around you and never give up.Sound mixing & Sound editing were perfect. Alongside Ahmed's great performance, the sound mixing & sound editing were showing exactly how Ahmed's character Ruben Stone, hears every single thing around him. It is like we the audience, are Ruben Stone. We are feeling what he is feeling and hearing what he is hearing. Loved how sometimes everything goes completely silent where we don't hear any single noise, and sometimes we hear everything that's going around him. The film shifts back and forth through that to show the difference. Hats off to everyone in this department who worked on it and got us this beautiful result.In addition, The directing & cinematography were absolutely amazing, they were portraying the different aspects of Ruben Stone's life in a creative and unique way.The film has a very great screenplay that is very well written. Some scenes will really touch your heart and they have a really deep meaning behind them. The film is also filled with quotes about life that are really deep.Riz Ahmed's performance was amazing and he was able to play Ruben Stone very very well. Really can't imagine someone else other than him to play Ruben. I really don't know what to say much about his performance other than, IT IS THE PERFORMANCE OF THE YEAR. Although Olivia Cooke did not have much time on screen, she was able to give a great performance as well.In conclusion, Sound of Metal is one of the best movies I have ever seen, I "HIGHLY RECOMMEND" every to watch it as soon as possible. It is new, unique, creative, emotional, genuine. It is just everything.My rating is: 8.5/10.

There's nothing wrong with the performances, but this movie -- slow, dreary, repetitive, and humorless -- exemplifies everything I hate about "significant" films. Poorly edited and devoid of dramatic momentum, this film raises "heavy, deep and real" to new levels of torpor and tedium.

reviews.review_title: Acting is stunning, plot has many, many holes
reviews.content: The acting from all of the protagonists is one of a kind...The plot on the other side, has too many holes. I couldn't empathise with the guy going deaf.It'd be a shocking, nerve wracking, scare full experience... he goes to the doctor; but he doesn't follow instructions from the professional. Stay away from loud noises!! His reaction; I keep playing in the band, to get my implants.Then, why the manager, recommends the deaf community and is the only option/best idea? Wouldn't someone going with him to the doctor would be best? Fully understand what's happening?Then the girl abandons him in the community and builds up her relationship with his dad... okI could go on and on... no logic behind each decision.I get the Oscar nomination for acting and sound, WOW! But for screenplay, it doesn't make sense.

reviews.review_title: Incredible solo performance. Rest of the film falls flat.
reviews.content: Riz Ahmed is outstanding in Sound of Metal. The film subject is so interesting and eye-opening that it's certainly worth a watch but sporadic moments of beauty and great acting don't make the entire film for me.

This was a sad movie. I don't have a disability, but I felt for Ruben's character in this. To one day be able to hear fine, and have it rapidly disappear? That's scary stuff. And you can't blame him for wanting to fix it. It was difficult for Lou as well, having to adjust for to this new development. Joe was tough but fair as a caretaker. And the ending was a bit of a surprise. This also had some good use of lighting and some pretty shots. Everywhere I've watched, people are saying this is a sure win for Best Sound, and there's no arguing with that.

reviews.review_title: A Tale as Heartwarming as it is Heartbreaking
reviews.content: Riz Ahmed delivers his career's best performance in a tale about growth in the face of great loss.The story is one that could have been about any degree of loss (a car, a lover, a friend, a family member), and it would have worked in terms of facing that loss and trying to fill that hole with something superficial. This story, however, revolves around the loss of hearing and the reason it works particularly well is because while it could have been any degree of loss, it was extremely foundational to the protagonist, as he is a musician, so the loss of hearing is one that particularly ruins him.While I won't go into any further detail, as to avoid spoilers, I will say that the resolution this film provides is particularly heartwarming and provides a particularly resonating ending to this story. A truly one-of-a-kind and once-in-a-generation film. 8/10.
Amazing acting - a tender and moving film. I was entranced from start to finish.Highly recommended.

reviews.review_title: Very good movie but a massive buzz kill
reviews.content: In what must be a career defining role Riz Ahmed plays a drummer in a punk band who suddenly and without explanation goes deaf. Thus begins his emotionally exhausting journey which sadly doesn't end well.The emotional intensity of this movie is at once it's strength and it's weakness. Just a little bit of lightness or even humour would have been welcome as it all gets a bit too much. There are the scenes in the deaf school which give a little relief but these only serve to make the ending all the more bleak.

It is nice to watch this movie but is not perfect. The end was clearly obvious from beginning. Riz Ahmed acting is perfect and the story is good but could be better. Anyway 6/10 for Sound of Metal is my opinion.

Although I think it ended well with the theme being either "Make the best of what you have" or "Always Adapt and never stop trying" it tended to be boring and not interesting during the bulk of the film. I'd recommend it even though it wasn't that great of a movie.

I don't doubt the performance of Riz Ahmed, but I could not finish watching this movie, found it so boring. Would make more sense it this was a true story which it is not. Maybe musicians or drummers can appreciate it more than me.

reviews.review_title: Good story, good message, and great sound design
reviews.content: I glad to see my favourite Four Lions star in this movie. The Sound design is such a major part of this film, as you would expect, but it was mostly great. The bumps and knocks that his muffled ears hear add soo much to the design.I like the messaging of his desire not being what he actually needs. Meaning his job as a drummer, and Lou, his girlfriend, are the reasons he wants his hearing to come back. But along the way of trying to live without hearing. He finds peace and happiness. As a theme, i think it works very well and i think its a very good message for disability not being a curse for life. He is taught that being deaf isnt whats most important, being happy and happy with yourself is. No matter if you have a disability or not.The film also stresses at points the idea of you have to want to better yourself for yourself and not external factors. I think it got it point across well and gave Ruben a good arc, with him finally having a moment of peace with no hearing aid.I like this film alot and i'll probably watch it again soon. The acting was pretty good. No one felt fake. The cinematography isnt very interesting but the characters and focus on the sound kind of covered up for that.Good film. Watch it.

reviews.review_title: A revelation into the life of someone who suddenly loses their hearing.
reviews.content: Movies have the power to give a perspective we might have no ability to understand. Much like the fantastic The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007) gave viewers a chance to experience life through the eye of a paralyzed man, Sound of Metal (2020) was a revelation into the life of a musician who suddenly goes deaf. There are so many aspects to sudden deafness that Sound of Metal provided insight to that opened my eyes to the struggles of this particular disability. Of course, while this is the obvious takeaway from this film, the meaning is much deeper than that.Ultimately, the twist Sound of Metal gives to the deafness narrative is the power of addiction. It's encouraging to see positive handling of previous addiction through accountability, but it's even more striking to see how addictions can take many different forms. Whatever gives us dopamine, we can become addicted to. While not as in-your-face as Requiem for a Dream (2000) is with the dangers of addiction, Sound of Metal is subtle with the lesser-known addictions. I never knew someone could become addicted to a person, let alone to the simple ability to hear.Of the Oscar nominees this year, Sound of Metal is certainly the most artistic. The cinematography was very deliberate to show the moments of quiet, but the sound design made all the difference in delivering the emotional impact of hearing loss. You don't realize how much hearing affects your life until you can watch a man struggle with not having that input while also "hearing" what he does (which isn't much). If Sound of Metal has one fault, it's that the focus on the art meant the story was a little simple. Sure, there are layers to its moral, but they all end up focusing on the same thing.A revelation into the life of someone who suddenly loses their hearing, I give Sound of Metal 4.5 stars out of 5.

The film infringes on a certain discomfort at different times, because it puts us in the protagonist's place, sometimes we have our hearing "impaired", or we only hear noises, or even the blurred vision when it seems uninteresting to see, it is a film about sounds and silence, the perspective is very interesting, despite the slow pace ... And the breaking of the scene, alternating between the vision / hearing of the protagonist and the viewer ... It deserves the Oscar for the best sound... Adorable...

reviews.review_title: Brilliant acting, writing, and use of sound. Story drags in 2nd half.
reviews.content: Ruben (Riz Ahmed) and Lou (Olivia Cooke), a couple, perform in an avant-garde metal duo. The music is raw, energetic, and LOUD!!! They have a tough but very happy life together, making music, touring, and loving. This all comes to a stop when Ruben, the drummer, loses his hearing. Their lives become completely unravelled. Ruben gets help but he must still figure out how he's going to cope with the change.The story was very compelling at first. I was totally hooked into what Ruben would do. How would he cope with this problem which would completely upend his life? It was a tough sad story. It took a while to realize that Ruben could not go back to the life he once had with his girlfriend Lou, no matter how badly he wanted. The school he went to built him up but they also were strict. It seemed very fundamentally Christian in a good way and in a negative way too. It built up a support network but it took away many basic choices from the individual. It was a very limiting experience and not for everyone.There was much of value in this movie. The use of sound especially was amazing. The visuals were quite solid and the acting was understated and quite lovely. The only problem was that about midway through the movie until near the end, at the school, the pacing just dragged. It was not an exciting way to tell it. There were too many dead moments - things that could have been either shortened up or made more interesting. It's a tough situation - to get an idea of Ruben's isolation and sparseness without making things boring.Riz Ahmed is absolutely stellar in this movie - he's so grounded and believable. Rather than get too emotional, he seems to struggle to contain his emotion and this makes his story even more heartbreaking and believable. Olivia Cooke is also brilliant and a good match to Ahmed. The movie was not nearly as interesting when she wasn't in it. The dynamics of Ruben and Lou were really the core of the movie. It was a beautiful life but it could no longer continue - how painful is that?

reviews.review_title: A film with the core belief that deafness is not a disorder
reviews.content: A realistic drama film about accepting deafness and drug addiction. Sound editing and the acting of Riz Ahmed (as Ruben) and Paul Raci (as Joe) is remarkable. The film's title could also be a innuendo to the distorted sound from cochlear implant that led Ruben to accept deafness instead of fixing it.
I found it very hard to sympathize with any of the characters, with the exception of Joe. If you want to see a much better movie about deafness and redemption watch It's All Gone Pete Tong.

As a film Sound of Metal has been highly praised from critics universally and having won several Oscars, along with more nominations.The acting is very strong as it has a realistic feel and tone. The story is solid but slightly different than expected. And of course it sends a strong and warming message.

Heavy Metal drummer Ahmed suddenly starts to lose his hearing and is persuaded to stay at a site devoted to helping the deaf - but can he overcome his denial and work in some isolation to move forward and will he have an expensive operation which might help him.Ahmed is impressive as a man unable to work out his place in the World now that he is deaf. Watching him slowly start to appreciate that he can survive the crisis and have a relatively normal life is quite engrossing and sometimes moving - the final scenes where he makes his mind up about how he is going to cope going forward are wonderful. Fine support from Olivia Cooke as his girlfriend.

reviews.review_title: Raw and gritty look at coming to terms with loss and facing acceptance.
reviews.content: "Sound of Metal" is one tough film that rubs on your feel and senses as a viewer you see what it's like to lose a health trait while it affects one's skill and love of their craft. Really a person should never take anything for granted. The movie is the story of Ruben(in a well done performance from Riz Ahmed) a hard living addled drug abusing heavy metal drummer who all of a sudden finds his life and world turned upside down once he starts to lose nearly all of his hearing. As the nightly grind of the loud beat and pounding of the drums in after dark clubs has finally caught up with him.This film is more than about loss, it then goes on a journey of dealing with one's new way of life and frame of mind. This really is a tribute to the deaf as Ruben finds out when he goes to a deaf and hearing loss camp that he now has to learn sign language to communicate. It really is a struggle and new go for him, the film is brash and to the point with this, yet at the same time it portrays the pain and grief that Ruben feels. Plus this film is a journey of love and feeling as Ruben still continues his love life joy with his gal pal Lou(Olivia Cooke).The way that sounds are showcased in this film is top notch from the hard and loud pounding of drum metal to the static and unclear new world of silence and hearing loss that Ruben deals with the way the scenes were crafted happens to be fine showcasing of polar opposite worlds. Really watching this film you will learn to love and respect what you have as you will not take anything for granted as it shows aspects of how life can change from the norm. Overall watch this film for it's harsh gripping look at loss and new acceptance.

The story of a drummer that suddenly loses his hearing and all his life crumbles as he is not able to play anymore. For a musician losing the most important tool is such a tragic event. Riz Ahmed who portrays Ruben, well represent the enormous torment that he needs to go through, and he is never able to accept his condition, even if for a moment seems to embrace his new reality. The main character will try to return to his previous life, but the price that will pay on a personal level, will be very high. Definitely not the average movie with an happy ending and a pretty realistic take on becoming deaf: an event that will change forever every single aspect of life, and how different people can cope with it.For almost the entire movie there is no music. This is a very nice choice by the director, as it will highlight even more the trauma felt by the protagonist. The audience will "lose" the hearing together with Ruben: for most of the time we will hear distorted and muffled noise, creating a sense of confusion. Most of the time things said by actors are pretty much incomprehensible, and I felt a sense of isolation and powerlessness. It is really easy to identify with Ruben and to really care about him. I felt really sorry and I root for him until the very end, hoping that he could find happiness with his new life.The acting is extremely good and I really enjoyed Paul Raci as Joe, the owner of a community of deaf people, trying to guide and make them find purpose in life, by teaching valuable lessons. Such an expressive and emotional performance, definitely a talented actor and a good discovery. Riz Ahmed completely nailed the part, absolutely an amazing performance, he was definitely able to show his skills. Really hope that in the future we can see him on more main roles, because he definitely deserve it.Amazon is releasing very good stuff in latest years, and I really hope to see more from them. This company is taking some big risks and should have more attention. I highly suggest this film, definitely a small gem, worth to be watched.

Having a deaf daughter with cochlear implants, itv portrays them unfavorably. I great it could discourage someone from getting them. I wish they did more research into how chicken l cochlear implant work and the audiology side of them. Also, they are covered by insurance, even Medicaid.

An impressive dive into a topic rarely explored. This was always going to be well-represented in awards season because it is powerful, it does cover an aspect of life people know little about, the acting was faultless and audio is used perfectly. As someone without any hearing problems it is hard to pin the accuracy of the film, however it certainly feels real and is by far a more in-depth look into the difficulties than anything previously seen.The plot is interesting without being entirely engrossing, and Ahmed doesn't do a single thing wrong, creating a relatable and likeable character with a backstory far deeper than the surface plot. Surrounding cast is good but particularly Raci who is the true supporting character in my eyes. It can get a little frustrating and it does drift off a bit at the end, but still a great film going far deeper than most do.

reviews.review_title: Symmetry of the Sounds of Metal
reviews.content: This very moving film deserves all the kudos it is getting. I was really impressed by Riz-Ahmed, Olvia Cooke, and especially Paul Raci, but also the actors from the deaf community. Others have commented on the meaningfulness of the film's title--I just wanted to mention a bit of symmetry regarding that. First, of course, the film begins with Ruben in the heavy metal band. Halfway through, when Ruben is at the deaf community home, he and a boy are leaning on a metal slide and discover they can listen to the subtly different vibrations of their fingers drumming on the metal. And then at the end, it is Ruben's dismay at the cacophonous sound of the metal church bells he is hearing through his implants that causes him to reassess everything.

reviews.review_title: An Auditory Revelation Powered By Riz Ahmed's Star-Making Showcase
reviews.content: Powered by a strong, spirited & soulful showcase from Riz Ahmed, Sound of Metal delivers an intense & emotional roller-coaster that will find a way to strike a chord with most viewers, if not all. Definitely amongst the better films of the year, it is a riveting & reverberating story of passion, addiction, acceptance & rediscovery, and is rendered on screen with both compassion & consideration.Co-written & directed by Darius Marder, the plot concerns a drummer who begins to lose his hearing and keeps the audience in close proximity with the protagonist at all times so they can relate to his agony & frustration as he comes to grips with his inevitable fate while also offering a much welcome insight into the experience of the deaf community, all of which is portrayed with deft care & understanding.One of the technical highlights of the film is its sound design. At times an assault on the senses and deliberately so, it really familiarises us with the feeling of what it's like to lose one's hearing, the invaluable perks of silence, and the harsh reality of cochlear implants. As for the performances, Ahmed brings his character to life from inside out, steals the show with what's undeniably his career-best work, and is brilliantly supported by the rest.Overall, Sound of Metal is a consistently engaging & emotionally gripping drama that rides rather heavily on Riz Ahmed's outstanding acting & complete devotion to his role. The characters, including the protagonist, are far from fully fleshed in the script but the energy & commitment the actors bring to their respective roles nonetheless help steer the story past the finish line. An auditory revelation led by a star-making turn from its rising talent, Sound of Metal is a definite must-see.

reviews.review_title: Bad acting and a drag of a film
reviews.content: I expected a transcendental drama of a relatable character. I a slow, uninspiring film with poor acting which is a shock as I liked Riz Ahmed in majority of his roles. Sadly here he seems like didn't have an idea to give character depth like he did with The Night Of. I guess this could be due to an underworked script or poor direction.

This movie was absolutely haunting to watch and even after the credits rolled it hasn't left me. I watched this days ago and still find myself thinking about it and to me that is a tremendous achievement. Riz Ahmed is fantastic here as a metal drummer who suddenly loses his hearing and, with it, a large sense of who he is only to be forced to rediscover himself. Ahmed delivers on all of this superbly and does a fantastic job of keeping attention glued to him the whole way through. The sound work is spectacular as well, really driving home the auditory issues at play here.Possibly my favorite thing though is Marder's willingness to linger and let the actors do the work rather than expositing all over us. The ending is a perfect example of the negative space in a conversation really informing everything. He achieves so much without saying anything which is so perfectly befitting a film of this nature. Going in and finding out they actually utilized people who are actually deaf makes me love it all the more and gives the film an even greater sense of agency.Strong recommend for everyone, especially those looking for a stunningly acted drama about redefining the sense of self. Don't expect huge action or flashy set pieces but if you come in just looking for a moving drama then this right here is perfect. Absolute recommend.

reviews.review_title: made me think because myself do work on stage a lot
reviews.content:
Amazon original made with a Belgian crew and all about a metal duo band. Sounds interesting. And over in Belgium the papers were saying, a must see.So I did without reading what it was all about and what a flick this was.Starts off with a gig were cams are focused on the drummer. Gig done, the drummer notices that something is wrong with his ears. No tinitus but his hearing was fading away. And after a terrible gig he hadto admit something is really going wrong with him. From there we are focused on the drummer and his way to start living with being deaf. Not easy for a musician but the manager sends him to a place for deaf people. From there he had to amke a decision. Living with it or getting medical help.What happens next is out there on prime video to see. And indeed, a must see for musicians and how live could suddenly change in a few minutes.
Gore 0/5
Nudity 0/5
Effects 0/5
Story 4/5
Comedy 0/5

reviews.review_title: Extremely Profound Performance, Slighly Underwhelming Final Product
reviews.content: Riz Ahmed delivered a unbelievably powerful and captivating performanance as a young drummer sobered by the loss of his hearing. Besides that, this film left a lot to be desired; at least in my eyes. It just missed a certain something that underwhelmed me and i don't really see how it's best picture material. Nonetheless watch this film just to see a absolute top tier display in the art of acting.

Not a bad movie, but definitely not a 7.8 as rated here. This is not as good as movies such as the godfather, alien, goodfellas and so on. Therefore all these 9s and 10s are very dishonest.Acting is good not great. There's not much you can do with the story unfortunately.

Awful movie. It had potential, feels as if a good script ended up in the wrong hands. It's very depressing and you don't take anything from watching, it doesn't instigated any thinking or discussion, it doesn't inspire, is just a waste of time.

reviews.review_title: (2020 list excerpt) Very close to my top 10
reviews.content: Sound of Metal is a film that nearly made the cut, falling a bit short in terms of pacing and repetitiveness, and is nevertheless a pretty great movieDespite some of the problems I had, the film is an immersive and uncompromising look into the deaf community, expertly using sound editing and foley to put us in the mind of Riz Ahmed as it loses the ability to register sound. As scary and heartbreaking as it is for Ahmed's character, a drummer with a passion for his craft, he's told that he is wrong to think of his condition as a curse; something to be fixed. I shall leave that can of worms untouched.For now, I'm here to tell you that this is a well-crafted movie that, if nothing else, will give Ahmed a shot at the Best Actor prize if movie awards will still be a thing in 2021.

This is a film for anyone who has had a devastating medical event or diagnosis. If you have had such an experience, there will be many moments in which you identify with the main character. If you have had a fortunate life in which nothing ever has gone wrong with your body, you might find this movie dull. The characters aren't deeply developed and there isn't what most people would call action or suspense. Either you get this movie or you don't, and it will likely depend on your personal experiences.

That movie has nothing to do with metal, or music, or with the genre "music" as stated by imdb.
It is a pointless drama story, that nobody can relate to, about a guy who when faced with a medical problem, instead of seeking medical attention, went to join a community that he didn't know what it was, and did nothing to help him with his problem.
His life in the community is the biggest part of the movie, but somehow had nothing to do with the movie.
Surprisingly, whether it helped him or not in any way, is a total mystery, as the story did not tell us anything about the benefits he acquired from that.
This community was recommended by a friend, like the first thing you do when a friend says he's gone deaf, is recommending a deaf community instead of speaking to some doctors to try to first figure his condition out.
The acting, the picture and the directing is decent, so if you like sad drama movies with no plot, maybe you should give it a go.
But if you are in a mood of watching a movie about a drummer or musicians in general, you should instead try a movie that actually has something to do with music

Having a hearing impaired child, we were intrigued by the movie. However I think the approach lacked development. From the get go, the music lacked quality. It would have been more interesting to hear something that sounded great combined with the dynamic of hearing loss and growing into that environment. However, i left wanting to be deaf at the beginning and the end of the film.As far as character development goes, in many instances, the dialog seemed random or confusing. I did find throwing the viewer into a deaf community daunting and impactful. But the filmography and script felt low budget and other than learning some new signs, I didn't feel attached to any of the characters.By the end of the film, it was interesting to hear a representation of what hearing aids can sound like in a noisy room and it clearly demonstrated a point made earlier about quiet moments...which is why the sudden ending was both artistic and as empty as the silence that preceeded it.I really thought the movie was going to be more about overcoming obstacles and making a difference in ones self and others. It's not. It's more like what happens if you're asked to make a movie about hearing loss and coming to terms with it and instead smoked pot through the whole filming of it.

reviews.review_title: This is a Must See film. Riz Ahmed deserves an Oscar.
reviews.content: Wonderful writing for a top notch cast. This interior film moves at a swift pace so that it never drags. There are no wasted or superfluous scenes. Each scene moves the story along and reveals something new about the character(s). Riz Ahmed was amazing in HBO's "The Night Of". But his portrayal of the flawed Ruben in "The Sound of Metal" is outstanding. He is at different times stubborn, sweet, rude, ambitious, stupid, sexy, lost and confused. But mostly angry understandably. This is a very ambitious film and Ahmed totally met the challenges of portraying Ruben.

reviews.review_title: If there has ever been a movie to watch.
reviews.content: This movie...it's deep. It has heart, it has heart and it has a story. It is beautiful told, shot and heard. 10/10.

reviews.review_title: The Simplest Stories are Often the Best
reviews.content: The Good: I've seen this movie twice. Honestly, the first time, I liked it, but didn't truly get the hype. The second time...my God. This movie hits you with such emotion and humanity. The sound design is obviously incredible. I haven't seen a film that truly captures you not with its visuals, but with its sound. Watching this film, a celebration of deafness in a way, you come out appreciating the beauty of sound itself.Moreover, it works as a tool to truly help us empathize with Ruben, whom is played amazingly by Riz Ahmed. It's telling when a character is truly an asshole most of the story, but you get it, because you probably would be too. Also, shout out to Paul Raci. His performance specifically moved me so much.Not many movies make me cry. This one did. That ending is one of the most beautiful I have seen in years.The Bad: honestly, it should have been longer. Ruben and Lou's world seems so colourful and interesting, I would have loved to spend more time there.The Ugllovehose blonde eyebrows. Come on, Liv.

This is a film of both beauty and purpose. Despite Oscar nominations this is not a disability story of quaint tragedy and saintly patience.The opening is magnificent as the aural world collapses into distorted thuds. And Ahmed's performance is a force to be reckoned with. This is an actor who's deeply connected to his surroundings - those large, inquisitive eyes always darting around in order to take in every detail.Taken in by the deaf community, Ruben is finally given the opportunity to slow down and reexamine his life. Thus Sound of Metal becomes a film about what change means for a person.

"when this crappy, mundane world suddenly becomes radiant and magnificent... all the fear is gone. that plane will never abandon you."Utterly floored by this film. As a ex-drummer myself, this has honestly always been a deep fear of mine. And to see this come to life in such a real way was heartbreaking. I love seeing representation for the deaf community. The sound is top notch and Riz Ahmed delivers an Oscar worthy performance. And the fact that this is a directorial debut adds on to how impressive this film is. Easily one of my favorites of the year.

This is such a beautiful movie. Some moments are so intense, you will fall in love with the characters. I had never really tried to fit in a mind-frame of a person with hearing issues but the movie had so many moments which leaves you disturbed, makes you aware of how difficult thing could be. But, then eventually the way it has portrayed that hearing loss is not a disability for many people but a way of life, is incredible. The love story of Ruben and Lou is really delightful. Riz Ahmed shines in this one.

Two best things about the movie were the sound design and the performances. The design mimicks Ruben's hearing. It makes you feel like the character, to have a sense of what the character is hearing and what its making him feel like. I haven't seen a movie with such concept before. And Riz Ahmed nailed the character. Raw, original, heartbreaking, captivating, sad, yet inspirational and rewarding.

Yes, it was an emotional film, but it was yet another movie completely ruined by "Shaky Cam".I am still amazed that any cameraman or director thinks that this is a good medium, outside of action movies.I felt sea-sick the entire time and couldn't fall into the story.I need to start a movement: DEATH TO SHAKY CAM!

Sound of Metal is perhaps the only film that I've seen in which it's sound design can make or break it. Our main character is a drummer for an extreme metal band that loses his hearing after years of exposure to the piercingly loud music that he creates. Through his POV, we are given the chance to feel what it is like to lose your sense of hearing. The sound design doesn't disappoint. In fact, it's incredible. We hear the muffled treble of his surroundings as his hearing progressively disappears. We hear the warped, radio-like fizzle of his cochlear implant as he readjusts to a world with sound. It's a profound experience. The scenes at the deaf community home is also a masterclass in directing scenes without any dialogue. I haven't seen a film that has explored sign language to this extent and it's refreshing and creative in a whole new way. Completed in 2019, this has become one of the stand-out independent films released digitally in 2020. If you have Amazon Prime, see this now.

reviews.review_title: The best sound-based story in a long time
reviews.content: If this doesn't win the Oscar for "Best Sound", I'll riot. I can't remember the last time I was on the edge of my seat with a movie that encorporates so much of it's narrative around sound.I loved this movie so much. What a great performance by Riz Ahmed - who did great research with the deaf community to nail this movie - and a lesson to everyone of us. Whatever we lose in our life, we can fight and fight until we get it back, but we must also know that things are never going to sound the same and we just have to deal with it.

I love this movie for all sorts of reasons. I am a musician and have lost a good portion of my hearing. I can relate. I hate hearing aids! I have them but use them only when I really need to hear. Other than that I embrace my deafness. I am also sober 27 years. It's about acceptance.

I was pretty hyped for the drumming, but sadly the dumming takes a backstage throughout the film. What I was left with was a character study on a hardheaded person coming to terms with his loss of hearing, and being part of the deaf community. It's not exactly what I hoped for but it was still a very thoughtfull movie. And overall very well made with great attention to detail.7/10: yepyep.

reviews.review_title: Beautiful Owl eyes add meaning to this story
reviews.content: I really love this film. I'm an ASL interpreter and my partner has lost some hearing. I want to show them this film because I think it captures that experience so beautifully.I remember the first few years of learning ASL and how I adjusted to how quiet the classrooms were. It was thrilling and so calming at the same time. I love that this movie found a way to prioritize conveying that.What made me want to watch this was the line "we're looking for a solution to this (pointing at 'third eye'/mind) not this (pointing at ear)." YES.There's something liberating about sign language and silence; and also using your eyes and surroundings/ other senses to absorb the world around you. I found that sign language made me pay attention so differently; not to mention it helped me express myself when I found the English language limiting.Riz Ahmed is beautiful in this and I particularly love that someone with such large eyes was cast for this because it's emphasizing his experience even more.Just a perfect movie, I can't say how much I love it.

A recent Amazon Prime release is a great showcase for the already great Riz Ahmed. Here he plays a drummer to his vocalist girlfriend, played by the equally talented Olivia Cooke, who after one show he discovers he has sustained permanent hearing loss. Panicking, he books an appointment at a doctor's office to give him his options (the one he responds to is a cochlear implant but the price for the operation runs anywhere from 20K to 80K & his insurance doesn't cover it, sound familiar America?). A recovering drug addict who is reaching the limits of his sobriety (he's been clean for 4 years), Cooke reaches out to his sponsor who diverts them to a secluded farm estate where a bunch of recovering addicts (who also are hearing impaired) reside led by a tough yet kindly caretaker, played by Paul Raci (in a marvelous turn). Ahmed now has to relearn things most of us take for granted since he can still speak but his command of sign language is non-existent prompting him to enroll in a class made up of young kids w/him (all tat'd up & sporting a bottle blonde top) being the obvious odd man out. Cooke leaves him behind fearing they'll both get into bad habits making Ahmed's progress slow but sure. Once reemerging as a functioning member of society he never quite embraces the 'stillness' which Raci implores him do & instead sells off all his worldly possessions (his RV & all of his sound equipment) in order to go ahead w/the surgery. When he reunites w/Cooke in Paris (she's spending time w/her estranged father, played by Mathieu Amalric, also a musician), Ahmed must come to grips w/where his life is now finally finding the peace he's hoping to get. Wonderfully nuanced (mimicking his hearing loss we get passages where nothing is heard on the soundtrack) w/Ahmed the eye of the hurricane as it were, the film lives or dies on his shoulders & he carries it like a champ w/vivid support from what I presume are a bunch of hearing impaired, non-actors (I did see Lauren Ridloff from the Walking Dead playing a teacher at Ahmed's school) giving the entire affair a degree of legitimacy.

With excellent performances, that addresses some very important issues with great sympathy.Having achieved audience empathy with the leads, I think this is one that was left nicely poised and invites a sequel, as Lou continues to move on with her life and Ruben goes back to the community and embraces the role of helper. But they still love one another and keep in touch. And maybe Lou faces a crisis - possibly deriving from her mother's relationship with her father and suicide - and Ruben goes to help her... take it where you will from there!

This movie has so much to teach: about adversity, addiction, relationships, the lies we tell ourselves, things we say, and the things we don't say.The plot is stripped bare and tears right to the marrow of anger. Riz Ahmed has never been better in this raw performance. I felt every sinew.Olivia Cook seems transformed, almost unrecognizable in an impressive and authentic turn. We feel the history between them, and yet there's is a distance as well. Poignantly executed.

reviews.review_title: Rare and powerful film. I'm still thinking about it.
reviews.content: It's a rare movie that so moves me and has me ruminating about it for days afterwards.This profound film tells the story of Ruben, a heavy metal drummer, who is losing his hearing. Riz Ahmed in the starring role brings an uncanny gift of being able to communicate emotion through his expressive eyes. He's a tremendous actor. The script is sparse at times, the sound editors utilize noise, silence, and tinny tones to convey a semblance of Ruben's life changing experience. Due to an event in my life, this film rocked me to my core in this portrait that explores the awareness that we are ultimately totally alone and have to bring our own perspective and meaning to our life.

The life of Ruben, a heavy metal drummer, enters a whirlwind of emotions, as soon as he starts to lose his hearing.A frantic drama, with a very punctuated human tone, that can transcend the main element (music), and grab anyone.When talking about the importance of the score and sound design for a film to work, there should be no better examples than this one, in recent years.Throughout the narrative, and as we get more and more immersed in the life drama of Ruben, and his girlfriend, Lou, our capacity for understanding and empathy changes.Our emotions start to be part of the story, in a natural and genuine way.Riz Ahmed has the best role of his career, and Olivia Cooke shows a clear maturity and growth, which makes her much more complete, as an actress.

I rarely rate movies as a nine. This movie was really special. The filming, acting, dialogue was all above par but the way it revealed the complexity of the characters situation way heavy. You get a feel for what it would be like in the characters situation and all that go's with it.

reviews.review_title: Copy of It's All Gone Pete Tong
reviews.content: Good movie, but is a pure copy of the Pete Tong movie.

A perfectly ordinary film with sinusoidal performance, sometimes effective and sometimes downhill, does not produce much drama in the film, the film could better portray the problems of the deaf community in everyday interactions and take a deeper look at this issue.
Some mezzanines had problems, but in the case of Riz Ahmed, I don't think he could handle the role.

I was expecting this to be a film about how the lead character gradually and terribly loses his hearing. But that's really just the beginning of his journey. The story is more and better than I expected. Riz Ahmed is great in the lead role. And the film's use of sound, or sometime it's absence, to take us into Riz's world was excellent.

Darius Marder's Academy Award-winning "Sound of Metal" focuses on a heavy metal drummer (Riz Ahmed) whose life takes another turn when he starts to develop hearing loss, forcing him to move in with the deaf community. Overall, the movie is about how he has to relearn to navigate everything. The entire cast turns in some fine performances.This movie got nominated a year before "CODA", also focusing on deafness and music. Both are outstanding movies. A noticeable difference is that "Sound of Metal" has no soundtrack so as to keep the focus strictly on the characters. This made it one of the most effective movies that I've seen in focusing on disabilities. All in all, I hope that in the future, more movies focus on disabilities.

Ok... The movie as a whole if youre exploring the world of becoming deaf... amazing. As a music lover though this was a disappointment. After the first twenty minutes it turns into this search for being. I gave this six stars as a result and I love that Derek Cianfrance who did my favorite movie of the last ten years Place Beyond the Pines helped produce this.

reviews.review_title: This movie nails the experience of going deaf.
reviews.content:
How many times does a movie hit so close to home that your life seems to be literally displayed in front of your eyes. Not many.My Story (Review Below)
I lost my hearing in my right ear in my early 30's. Some weird thing they can't cure called Meniere's Disease. 20 years later and three months ago, my good ear started crapping out and I was told I have bi-lateral Meniere's. Not good.I wasn't a drummer (practiced to be one though). I went to metal/rock shows before COVID, and I wear ear plugs now when I go. I can't personally speak to what it's like to be in the music business, but I can speak to what it's like to go deaf all of a sudden.Just as in the movie, I wake up and hear a loud humming with everything else a dull murmur. Even my own voice.I was told hearing aids could help -- I was lucky that I had a family benefactor who offered to pay for the best of the best as they are not covered by insurance.And they helped -- a little, but for the price they barely did squat. Sounds were shrilly like you had an AM radio with a bad speaker in your ear. I need to put subtitles on all movies I watch these days.But having trauma in your life reminds you of the importance of connections. Friends and family that support you, or people you barely even know -- like my Letterboxd friends in the comments section. What a great community we have here.Sound of Metal Review
I went in without reading the byline, expecting an expose on life in the hard rock music business. Instead it's a tragic situation of the young drummer of a metal band, played fantastically by Riz Ahmed, who goes deaf.The acting is fantastic. Riz Ahmed is great as usual but reaches a new level . His girlfriend Olivia Cooke is unrecognizable with the bleached eyebrows, moving refreshingly from trash horror movies to a fantastic dramatic effort.There's more to say but I need to digest this more and possibly do a rewatch.Amazing.

It was rather good that I find this a difficult story, a drummer loses his hearing, and finds an unusual school of deaf addicts. Riz Ahmed is an exceptional actor with Nightcrawler (2014) and Four Lions (2010) and his girl, splendid as the singer with him in the story is also very good, Olivia Cooke in the, Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015). The film was rather sad and we wonder how well it could work out in the end. The fantastic caravan nothing like a little car and looks more like a silver, diner camper van.

Riz Ahmed is outstanding as a drummer who survives playing in a heavy metal duo with his partner, wandering through the US in a camper vehicle. He suddenly loses his hearing and has to deal with the profound consequences of that to himself and his life. There are few dramatic films dealing with deafness, let alone a sudden affliction, so on that point alone this is a refreshing change, and the film genuinely does try to immerse the audience into the disturbing soundless world he enters and his struggles to deal with it; here the film should be lauded for superb sound design and equally impressive editing. It's a vividly told story and an informative journey, especially if like me your knowledge of the deaf experience is limited. Although I couldn't in the end quite warm to the main character, perhaps that's a strength of the film - thus avoiding sentimentality. Highly recommended.

A heavy metal drummer experiences sudden hearing loss, forcing him to stop touring with his girlfriend and enter a shelter for the deaf, which provides assistance for recovering addicts and a school for children. It's a premise that in so many ways could have led to a film going the usual sorts of Hollywood routes, but the storytelling from director Darius Marder is nuanced, and the pace he sets is fantastic. We feel this character's emotions as he tries to process this dramatic change in his life, but we're never hit over the head with expository speeches or grand scenes that resolve things in black and white ways, which was something I really liked about the film.That subtlety is perfectly matched by the performance Riz Ahmed gives, which is one of the best I've seen in a long time. Some of his finest acting is in little moments, just as some of the best scenes are filled with silence. Olivia Cooke and Paul Raci are very strong as well, and the scenes they have with Ahmed in the second half of the film are quite powerful. There is so much genuine feeling being expressed, with love and empathy being counterbalanced by the realization that life changes, and that it's hard to recapture the past or to be truly content in the stillness of the present. Throughout it all, the superb sound design helps immerse us into the experience. Just a very well done film in every respect, including its ending, and one I might have given an even higher rating.

Ruben is an amazing character and was perfectly played by Riz Ahmed.
I really could emphatize with him and with what he went through.

I am basically very similar to the people this movie is focusing on and it's just too poor of an attempt to emulate reality. I was immediately taken out of the beginning scene because of the fake performance and terrible fake music. Then the fake bs convos the two main characters had. I just had to turn it off. If you want to watch a better similar movie then watch green room. Obviously a different type of movie overall but at least they get the type of people right, sheesh. This movie is wayyyyy too overrated. Wish I could've got past the facade.And actually after scrolling through some other reviews was reminded of the movie it's all gone Pete tong which I saw years ago and is GREAT. This movie is definitely a rip off of that movie. Guess I'll watch that again instead.

reviews.review_title: Mostly frustrating, but worth checking out
reviews.content: Mostly frustrating, but worth checking out. Kind of cliche portrayal of junkie metal musicians, which was used for all of the drama. It made me want to learn sign language though! Loved the parts at the recovery/learning home. I wonder if the duo was based of the band Jucifer?? Pretty cool sound design elements, but otherwise had the feel of a generic modern straight-to-streaming production.

reviews.review_title: Sound of Metal is a stressful, yet hopeful cinematic journey
reviews.content: Much like the drummer in a band, Riz Ahmed is the backbone of Sound of Metal. His performance in this movie is what makes it so relatable and realistic. This film also uses creative sound editing to give the viewer a sense of what it's like to be hearing impaired. Sound of Metal is a stressful, yet hopeful cinematic journey created by a talented cast, a capable director, and a convincing script.
It's not an original idea.But this was a different movie than I expected.Acting was great. The sound design was very good.
Wow. Riz was brilliant as always. His performance stunned me.

I was captured by the intro and the first 20 mins. The sound design originally captured me and like many of the other negative reviews it became very dull. I have 20 mins left but I don't even think the ending can save it, it's probably going to be depressing. I think I've seen far too many movies in my lifetime and not many inspire me any more, but there still a handful left.... Hopefully, but not this one. Oscar worthy movie or performance.....Nope.

reviews.review_title: Exceptional sound design with a powerful performance by Riz Ahmed
reviews.content: This was a film I was very interested in. The concept alone sounded intriguing and having two talented actors like Riz Ahmed and Olivia Cooke as part of the cast got me excited.Sound of Metal follows Ruben, a heavy metal drummer whose life changes forever after the loss of his hearing.I thought this film was absolutely fantastic. In his directorial debut, Darius Marder constructs such a beautiful yet harrowing drama. This is a film that really made me feel something. Seeing Ruben's battle and struggle towards his hear loss made me realise just how important our senses are to us and losing any one of them can impact our life to a great extent. The sound plays an integral part in the film and is easily one of the strongest factors. From the loud heavy metal music at the beginning to the muffled vibrations and speech, the sound design perfectly puts us into the shoes of Ruben and helps us get a full understanding of what it's like being deaf. If this film doesn't win Best Sound Editing and Mixing then I don't know what will. The pacing may be slow for some but I was consistently enthralled by what I was watching. It was interesting and even educational to see how the deaf community, which I believe were portrayed well, live their lives without being able to hear.This is the best I've seen Riz Ahmed act. I could feel his pain during his heated moments and even during the silent scenes, where the camera would just focus on his face, the expressions he would give communicated so much about the way his character was feeling. He carries the entire film as he's practically in every scene and I hope he wins some awards for his work here. In collaboration with the amazing sound design, this is the most empathetic I've felt towards a character in a long time. Darius and Abraham Marder leave small hints about Ruben's past which allowed me to align with him further. Olivia Cooke isn't in the film as much I thought but she did a great job playing Lou and there was enough context given for me to understand what her character was like. Paul Raci was remarkable as Joe. He's an actor that I would definitely like to see more often.I really loved Sound of Metal. It's a expertly crafted film with so much heart, care and emotion put into it that ends in a way that spoke levels to me. Riz Ahmed proves once again how talented of an actor he is and I'm looking forward to what Darius Marder makes next.
It's a nice film , unique and interesting.. may not watch it again though

This film is strongly directed with a gripping story. Featuring strong visuals and innovative sound design, the viewers is pulled into the heartbreaking story of a young musician who loses his hearing and who has to come to terms with who he is. Riz Ahmed plays this role with raw emotion and it is hard not to be on the edge of your seat thinking about where his life and decisions will take him. I look forward to future feature films from first time director, Darius Marder. This is a poignant film that is worth the watch.

This is the most beautiful film I've seen in my life.
Sound of metal is about much more than just a drummer who goes deaf. Its a film about both losing and discovering what makes life meaningful. It never gets preachy or tries to convey any kind of moral, it only tells a story. Yet, it has more meaning than many movies who try and fail to do what it does.This is a personal 10/10, and an objective 9/10.
I would say "go watch this now", but I think it is better if you give this movie time to set in after you watch it, so I would tell you to find a time when you can watch it, and think about it after.
I found the music to be so unpleasant and offensive that I envied that the protagonist was going deaf.

reviews.review_title: This is How My Ears Felt Coming Out of Tenet
reviews.content: In university, I actually wrote an essay on hearing loss and cochlear implants, and from my (not) expert opinion, they did a fantastic job portraying hearing loss. Hearing is such a fragile thing, and once it's gone, it's gone forever, so seeing the character of Ruben come to terms with that was incredible.As for Riz Ahmed's performance, it was nothing short of extraordinary. You feel his initial anger and confusion, and as his character grows, you find comfort and peace in his silence. It's an emotional rollercoaster as his journey teaches us more about the deaf community and how to live without hearing.The supporting cast all do a great job, especially Paul Raci as Joe. But the subplot with Ruben's girlfriend, Lou, did nothing for me. Their relationship was touching, and they have their moments, but I just didn't care for their love story/the tour subplot. I just thought that Ruben's personal journey of learning to live without hearing was more interesting when he was figuring it out on his own.I was actually blown away by the sound design, which is not something you usually hear in movies. (Pun intended.) Since hearing is such an important part of the film, they use it in so many creative ways. There are even long sections without any words ever being spoken, which made for a more immersive viewing experience.On the other hand, the movie can run a little long at 2 hours. They could have probably shaved off like 20 minutes, mostly to do with the girlfriend/tour subplot. But with such an immersive sound design and an excellent performance from Riz Ahmed, this would have definitely made my Top 10 Movies of 2020 list.

Wish I watched this in the cinemas! Such a beautiful and powerful story that any person can relate to! Riz is amazing and it is definitely a stand out for 2020! Sometimes it's good to just sit in the silence. A must watch!

I hope at least it wins an Oscar! Riz Ahmed was so suitable and nice actor in the movie. When you think what happens to main character , it really sucks but every human adapts so fast to every situation. This movie is about that and also about lots of alternatives for us. Highly recommend to watching.
Amazing movie, I really like it, the movie catch you from the begining the end.The movie is too much kindly and human, if you can see it please do it, different and great.

Riz Ahmed is Ruben a heavy metal drummer who is going deaf and along with his girlfriend and singer, travel to a school for the deaf run by Paul Raci. He learns sign language but wishes to have surgery o recover some of his hearing. The music is not to my taste but Ahmed owns the film and it is one of the ten best for 2020.
This movie is excellent. Great acting, good character development, direction etc. I think anyone can get a good message they need from this movie if you listen closely.

reviews.review_title: Maybe the best film of the year-a striking experiential work
reviews.content: While the film simplifies and streamlines some aspects of cochlear implants and hearing loss I am greatly pleased with the films commitment to lived experience of the Deaf community. It is deeply gratifying to see a mainstream film that doesn't take it for granted that deafness is a disability and that cochlear implants are a "cure." On every single aspect of production this film is committed to messy reality. Even Joe's harsh reaction to the implants-plausible but not common-is entirely within the realm of how people actually behave. With that said I think the movie is about addiction not deafness.Ruben's arch is learning how to sit still; that is learn to accept the hardships life throws at you without engaging in self-destructive behavior. It is a hugely important aspect of this script that the implants are not treated as a good-you can argue that Ruben harmed himself with them. I think eventually he learns this lesson but it is really touch and go there for awhile. The film has a great unresolved-that is not everything has a bow on it-quality that adds to the messy reality the film is going for. As such this is an emotive powerful work.This complexity is supported by all the formal elements of filmmaking. The script is efficient piece of storytelling. The direction is assured without being obtrusive. And above all the sound design of the film places the viewer in the headspace of person with hearing loss and cochlear implants. It is deeply effective and effecting.Much credit must be given to Ahmed. He turns in a performance that is completely real-he is electric and subtle. He carries the big moments and the quiet ones. He is completely vulnerable and open. The film is carried by Ahmed and sound; Ahmed does his job perfectly.But speaking of acting Raci is sneakily good. He has maybe 20 minutes of screen time but he is so real and strong that you totally get the where the character is coming from. Like much of the film he is just alive.This could have been a dull Important Subject Movie. Instead it is a living piece of cinema that allows everyone to step into Ruben's shoes.

I don't get the high rating this movie got here. I couldn't even sit all the way through, after one hour I turned it off and went to sleep. It's one of the slowest films I've seen lately, nothing keeps happening for minutes and minutes. The characters are not remarkably likeble or relatable, they're rather dull and not interesting. All in all, this film is just a pain in the butt.
Ahmed once won a historical Emmy for The Night Of. Now, I am betting he's gonna win an Oscar. One tip: watch this with headphones on and your hearts out.

It is a good story, well told, directed and acted. It could have been a great story only the third act was predictable and the ending obvious. My attention drifted since I'd already seen the end in my mind.

reviews.review_title: Narrative problems aside- Riz Ahmed makes this film worth watching
reviews.content: I praise the performances throughout this film, there is no denying Riz Ahmed's and Olivia Cookes talent- let alone their chemistry. However, Darius Marder's script makes a simple case out of an extraordinary story, seemingly belittling the complex and unique vision it has the potential to be- with a simple, formulaic narrative that we have seen many times before. I enjoyed this film, it wasn't the most entertaining film i've seen, but it did have very interesting moments throughout. It's a dark, sometimes brutal feeling film, and its raw emotion is often encaptured and amplified by these performers on screen. Ahmed is obviously the standout, as well as Cooke, but Paul Raci and Lauren Ridloff also deserve some attention for their work as well. The film feels a bit bland to look at, an attempt at a grounded setting maybe, but it just feels to dull and gray, and therefore depressing to watch, when it could have simply been hard. I enjoy many things about the film, the way it focuses on sound to tell its story of our lead character is very unique, but the story it tells is unfortunately just average. Not bad, but average, and the pacing from Marder's script doesn't make it much better. In the end, Sound of Metal is far from a missed opportunity, and it has many excellent and unique qualities, as did Marder's other film The Place Beyond the Pines. However, it's just not daring enough to be something truly worthwhile, and although there are many strengths, that disappointment still leaves with you by its end.My Rating: 7/10.

The nightmare of any musician, particularly a drummer, keeper of beat, keeper of time, is hearing loss. That is Ruben's dilemma.
