After a boisterous, mid-tour set, one half of a power duo starts to experience aural malfunction. Uh-oh.In typical human nature denial, Ruben carries on, but is soon forced to make tough decisions. Scrambling desperately to get back on course, and continue his career, Ruben is eager to gamble on an expensive operation, while his vocalist girlfriend steers him to a recovery community, focusing on adaptation over cure.Reuben's journey, careening between hope, desperation, struggle and revelation, is a fascinating one, amplified by the extraordinary presentation from director Darius Marder. Putting the audience in Reuben's ears, the loss experience through muffled passages, jarring distortions, and worst of all, total silence, is devastating. The eclectic sound design may be the star here. Closed captioned throughout so nothing is missed, the sub-titles, usually a distraction, become a fluid part of the viewing experience.As a simple, uncomplicated young man jolted by a life altering shock, Riz Ahmed is terrific in a subtle yet demanding role. He absolutely rocks as a kickass drummer, a reluctant deaf student, and an empathetic partner willing to go any distance to make things right. The buzz about this film is not just in Ruben's ears.hipCRANK

reviews.review_title: Sort of a guide for the people who are in desperate need of guidance
reviews.content: Let me just say this right off the bat, Riz Ahmed is a revelation here. For someone who isn't a deaf person in the real world, he accomplished an incredible feat, did an amazing job in the illustration of the same. So did Olivia Cooke; people might have not been much appreciative of her performance here, but one must agree that despite her lesser screentime, as compared to our main lead I.e. Ruben, she does make a solid impact.At the end of the day, it's all about Acceptance. The true realisation of the actuality, irrespective of the harshness and gravitas of the same. Now the people who have been rather harsh on the film, need to understand that this is not here to satisfy your needs for 'Entertainment', nor has it been made to give the audience the traditional vibes of a musical drama; it is rather structured like a lesson, sort of a compass to all those people who feel lost and going through comparable phases.If you speak strictly from a cinematic stance, several flaws can be brought up, not regarding any of the technicalities though, as those have been pretty impressive and probably the strongest suits apart from the enactments. Nevertheless, if you ask me, that's not how your approach should be this time. You shall go in with an open mind (and lots of patience) to truly comprehend the significance underneath.I'm no musician and I'm not somebody whose livelihood depends upon the ability to hear. Regardless, the lone thought of losing my hearing terrifies me to the core. Lately, I have experienced Mild Tinnitus (due to ETD). For those couple of days, I felt nothing but hopeless, the persistent buzzing inside my head, all the discomfort in my ears made me angry, I was worried sick. Through a handful of medications and some exercises (Yoga), I'm now in a much better shape, almost healed, but I'm still very much in fear of getting the ringing once again.I couldn't possibly imagine what goes through those people who underwent permanent hearing losses, or those who are currently on the way to losing theirs. It's awful, it's tragic, yet the harsh reality is we have to make peace with our condition and must move on. Cause, Life stops for nobody, it goes on and we have to make our adjustments accordingly, that's what this story aims to teach. At first, it would be tough to cope with your situation knowing that your life would never be the same, but you have to fight no matter what life throws at you. These are the lessons, this specific narrative cares to dissipate.

I made it about 40 minutes into the movie and was bored out of my mind. I did not hear any metal music at all. I don't care about other peoples struggles. I love Olivia Cooke but the deaf dude wouldn't stop making everything about him.

reviews.review_title: A hard-hitting, sensitive portrayal that benefits from excellent sound design work! [+81%]
reviews.content: I can't believe I missed watching this gem of a film. Riz Ahmed's terrific performance as a drummer who suddenly goes deaf is uplifted by the screenplay (by Darius Marder andAbraham Marder) that immediately draws you in, and a fantastically immersive sound design which makes you experience what the protagonist is going through. The tender chemistry he shares with his girlfriend Lou (Olivia Cooke) is beautiful. The screenplay incorporates several scenes that leave a silent-yet-poignant mark on viewers, and director Darius Marder saves the best scene for the very end. It's so subtly impactful - and it doesn't need a single line of dialogue. We travel with Ruben on his journey from becoming deaf to trying to avert that with implants, learning to live with his disability, and the realizations that eventually follow. The edit work (Mikkel E. G. Nielsen), detailing the sounds that constantly take us in and out of Ruben's head, is tremendous.Perhaps, the struggle-filled journey (with occasional, momentary joys) lasts a lot longer than a few months, as is showcased in the film. But the entire crew treat the subject of disability with much-needed sensitivity, portraying the members of the shelter as never seeking an ounce of sympathy. Also, I wish music had a larger role to play role here, especially since the very thing that Ruben is good at, is taken away from him probably during the peak of his career. If you're looking for a single good takeaway from the film aside from its performances and technicalities, it's how there's inexplicable beauty in silence. Sound of Metal deserves all the praise (and the Academy Awards) it has gotten!

A lot of filmmaker try to be deep about disability, few actually can. This film really goes deep into the theme,as well as the fact of growing apart from a loved one, when you life changes; it does so without fireworks, huge fights or tears. Every steps of the characters acceptance are shown with perfect pacing and smooth transitions. The characters are beautifully humans and realistic.Truly a beautiful story filled with love, grief and transformation.

reviews.review_title: Worthwhile movie about losing something that is important to you
reviews.content: I was quite impressed with how Sound of Metal tried to put us through the experience of going deaf with the main character. My biggest complaint was the fact that his onset of symptoms was so sudden. This felt like something that would be more gradual in real life, but either they compressed time significantly or he just went deaf almost instantaneously. Despite that minor issue, I felt like I was in his shoes throughout the film, and understood exactly why he was getting so frustrated. The performances were all great, in particular Riz Ahmed did a marvelous job with all the emotional stuff he went through. I think what impressed me most was how this movie didn't go in certain obvious directions that I expected. There were some frustrating tropes that I anticipated, and the movie didn't fall into any of those cliches. I think the most interesting aspect of the film was the sound design, because the sound technicians did a great job of simulating the way the main character would hear things. It was so well done that it felt was jarring whenever they switched to normal audio. The conclusion itself was done perfectly, and I was overall satisfied with the film. I can't say that Sound of Metal was all that groundbreaking or legendary, but it was a solid movie that I'd gladly watch again.

reviews.review_title: Deafness is a lot more complex that losing your hearing
reviews.content: When directors make movies about disabilities, they often tend to pull on the emotional strings of the audience by turning the film into a melodrama. Sound of Metal is different. It is not a sobby story about a deaf person but a character study which tackles the aspects of life that people don't often think about when it comes to deafness such as heartbreak, denial and the ultimate acceptance.While it is a challenge to make the audience truly resonate with an experience of being deaf, Darius Marder manages to masterfully accomplish just that. Through a skillful manipulation of sound, the viewer can slip in and out of the deaf state to experience the maddening sensation of losing the ability to hear and the emotions that come with it.In order be an impactful film, the technical aspect must be supplemented with poignantly realistic acting and Riz Ahmed aces his role. Being a young musician, the ability to hear is what defines his life and the devastation which he goes through can be felt in every scene. He is scared, angry and confused all the same time as he struggles to accept his new reality.The three arcs of the film are perfectly fleshed out as each one has a distinctive theme, message and atmosphere that stirs up different thoughts and feelings. While tragic in nature, the movie has it's share of sweet moments which show that deafness is not the end of life. Personally, I kept thinking whether I would have managed to accept losing my hearing and learn how to live in my new world. It's not often that a movie pushes me to think about such life-altering decisions and if that is not a sign of a great film, I don't know what is.movies.shmovies on Instagram

Started off slightly boring and it almost lost me.. but the sound direction was so intriguing and brought me back in. The acting is great overall, especially from Riz, which wasn't a surprise. This film is inspiring, revealing, and heartbreaking. I hope Darius Marder brings us more great films in the future.
Sound of Metal is a truly original film that gives me more anxiety than any thriller. The film taps into anxiety and fear in a scary, real way. Amazing.

Wow, the lead actor Riz was great... It all begins with life in the rock band, a non famous indie rock band. Life on the road, writing songs, travelling in the RV from show to show, trying to get an album together. Then life throws the main character a curve ball, as we already know going in, he starts to loose his hearing, as a drummer this is not good. The quest then is... What to do about it...? That's where my review stops, and the film shines... Gotta see this one...

reviews.review_title: Well acted drama builds to a satisfying conclusion
reviews.content: There are few things that are more debilitating for a musician than losing one's hearing. Here, a hard rock drummer, Ruben (Riz Ahmed) is a member of a two-piece band with his guitarist/singer girlfriend Lou (Olivia Cooke). He wakes up one morning practically deaf. Ruben reacts like most immature impulsive head-bangers would - he freaks out. Lou can barely contain her boyfriend's anger long enough to tell him she's found a facility that can help him cope. The community for the deaf is run by Joe (Paul Raci) who's plain-spoken, kind, but firm. When Ruben enters he's still a bucking bronco who just wants to "fix" his problem and get back to his music and Lou.Director Darius Marder and his brother Abraham's script essentially follows the pattern of an ailment/rehab film (shot on 35mm!), even with such an unusual character at it's front. It's to their credit - and the actors' - that it becomes so affecting. Ahmed's performance builds as the movie progresses -- just like his character. Cooke is solid and saves some of her best for later in the film, as well. But, it's veteran actor Raci who becomes the heart and soul of the piece. Raci's own parents were deaf and he brings a delicacy and intuition to the role that goes far beyond what was on the page. He exhibits tough love, but with genuine feeling. The always welcome Mathieu Amalric is a nice presence as Lou's Belgian father.The on celluloid lensing by Daniel Bouquet captures the Boston settings well and the music is appropriate even when it's abrasive. The sound work is technically adroit without calling too much attention to itself (which is pretty difficult under the circumstances). The design weaves the viewer in and out of Ruben's head and gives a sense of what the character is going through. Marder is also judicious in how he uses subtitles for the signing only once Ruben himself could understand them. Subtle, but spot on.SOUND OF METAL takes a bit of time to elevate itself from the standard structure it follows, and there are times where the story doesn't quite flow in quite the way the writers obviously intended, but these are fairly minor quibbles. Just the fact that the film doesn't treat deafness as a 'handicap' is worthy enough of attention, but the acting and technical skill on hand make it something much more. Like Ruben's character, the film grows.

Rudy is the drummer in the worst band on the planet, sounding like a bad Yoko Ono covers band, consisting of drums and a girl guitarist vocalist who shouts and can't play. (I heard in an interview that Riz Ahmed had 7 months of drum lessons prior to filming. I've looked through Buddy Rich's 'Snare Drum Rudiments' and Ted Reed's 'Progressive Steps to Syncopation' but I must have missed the chapter on beating hell out of the cymbals for a whole gig.)Anyway, Rudy goes deaf for no apparent reason. He wears ear defenders and has no obvious signs of any illness, he doesn't go for tests and doesn't seek advice, though I'll suspend disbelief and give the writers some artistic licence.He books a test with an audiologist, who, rather than playing varying frequencies and amplitudes of sine waves at very precise levels, says a series of words and asks him to repeat them. From this he arrives at the conclusion that he's lost 72% of his hearing in one ear and 80% in the other. He tells the Rudy that the most important thing is to protect what's left of his hearing. Cut to the next gig where Rudy has taken his ear defenders out and is beating hell out of his kit again. He walks off stage in a huff, followed by his girlfriend guitarist who he lives with in an RV, but hasn't sussed that he's gone deaf.He books an appointment with another specialist who tells him about cochlear implants, which cost $40-80k, but it's ok, they'll just get it done and worry about the cost later.His girlfriend takes him to a hippy commune run by a deaf Vietnam veteran who will teach him how to be Deaf.There were lots of conversations using sign language, but not really ASL, more like sign supported English. (ASL has different syntax and word order.) Most of the conversations were head shots so the sign language largely became irrelevant anyway.He starts hanging out with the kids at the Deaf school, and this unknown, former heroin addict is entrusted with taking a young boy out of class when he becomes unruly. Soon he's rolling around on the floor with the entire class. I think I'd need to look at the school's safeguarding policy.He smokes a cigarette and his girlfriend leaves him because she's scared he'll go back to taking smack again.He sells all the band's equipment (without speaking to his partner) to get two cochlear implants. No pre-op counselling or advice. He's disappointed with the level and quality of hearing the CIs have given him.The Deaf commune kick him out after he asks for money to buy his RV back and they're offended that he wants to rejoin the hearing world.Somehow, after spending all his money he manages to get a flight to France where his GF has gone back to living with her millionaire socialite dad. He tries to convince her to go back to the USA and start the Yoko band again.She says no. He takes the implants off and is happy.The End.Woeful acting throughout and a script that feels as though they made it up as they went along.Nominated for six Academy Awards.

Ok. So the protagonist, who is a musician, goes to a medical consultation where they inform him that he has lost almost 80% of his hearing and that he may lose it all if exposed to noise. The first thing he does? Go play drums.It's so unreal that it took me completely out of the movie. Because, let's see. Option 1: the protagonist is so dumb that he prefers to risk losing all his hearing for a concert, in which case his story arc is no longer interesting.Or two, the screenwriter forced the scene to generate drama, which is much worse. Couldn't care less with everything that happened afterwards since it's grounded on a stupid and illogical narrative decision.

reviews.review_title: Riz Ahmed's performance alone is worth to watch Sound of Metal, it's an incredible film
reviews.content: Ruben (Riz Ahmed) is a drummer and one half of the metal duo Blackgammon, along with the singer/girlfriend, Lou (Olivia Cooke). They live in an RV while driving across the United States to perform gigs. When Ruben begins to suddenly lose his hearing...... Sound of Metal is truly a brilliant film that touched on some much needed themes, the original screenplay mixed with the direction of Darius Marder who also co-wrote the film, its fantastic and deserving its award nomination. It's also nominated for the Best Picture academy award. Riz Ahmed's performance is absolutely one of the best of 2020's acting performances. The film is also nominated for six oscars, and the critics aren't fooling around with this one, it's fascinating from start to finish.Lauren Ridloff plays Diane, a teacher who teaches Ruben American Sign Language. I know her from The Walking Dead and she's great in that show, she'll also be in Marvel's The Eternals. She's deaf and does a good job with representing awareness for the ones with inability to hearing. But the actors that deserve most praise is Riz Ahmed and Paul Raci, Olivia Cooke too.Sound of Metal is a film that both the critics and audience have agreed to be a phenomenal movie, it doesn't try to entertain you. But instead telling a compelling, realistic and much needed story of someone losing their hearing.

I enjoyed the concept and half longed for a bit more of a gritty approach. I felt his struggle jumped too quick to the deaf centre and not enough time spent exploring the conflict around loosing his hearing whilst trying to gig, record etc...
It was a strong debut and I look forward to seeing what comes next.

reviews.review_title: A powerful and poignant story of loss and sacrifice
reviews.content:
I like how director Darius Marder helps us identify with Rubin (Riz Ahmed) by providing us the sounds he hears as his hearing deteriorates. We feel Rubin's torment, anguish, and anger as he gradually loses his ability to play the drums he loves and feels losing the girl he adores. We feel the uncertainty as he sees his world crumble. Rubin sells his prized Airstreamer RV and expensive music equipment to pay for the surgery that might save his world, but in this process feels the memories he had with Lou (Olivia Cooke) inside that RV slipping away from him. First his girl, then the memories he shared with her slip away for a risky surgery that may or may not return him back to his music and to Lou.The scene when Rubin shows up in Belgium where Lou's father lives. The dialog between Rubin and Lou's father. The sincerity of that scene about a father who loves his daughter and the man he once felt was taking her away from him as her mother once did. The dialog is minimalistic with few words, but yet so very powerful and tense. Two men speak and listen to each other frankly as they speak of the woman they both love. Lou's father expresses his appreciation to Rubin for all that he's done for her.But the real tear-jerker moment for me is when Rubin and Lou are both on the bed. Post-Surgery Rubin talks to Lou about his excitement to return with her on the album tour. The following conversation takes place. It shows how deeply Rubin loves Lou that he is willing to unselfishly let her go because he does not want to be the cause of further hurt in her life. That is true love. He loved her so that he was willing with great anguish to let her go and let her find her own happiness.Rubin: "Yeah, the f_*kin' tour, everything."
Lou: "Yeah."
Rubin: "Like, we just gotta get back on it, you know, everything."
Lou: "Mm-hmm."
Rubin: "The album, the tour the, the You know?"
Lou: "Yeah."Rubin notices Lou's anxiety increasing and she begins to scratch the inside of her left arms where she had previous scars from scratching herself.Rubin: "Hey. It's okay, Lou."
Lou: "What?"
Rubin: "It's okay."
Lou: "What's okay?"
Rubin: "You saved my life."
Rubin: "You made it; you made it beautiful"
Rubin: "So it's okay."
Lou: "What?"
Lou: "Why are you saying this?"
Lou: "You saved my life, too, Rubi"The next morning Rubin carefully leaves so as not to wake up Lou. Rubin does not want Lou to hurt any longer because of him and the album tour. He releases her and wonders along the canal listening to the sounds of the street. And finally removes the implant and sits watching the world in complete silence.

The Sound of Metal is a painful but ultimately heartening watch. It has a great and inventive use of sound, a brilliant tone and stylish direction. As a result it feels like a very personal and close film.Sound of Metal is at its best in its middle third. It is here that the films emotional core lies, as Ruben integrates with the deaf community and begins to adapt to his deafness. The film is at its most beautiful here, despite the struggles that Ruben continues to face and the pain he experiences. I think it also helps that the cast is at its fullest in this third, with great supporting performances from Paul Raci and Lauren Ridloff.Saying that, one of the things that I really liked about the Sound of Metal was how small the cast was. It was a very minimalist film that was never crowded. This allowed us to really connect to Ruben and feel what he was going through on a personal level. I loved this connection and it was carried through the entirety of the film. He was a complex character, with a past stricken by addiction that we are privy to but that is not fully explored. This required a highly accomplished performance from Riz Ahmed, which we got. He allowed us to instantly connect to him and feel the fear and uncertainty that he felt.Olivia Cooke as his on screen part was great too and the two of them had fantastic chemistry.My only real criticism of the film and the reason I'm not giving it a 9 is that I think it had a slightly weak end. It felt a little rushed and, despite the very end being a satisfying conclusion, the 20-30 minutes leading up to that felt a tad empty.Overall Sound of Metal boasts an impressive script and story, great style and direction and some fantastic performances. A slightly weak third act doesn't detract from how great this film is.

The Sound of Metal is a very good movie, driven by a stellar performance by Riz Ahmed. It's a movie about a metal drummer who loses his hearing, but it's also about the experiences of the deaf community, learning to deal with the cards you've been dealt, and many other themes. I really enjoyed it and would highly recommend this film.

reviews.review_title: The best use of sound in a film I have ever heard
reviews.content: I went into this film knowing little of it. It's story or meaning. I guarantee you will finish the film having watched and heard a compelling storyline that leaves a lot of paths to think about.It follows the story of Ruben (Riz Ahmed) drummer in a very loud heavy metal band!He lives with fellow band member, his girlfriend Lou (Olivia Cooke) in an RV which they use to travel from gig to gig and record their music in.Now being a drummer means his musical life is all about hearing the beats etc. One day he begins to rapidly lose his hearing.In a panic he visits a specialist who explains that expensive cochlea implants may help restore some of his hearing.An added complication is Ruben's previous lifestyle. He is a recovering heroin addict and the band lifestyle keeps him away from that.As the hearing loss advances Lou persuades Ruben to begin to accept his disability by joining a church funded hearing camp/facility ran by a Vietnam War veteran, Joe (Paul Raci).Ahmed actually learned American Sign Language for the role and Ruben becomes quite proficient in it as he begins to accept his disability amongst a fellow deaf community.Or does he accept it? Deep down he still has a yearning to return to his previous lifestyle and somehow raises the money for the cochlea implants.It is at this point I realised the impact of the sound design on the film as the viewer not only hears Ruben's hearing deteriorating in the first act but how some semblance of hearing is restored by the implants. The impact of crowds and singing on the sound Ruben now hears is also prominent.How would you cope in Ruben's situation? Would you learn to accept your disability and do something about it like Joe's deaf community or forever yearn for past and insurmountable feelings?A great film that perhaps is one of the best of the year. Director and co-writers Darius Marder draws from some of his own family history. Riz Ahmed is totally engrossed in his role.A story that you will think about for days unlike many other films.

reviews.review_title: 'Sound of Metal' is an Oscar-caliber film with a perfect third act
reviews.content: Similarly to other films in my top five here, 'Sound of Metal' deals with a musician struggling with an existential crisis, which triggers his substance abuse addition. I connected immediately with the film's lead, brilliantly portrayed by Riz Ahmed who should be nominated for a best actor in a leading role. Not to give to much away here, but the third act one that might go down as one of the best endings I've seen in a film period. What I enjoyed most about 'Sound of Metal' was it's unpredictability. I credit this to writer/director Darius Marder and co-writer Derek Cianfrance ('The Place Beyond the Pines', 'Blue Valentine', 'I Know This Much is True').

My Review - "Sound of Metal " streaming on Prime
My Rating 9/10Today it was announced today that this film "Sound of Metal " has been nominated for 6 Academy Awards including Best Picture, Best Actor for Riz Ahmed , and Best Supporting Actor for Paul Raci and also Best Screenplay.
The film is also a BAFTA hopeful with 3 nominations including another Best Actor nomination for Riz Ahmed.
Well after seeing Sound of Metal I have to say of all the Best Actor and Best Supporting Actor movie performances this year these two Actors stand out for me.
I have a feeling though that it will be a sympathetic posthumous win for Chadwick Boseman . With the greatest respect for the departed and much loved Actor Chadwick Boseman's performance in Ma Rainey's Black Bottom doesn't even come near to the superb performance of Riz Ahmed cast. Riz is cast as Rubin a punk heavy-metal drummer's life that is thrown into freefall when he begins to lose his hearing due to excessive volumes in the music the band performs.
Riz Ahmed a 39 year old Actor also known by his stage name Riz MC and birth name Rizwan Ahmed, is a British Pakistani actor, rapper, and activist.
Riz is truly brilliant in the challenging role of Rubin a successful heavy metal drummer who is faced with the consequences of entirely losing his hearing due to the excessive loud volumes of sound that his eardrums have endured.
Director and writer Darius Marder shows how loud in the opening scene of "The Sound of Metal " where Rubin and Lou his girlfriend ( Olivia Cooke) perform "Purify" I had to turn the volume down but heavy metal music lovers might turn it up. Thankfully that's the only really loud song and it's so effective when we realise Rubin is going deaf .The Director cleverly fades out and cuts out chunks of sound as would occur with rapid deafness and we can imagine the panic and fear that this young man is experiencing.
The research that went into Riz Ahmed's role and this film are impressive an a large number if the cast were hired from the deaf community. For eight months, Riz Ahmed prepared for the film by spending two hours a day learning American Sign Language, two hours a day in drum lessons, two hours a day with a personal trainer and the remainder with his acting coach. Director Darius Marder wanted Ahmed to "trust his instincts" and did not allow him to review dailies of his performance or script analysis. The film was shot in four weeks
Sound of Metal is an educational, inspiring film on many counts as experiencing the trauma of deafness Rubin is also a recovering addict of 4 years and is convinced by his supportive girlfriend Lou played beautifully by Olivia Cooke to seek support in the fear he may pick up again.
Rubin reluctantly joins a recovery programme ,especially designed for the deaf run by Joe played by Paul Raci,who is also nominated for Best Supporting Actor.
Joe try's to get Rubin to accept his deafness and with the help of sign language teaching and the connection with others Rubin has to decide whether to stay on as a valued member of the recovery community or move on.
This film is an amazing achievement and deserves all the accolades it's receiving and I hope Riz Ahmed and Paul Raci achieve great success at the upcoming Oscars and BAFTA Awards.
Don't miss this one.

reviews.review_title: Worst movie, depression is never ending
reviews.content: I thought this movie would be similar to whiplash before watching. I was wrong. I strongly recommend everyone not to watch this movie. It is so depressing and at the end it doesn't prove anything. Totally waste of time.

SOUND OF METAL has a pretty simple "one-line summary": Heavy Metal Drummer deals with going deaf. But is it the humanity at the center of this film that makes it worthwhile.Written and Directed by Darius Marder (THE PLACE BEYOND THE PINES), SOUND OF METAL tells the tale of Ruben, the drummer of the Heavy Metal Band BLACK GAMMON, who must come to terms with suddenly losing most of his hearing.Starring Riz Ahmed - in an Oscar nominated turn - SOUND OF METAL follows Ruben's journey as he comes to terms with the wrinkle that his life has thrown at him and the silence makes him study the non-stillness inside of him.This all sounds like it could be corny, right? Well...under the guidance of Marder and with a central performance that is grounded and real by Ahmed, it is anything but. This film finds itself in it's humanity and the very real, personal interactions.Credit must start with the performance of Ahmed (heretofore known to me as Bodhi Rook in STAR WARS: ROGUE ONE), he is in almost every scene in the film and he must bring a vulnerability to the screen for the audience to care about him - and he accomplishes this in spades. Even when his character makes mistakes (and, trust me, he makes a TON of them), you end up rooting for him to succeed.Paul Raci was nominated for a Best Supporting Actor Oscar for his portrayal of Joe, the head of the Deaf Community for Addicts that Ruben eventually goes to. His turn is also grounded in the reality - the reality of addicts who have yet another twist in their life thrown at them. Raci has a road-weary look to him and gives off an aura of someone who has seen - and heard - it all, so must take a "tough love" approach. This performance works very well.Also strong in this film is Olivia Cooke (READY PLAYER ONE) as Lou, Ruben's girlfriend/lead singer of the Metal Band they are in. She must make some tough decisions in the course of this film - and you end up emotionally engaged in her story as well. Both Ruben and Lou are good people at heart that must make hard choices, you root for both of them to succeed even though, through these choices, pain and suffering and separation must occur.All of this sounds good, but there has been many a film that falters under the "good intentions" of it's Director/Screenwriter, but SOUND OF METAL avoids most of the pitfalls of these types of films by not dwelling too much on the pain and suffering of the leads - it's there, but (as Joe would say), deal with it. I'm a little surprised that Marder did not get a Best Director Oscar nod (the work is that good), but am glad that he did get an Original Screenplay nomination.And...as you can imagine...a film about Deafness is reliant on the Sound Design to help bring that aspect of Ruben's experience to the audience - and this film delivers the goods. The sound team was, rightfully, nominated for the Oscar for sound design - and they should easily win - for the sound is another character in this film and that is what, ultimately, makes this film works. The audience is put in Ruben's shoes and, at times, are unable to hear what others on the screen are saying.A very satisfying film experience - one that needs to be seen with no distractions (especially sound distractions), so find a quiet time, lower the shades and dive into the world of the SOUND OF METAL.Letter Grade: A-8 stars (out of 10) and you can take that to the Bank (ofMarquis)

reviews.review_title: Be Here For Sound of Metal
reviews.content: Yes, winter movie season is in full swing. It seems like there are so many great offerings every weekend on multiple platforms. A plethora of opportunities for entertainment. Upon the suggestion from Prime Video, I watched Sound of Metal, which premiered on the platform on December 4, 2020. Here's why it was such a worthwhile experience.The plot of Sound of Metal is pretty simple - it's a drama starring Riz Amhed as a heavy metal drummer whose life takes an unexpected turn when he begins to lose his hearing. Ahmed plays the drummer, Ruben, who is part of the heavy mental duo with his girlfriend played by Olivia Cooke, and their music career seems to be going along smoothly. But, as a recovering addict, the hearing loss sends Ruben into a tailspin. As directed by Darius Marder, the crux of the film is how Ruben copes with the monumental change in his life and the emotions that he goes through, will he be able to hear again, will his relationship survive, will he survive and so many deep and devastating questions. It's not just a typical movie about an addict - though that is an important part. The film also dives into questions of identity and what makes us who we are - or who we think we are.All of these questions hinge on the strength of the performances of Ahmed, Cooke and Paul Raci. Raci plays a sponsor, or mentor of sorts, to Ruben as he deals with his addiction and his hearing loss. Ahmed plays Ruben so well. There's so much passion, and fear, felt throughout film. The success of the film really rests on Ahmed's shoulders and he carries it well. Cooke is very good as the girlfriend and bandmate. It's understandable why she may be a motivating factor for Ruben. Raci is very impactful in his part too. He's stern, thoughtful and makes a necessary contrast to Ruben. There's a lot of care in each of these performances and they grow as the movie goes along. These characters are really well-rounded and provide a strong foundation for this emotional story.If you are looking for a good, emotional movie to watch, Sound of Metal is a worthy contender. Riz Ahmed's performance is one people will be talking about for the rest of the year. Grab a big box of popcorn and don't miss this movie.

reviews.review_title: Updated version of the miracle of whoever
reviews.content: Predictable tosh. Have seen the same old story dozens of times on films made for tv. Monumental waste of time. Good acting though, quite liked that kid and the mentor, but that's about it.

As somebody who went suddenly and inexplicably deaf in adulthood I found this to be a powerful study of the distress and bewilderment that went with that. The moments of despair and the gradual zen of acceptance were portrayed brilliantly by Riz Ahmed. Having some hearing left in one ear I was able to appreciate the soundscape somewhat, which I felt mirrored my own experience. Confusion, numbness and sometimes chaos along with an utterly consuming, constant awareness of a sense gone wrong that I took for granted beforehand.

His performance is top level and believable, start to finish. The score was incredible. Sound engineering, incredible. Cinematography, pleasing. The main take away, for me, was that the film never feels forced. Highly recommend if you want to get cathartic.

First, I very much appreciate from the reviewers who can report back from first (or close second) hand experience on cochlear implants.The fact that the film poignantly talks about a rift in the deaf community may be the more important echo, than the details of the surgery and Ruben's rapid post process. Anyways, casting aside those details that are clearly important in real life, I still think this film stands strong.Many of us struggle to change our lives over time, but when someone has a significant change thrust upon them, in an accelerated fashion, to me that is fascinating. Never mind the striking contrast of drummer in a noise duo losing his hearing as the change covered. As for details, minor compared to the actual surgery and related aspects....the t-shirt work in this film certainly caught my eye.Anyways, more than a bit of a spoiler, but the "break up" between Ruben and Joe was more staggering to me than the break up between Ruben and Lu. A lot of the characters in this film come with back stories that are expressed in a couple of sentences, but pack the density of a black hole. Joe delivers his lines early on, but Paul Raci's portrayal fills in the spaces with a powerful soulful performance. Indeed spoken silence often when he's on screen, is as powerful as the message of silence he wishes to impart to Ruben. The old adage about the notes one does not play seems to apply.Reading up a little now on Raci, seems he was clearly the man for this role. As intense as Riz Ahmed was, Raci matched that fire with subtlety.The ability to adapt as human beings, and kids especially (those school scenes were the most precious of metals!), always impresses me.
The acting is exceptional and the general atmosphere of the film had me hooked from the start.
The kind of movie that will have an effect on you. The acting felt too real. Overall it's a very good movie that you don't wanna miss.

reviews.review_title: Starts slow but worth staying with
reviews.content: Beautiful tender ending, great sound design and acting.Well worth your time.

The sound engineer in this was amazing, I felt and heard the entire experience. A dark fear I have is that relenting ringing in my ears turning into the dreaded silence. Such an authentic and different movie. A story well worth hearing.

reviews.review_title: Don't ignore that ear bud volume warning on your phone kids!
reviews.content:
When I was young, I remember being scared to death by an old black and white movie about a woman who went blind.... I remember she was travelling on a bus and the movie simulated the view through her eyes as her vision dimmed and then went black. (I've googled this without joy, so can't place the movie!) I found the concept of suddenly losing one of your key senses to be utterly terrifying. So, I was fully engaged with Ruben's issues in this movie.I thought the movie was going to be downbeat and depressing. But, both with it's positive portrayal of the deaf community and with the extraordinary ending, I found it to be a wonderfully heart-warming tale.Positives:
There is just SOOO much depth to this story: a character torn from his familiar world and struggling to adapt to the changes. It's fundamentally a movie about acceptance of self. The last two minutes of the screen time are momentous: one of the best endings of a movie I can remember in recent memory. A truly religious experience."Sound of Metal" won the BAFTA at the weekend for Sound, and deservedly so. It's another leading character in the film, with the editing deftly weaving between the soundscape that most of us live in and Ruben's perception. Apparently, the sound team used a hyper-sensitive microphone in Ahmed's mouth to pick up the inner noises of his body.Both Riz Ahmed and Paul Raci are nominated for Oscars. Simply stunning performances from both of them.Although not nominated, I'd lob Olivia Cooke's name into that frame too. It's almost IMPOSSIBLE to see the same actress who played "Pixie" in the body of Lou. It's a transformation akin to Charlize Theron's in "Monster". (In fact, it took me until the Paris scenes to actually recognize her!)Director Darius Marder - IN HIS DIRECTORIAL FEATURE DEBUT! - delivers a fabulous example of "show not tell". All of the detail is present in the film to tell the story if you look for it. You don't need dialogue to give Lou's backstory: just a casual shot of her lower arm is enough.Negatives:
It's a VERY minor quibble but, with a 2 hour running length, the Paris scenes dragged just a little for me. I might have chosen to do a few nips and tucks there in the 'party' scenes. But I wouldn't have wanted to lose much."Sound of Metal" has - I'm sure - a guaranteed slot in my Films of the Year list. Simply stunning and highly recommended, this is currently showing in the UK on Amazon Prime.(For the full graphical review, please check out One Mann's Movies on the web or Facebook. Thanks")

reviews.review_title: Non-consistency error-prone plot with no characters development
reviews.content: I really like when Ruben in the deaf community and the school. I like how the film portraits each characters in those scenes. But for the general plot. It's really non-consistency and error-prone. No general character development in this film, how Lu changed, we have no idea Lu has a rich dad until the end of the film. Not to mention the factual errors about implantation surgery. Whole film feels like from someone just saw three pages of Wikipedia about deaf experiences and did a field trip to a deaf community. Audiences really can feel that the writers and director try very hard to twist the plot to fit the main message of this film, stillness. However, when the whole film don't make you feel real, when you don't even care about the key characters in this film, how strong this message can be.

I had to stop it after 30 minutes. I couldn't take it anymore. It was literally annoying and painful to watch this. The story was moving sooooo slow... I can't believe the script and the writing.... so bad. The editing - so bad. The acting - average at best. Very low budget movie that went absolutely nowhere. Bye!!!!

You're on solid ground with Riz Ahmed starring. Sound of Metal opens with him, playing Ruben, pounding the skins, bare-chested in a club whilst his girlfriend Lou (Olivia Cooke) screams into the mic. Music is clearly everything as they drive their world in an Airstream around the states. It's lofi DIY, music as a lifestyle, for love. Then Ruben's ears ring. You know the sound, even if hearing loss doesn't effect you. You know that high pitch warning sign that signals trouble. It's trouble for anyone of course, but for a musician, a young musician. Devastation is not too strong a word. We are put right in Ruben's head, all muffled and muted. It's pretty bloody terrifying. You have to strain as he does to make things out (although I cheated a little with subtitles). The world inside Ruben is markedly different from outside. When we hear the other perspective it's truly shocking and upsetting as to just how much he's missing. His loss is severe, possibly brought on by noise exposure, possibly something else. What's clear though is he's not much hearing left, has to protect what is left and has to make a choice. Choices are complicated things aren't they. We make our own, often don't understand others and this is often hard to comprehend. There's also denial, a strong complicated emotion and Ahmed pulls off Ruben's masterfully. Although it's Ruben's present that concerns us, he has a past too. One that could quickly come back to haunt him given his new bleak reality. Luckily for him, it seems he's some good people around him, one of whom introduces Joe (Paul Raci). Joe wants to help, can help, but it involves Ruben ditching that denial, before he implodes. Upsetting as the situation is. It is wonderfully uplifting to see people, a community, rally round and help, out of pure kindness, understanding. Ruben's isolation is palpable. Finding himself in a deaf community, learning to cope, there's little communicative sound and we're as isolated as Ruben. As he learns and his world opens up, as does ours and my god it is glorious! It's only one facet of his new life though. Sure he can communicate again, has even found meaning in the work he's doing within the deaf community. Music though. Performing. Living. That, well he still needs it and try as he might, can't let go. He's forced to make another choice and somehow this seems even harsher than anything he's faced before. It's a heartbreaking to witness Ruben's reality repeatedly smashed, but amazingly insightful and ultimately startling redemptive.

Definitely much better than expected, especially considering how terrible this year was. Acting is powerful, cinematography and directing as well.But could have been great if they would address some important things. For example I would expect to know more about the background of relationship between Ruben and Lou. How he lost his hearing? (it can't be just making noise music). And why no one tells him what to expect from surgery? Probably giving those details would have caused to lose focus on deaf people community yet I think character development needed more.One final complaint is that ending was too dark for my taste. Of course I wasn't expecting a happy ending but in final moments the only option left for Ruben was to commit suicide considering his personality. At least he had 20% hearing before the surgery and now what he has is absolute silence or low bitrate sadness. He lost Lou, the community and everything. Is the message "don't go after your dreams!" Or "don't try to fix problems even if there is a chance to fix it"?I'm not sure about the message. In the end this is definitely a good piece but could have been a superb experience with better crafting in the story.

What are filmakers ( especially americans ) smoking these days ? almost every 2020 film is just a chore to sit through, Sound of Metal, with a great performance at the centre, is simply a joyless, academic character study, in a different time it could've been something cinematic, a metaphor, with style, passion behind the camera, think about character studies from the 70s/80s like Straight Time or Scarecrow, this is so earnest, almost a rejection of cinema as an art form, same goes for critics favorites as Never Rarely Sometimes Always, Minari, even First Cow, and then you have the directors not getting funding for their projects... this is the reason why.

reviews.review_title: Amazing. Watch it. The sound. The story.
reviews.content: I heard that this was the movie to watch and these recommendations were right.The story was amazing. The sound in the film was perfection - enlightening, terrifying, mesmerizing ... perfect.The other reviews and trailer give you a lot of info. What you need to know is: sit down and watch. Not in the background, no pauses - just watch.

I skimmed a few reviews to see what others thought of Sound of Metal and a lot of folks seemed to have a lot of unanswered questions revolving the story line, a lot of holes and blanks. I also had many of those exact same questions during my viewing too. However, i feel that for some stories the answers to those questions are important, even vital to the success of the story. For the Sound of Metal however, i don't think that not having all those answers mattered all that much to the successful telling of this story. I still felt and became fully engaged in this persons journey. The one exception though is the relationship with his girlfriend Lou, that was seriously lacking and a real mess to the point of distraction. I've never experienced two people who are meant to be so in love and committed to also be so lacking in basic communication. Otherwise, I enjoyed the Sound of Metal.

The sound design leapt out. If this doesn't scoop up some Best Sound Design awards in the coming year it will honestly be a travesty.Truly phenomenal. As someone who has some issues with my hearing due to live music this movie was honestly anxiety inducing early on. But on an emotional level it ends up being completely fulfilling.

reviews.review_title: Solid film with a beautiful use of sound
reviews.content: This movie really breaks ground sonically. I kept myself completely in the dark beforehand with the intention of experiencing everything as a virgin. The movie is very powerful and the sonic POV is phenomenal. That was my first exposure to something to this level of creativity. I loved the casting and would even go out of my way to say how much I even enjoyed the music the band plays. (Not hard to impress me though because I'm a metal head-even the abstract, atmospheric kind)My biggest issue with the film, despite its impeccable approach to sound, is some of the filming. The cinematography is great but it comes across as a blatant rip off Aronofsky's films. It's being done into the ground these days-cough, cough, Nomadland, the unfortunate Oscar winner. "Quick cuts" isn't a new element to cinema but the way it is portrayed in the film has been done by Darren Aronofsky, to the "T". The Wrestler particularly comes to mind when comparing films side-by-side.Overall, this film is a solid one that will outlast the test of time. It's worth seeing and re-visiting.Ps: if you have the chance, watch this film with surround sound or with quality headphones. You won't regret it.

''Sound of Metal'' is, in the end, a movie about feelings and, most importantly, about acceptance. I have recently read ''Blindness'' by Jose Saramago and while I admit losing your sight and having almost no one to help you is indeed the worst nightmare one can live through, rapidly losing your hearing is still one of the most terrible processes one could go through, especially if you're a drummer and music is your dream and your future. One is full of anger in front of destiny; he has never been so far from the ''amor fati'' ideal enunciated by Friedrich Nietzsche. The truth is I don't know how losing something/someone very important to your life and mental sanity feels like (except my grandpa, but he died when I was 9 and my parents didn't let me go to the funeral so I only remember the happy times). Nevertheless, I can empathize with the main character and therefore comprehend the idea of having to accept a harsh reality and thus find the ''stillness'' one really needs. Oh, and great portrayal of the deaf community, I wish some characters could have had a more important role but it's O. K., they had their fair share. An 8,30 out of 10 from me.
Great story, great execution, great actors and a stellar Riz Ahmed. I don't think he was ever less than excellent. Oscar nod would be deserved for his work.

reviews.review_title: Riz Ahmed... a Star is Born!
reviews.content: While the craftsmanship of sound design is nothing short of excellent, it's nothing more than practical. It's by no means exceptional, but that doesn't take away anything from its value and efficiency that, in part, rendered this movie a truly immersive experience. It's Riz Ahmed's bravura performance, though, that gives Sound of Metal resonance that, in turn, made Ruben one of the most relatable movie characters I've witnessed in recent memory.His ability to reflect his fluctuating feelings throughout the movie and how he perceives every phase in his new life is simply astonishing. The aching experience Ruben goes through demands a real acting talent to make the audience emotionally connected to the protagonist, but Ahmed proved he's not just a talented actor but also one who's in a total command of his craft. For if it's hard to make the viewer feel what his character feels, it's even harder to transport its mental state to the audience. Here, we don't only get the sense of loss and being stripped of everything that forms every inch of Ruben in a flicker, nor only do we only understand his pressing need to regain what he lost-especially since the possibility hovering in the air-but we see him grappling with the dilemma of whether he should continue his journey of adapting to his new condition as if it was the norm or he should keep clutching onto the flicker of hope that definitely wouldn't help in case of it turned out to be a mere mirage.Furthermore, the movie also excels in aspects other than its nuanced portrait of its main character, namely is its exploration of deaf community that truly offers new insights. That's mostly because of the effort shown in the meticulous attention to its essential components, most notably the sign language. However, Paul Raci played a major part in that by portraying the leader of this community and a mentor for Ruben. Through his facial expressions during conversations with Ruben, he delineates the professional duties such an occupation demands. We see him monitoring Ruben's progress and interfering according to his understanding of Ruben's character in particular. As for Olivia Cooke, she further proves she's a remarkable young talent that yet to bloom. Playing Ruben's bandmate and girlfriend Lou, she managed to prove how important she's to Ruben as his most great and precious loss and equally as a great help for him to get a better sense of what he has lost and how to cope with that.The acting clinic these three immense talents put on here left an indelible impression on me, but disregarding the technical quality would make absolutely no sense. Besides the exquisite sound design, the highly-articulate cinematography truly adds up to the experience. If there's only one issue I have about this movie it would be its failure to maintain the same dramatic heft that was in its first half. As the focus on Ruben's progression through his medical recovery and its consequences slightly overpowered the emotional quality, and hence there was a bit of it lost that even the wrap-up failed to fully retrieve.(8.5/10)

Excellent sound design. Excellent performance from Riz Ahmed. Brilliant concept. Makes you appreciate the stillness and peace of coming to terms with recovery.Very powerful film, stired very deep feelings.

The best movies show us the perspective of others and make us truly understand what it's like. This movie exudes with that idea, and excels at it. The sound design is phenomenal, really giving you a feeling of being a part of the main characters story. I was riveted the whole time intently watching amazed by scenes and brought to tears at times.If I have one criticism, it's that somehow even though months went by his hairstyle never changed. It's like his hair never grew out. I feel like the passing of time and the change in his appearance would have added even more to the changes that are going on within the character. It kept drawing me out of it thinking "Well what, has it just been a couple of weeks? I don't think I could imagine anyone learning sign language that quickly...."
The writing was superb, the acting top notch, and overall technical ingenuity, especially sound wise, delivered such a amazing experience beyond all expectations!

reviews.review_title: Lingers long after you finish watching ... loved it!
reviews.content: I am a Riz Ahmed fan and watched this movie purely because he was in it and went into it with zero expectations. What a treat it turned out to be. It's beautifully scripted and the acting of all involved is definitely worthy of a few award nominations. You feel the intensity and the pain and then the beauty of it all eventually. I don't want to say too much but suffice to say its the kind of movie that you think about long after you're done watching it. If you don't mind powerful but subtle drama - go see this.
It's hard to believe that films like this are made these days. It is perfect in every aspect of film making. Acting, script and directing are all perfect

When i first saw the trailer for this movie, I though of Pete Tong.
It's the same plot and everyone who is interested in this movie should go watch "It's all gone Pete Tong" first. Its the same plot.

Wonderfully uncommon subject matter, beautifully acted and explored - what are your people and your kind. Sound is a key feature in this film so don't watch through a laptop speakers. Riz Ahmed is fantastic yet understatedly realistic. Loved this

reviews.review_title: The first 10 minutes, and that was it
reviews.content: I decided to try this film out since everyone had been raving over it, calling it a masterpiece, and everyone was talking about the acting, writing, sound design... I'm sorry, but I didn't want to watch the whole thing after seeing the first 10 minutes of it.First of all, does this director have any idea what pacing means? Because the first 10 minutes of this film are terribly slow and disappointing. We start out with some nicely done sound design, but otherwise, that's about it. The performances. Fine. Sound Design. Great. Cinematography. Meh. Directing. Meh. Writing. Terrible. I don't know who wrote this, but whoever did must not understand the importance of pacing, because the next 5-10 minutes of the film (after the loud opening sequence) are just plain horrible.We get a couple additional scenes that could have easily been cut from the film, including an awkwardly extended dancing scene between the two main characters, in which they dance to some slow music (I don't know...R&B, whatever it is) and then that's when I checked out. Because I knew that even if the rest of the film got better, I didn't want to see the rest of the film because of that one word that the writers forgot about: Pacing.
I liked this movie is good, a little sad but totally inspiring.

reviews.review_title: The Goofs start to sum it up
reviews.content: This film gets some things very right while at the same time working with a script that gets a lot of things very wrong that could easily have been right.Riz does not remotely look possibly Mexican but very specifically Pakistani, and the script has him not only as "Ruben" but he details his Southwest US childhood. Could easily have been changed with no difference in the film.In reality the doctor he sees would have done tone tests (who hasn't run into those at some point?) but the film goes on and on with word recognition testing. The doctor does not describe what is going on physically with his hearing and immediately talks about implants. There are various reasons for hearing loss, but for a metal drummer one version is most likely. From other surgeries I've had I bet anything that there are brochures from the implant companies describing everything that the doctor would have handed him, or some kind of other information sheets.Even though he has been clean for four years he suddenly goes to a deaf addict live-in program for no reason. Then he is in a grade school classroom for no obvious reason. But all of these do seem like very possible realities, just not him being there. The head guy has him seclude himself in a room and write, not draw. Nothing comes of it.As others have written, the process of getting cochlear implants is nothing like what happened. A lot of education, doing one at a time, sessions to learn to hear with them, and just time etc. And insurance would pay for all the surgery and probably most or all of the implant itself. If he didn't have insurance already (insurance was mentioned like he had it, but it not paying was plain wrong) he would have been told to get on Medicaid, which he no doubt would have qualified for.A film can shorten and leave a lot out, but there is no reason to just get it all wrong.After his surgery the doctor writes a message about what is next. He would already have been told all that and more already. It would also be in that brochure.When he returns to the program the head guy explains why he can't stay. This would have been something he already knew. He wouldn't have come back.The sound design is excellent on portraying how he would hear before and after the implant. What is left out is the therapy and just time and experience that would teach his brain to correctly interpret the post-implant information. The acting and overall reality of the scenes is all on point, things a less indie Hollywood film might get wrong. How did the director not realize all the things very wrong with the script? Oh, he was one of the writers.So, maybe worth seeing for what it gets right, but you have to ignore a whole lot it gets wrong.

What worked:
It's a well written, acted and executed piece of art. I liked it that it kept both prospective; the sound and the stillness together in the movie, and exploring them both. It's a beautiful movie, with metaphorical and spiritual meaning and humor embedded in the texture of the movie. The movie ends with the answer to the meaning that stands when we see the movie viewing experience. Riz Ahmed lived the role, I am sure he must have spent weeks both learning the drums and sign language. It's a good movie watching experience altogether.
What did not work:
As a movie related to metal, I was expecting to see a bit more sequence on performances or drum solos. It's not that they did not make us believe it, I wanted more personally. Also, a bit more insight by the lead character leading to the finale would made it better. At times, the permeability of the sound of deaf and normal hearing can be a disturbing experience. I would have been delighted with a bit heartwarming ending rather than the harsh, real ending. Maybe because it answered pivotal questions but not all.
Final verdict: having said that, it's a very recommended movie

reviews.review_title: Standard and unengaging drama with exceptional sound design and lead performance
reviews.content: Pretty much title. If you take out the sound design and Riz Ahmed there is nothing special about this at all. However, those two things do elevate it above an average film and the ending is also super effective. The theatre reacted very strongly to that section, myself included.

reviews.review_title: A new meaning to "enjoy the silence"
reviews.content: Sometimes, the simplest stories make the most intriguing films. This is the case in 'Sound of Metal' - a tough on the outside, tender on the inside telling of how a man must come to grips with who he is as he battles deafness.The success of 'Metal' really rests on three things - the caliber of Riz Ahmed's acting as the heavy metal drummer, Ruben, the excellent screenplay by Darius and Abraham Marder and the sound editing and mixing that helps give it a unique sense of character. The acting, writing and sound converge to make a beautiful symphony on the screen, which is ironic given the fact that a lack of sound is central to the story. Seeing Ahmed's Ruben struggle with his declining health is difficult, but it also opens up other aspects of his life. It's also worth noting the performance given by Olivia Cooke as Ruben's rocker girlfriend, Lou, as this is perhaps the most mature role Cooke has had to date.The most touching moment in 'Sound of Metal' is the final scene. Given the lessons learned throughout the film, the simplicity of this scene is enough to send chills down your spine. Sometimes, there's more to life than what's on the surface.

reviews.review_title: dude ,what an amazing film this is
reviews.content: A drama can not get better or more real than this. everything is spot on . acting , plot , directing you name it , it is there. this guy , riz ahmed is absolutely growing up on me... i admire his talent... strongly recommend it...
I'm not sure what all the hype is about this film. It's just a metal version of It's All Gone Pete Tong.Riz Ahmed was excellent in his role but that's the only original thing about this film.

reviews.review_title: An emotionally honest and raw film
reviews.content: Sound of Metal deserves the hype it's been generating, and Riz Ahmed's fantastic performance anchors it. Sound of Metal is a simple story, but the technical elements are well done and you feel like you're going on this journey with Ruben. I loved the avoidance of tropes and not trying to tie up every plot point with a neat bow or have generic rises and falls, but instead to have things happen and people move on as happens in real life. Ruben's struggle to accept his hearing loss at the start is well done, and I thought it'd go down an Aronofsky-style route of Ruben refusing to give up and remaining obsessed with drumming because it's all he knows, and it eventually ruins his life. It's not that type of obsession-driven movie; instead, it's a much more intimate story of a man adjusting to life as a deaf person and transitioning from being a drummer to a member of a deaf community. Ahmed is really fantastic, one of my favorite performances of the year. His initial confidence that he can do it and reluctance to admit the problem is great, but what really sold me was his reaction to the surgery. Finally he can hear but it's not very clear, and you can tell he assumed it would be a silver bullet and that everything had to go back to normal and in that moment he is crushed realizing it wouldn't. It also may be the best sound design I've ever seen, doing a great job of showing his perspective and how daunting the loss of hearing is while not losing any exposition or meaning in the scenes. This is a very solid film that really thinks about the nuances of losing your hearing, but is also an excellent and authentic character study.
To me, this movie is overrated. It was pleasant to watch and it surely made you feel empathy for people with such hardships, but that's the end to it.

reviews.review_title: Certainly distinctive, a bit simplistic and some awkward scenes
reviews.content: Hearing loss is not something being touched on in movies. Felt like the film portrayed it rather well, using the sound cut offs and the warped noises blending into each other when he got the hearing implants.My probelm is that there are a lot of missed opportunities. Only him and his girlfriend in the band? Would have been intriguing how other possible band members take the situation etc. The characters felt a bit cliche, dude plays in metal band and has tattoos so obviously his backstory is former heroin addict.Liked that concepts as stillness and acceptance was mentioned, a bit more impasingly though. Think it could have been 15 to 20 minutes shorter, just don't see what many of the scenes in the deaf support group are adding. Yes, he is coming to terms with reality and that is what should be conveyed, however don't think it was executed convincingly. That said, can't deny the finish was pretty great.

This is a movie about a person who is forced to lose something they find precious to them, and how they cope with it. It's about trying to accept what life throws at you. This is a universal theme all of us can relate to. The movie portrays that extremely well. Great acting by every person in this film. One of the best 2020 films I seen.

"The sound of metal" is a film that seeks to portray the anguish caused by a sudden hearing loss, and manages to do that very well.Telling the story of a drummer from an indie band who lives with his girlfriend (vocalist) on a motor home giving presentations by the country, the script in its first layer seems simple, but as the work progresses, the characters are deepened and we are feeling a commotion for the lives of the protagonists, script and direction work together to compose a narrative that deeply scales the sentimental level of the plot.The direction is good, with an emphasis on the opening scene, the good use of photography and lighting and the incredible use of sound mixing, which is often used even as part of the narrative of the work, causing a great immersionAll performances are good, but Riz Ahmed is spectacular, the actor's job is to deliver and deep knowledge about his character, we have a performance that goes through the most diverse personalities of a single individual, and even in the simplest scenes the actor managed to give a realistic and painful look to your character, the Oscar nomination is very fair.The work of the inexperienced Darius Marder is very interesting, it is very clear that the director wants to cause a great immersion to the viewer, and he manages to do this from the first scene of the film, and whenever we get distracted he finds a way to put the people back into the movie, these details are present in the protagonist's tattoos, and even in the detail of sign language, where the director takes the caption from conversations in pounds and only replaces it when our protagonist learns the language, without speaking the feeling of subject of the environments that we can feel, are details of those who thought a work, but not everything is perfect, the film has a belly in the second act, and despite the good and very brave ending we have some errors of coherence in the journey, however "The sound of metal" is a pleasant surprise. Grade 08/10

I was hyped to see this movie as soon as I saw the trailer. I am a fan of Riz Ahmed and Olivia Cooke both; they were both absolutely superb. Riz Ahmed should at least be nominated for an Oscar. Do yourself a favor and and see it; definitely worth a view at least once. Also, as to the title - Sound of Metal? I started watching the movie thinking it was describing the type of music they played; I got it by the end that it was referring to something else completely.

Really hard hitting film...yes it's a bit slow, but packs a punch, can really feel the frustration..
There are some parts where I thought it's a bit harsh to castigate him from the group because he's opted for the operation..
Above all though, Riz Ahmed is utterly convincing, fantastic performance that kept me gripped.

I feel like I'm going to give off the impression of hating this more than I actually do for some reason.It's an interesting film for sure though, usually you'd expect something with this concept to be a lot of moping and relapsing and whatnot, but it actually provides a pretty interesting look into the deaf community and there were a lot of things it showed that I had never thought of when it comes to how deaf people live.That said, maybe this was me being stupid, but to me, it never seemed to be implied that Ruben couldn't already afford the implants to partially bring his hearing back, so when his girlfriend dumped him at the deaf people's home and Paul Raci went on about how he doesn't see deafness as a handicap, it kind of seemed like they were being judgemental dicks trying to make Ruben's medical decisions for him.Aside from that, there's so many great touches that put you into Ruben's head, like how you don't get subtitles for characters speaking sign language until he's learned it, and the fantastic sound design, where so many other films would have just gone "he can't hear, innit".And this is the first big Oscar contender I've seen so far, but I don't think I'd be upset at all with Riz Ahmed winning best actor, and I absolutely would love it to win best sound. There's an amazing sense of subtle anger and dread to both of them, and they're easily the best two things of this.Aside from the interesting aspects of the deaf community though, I couldn't help but feel like the story was slightly cliche "tortured musician" stuff, but he's a good tortured musician so why am I even complaining.

Riz Ahmed is stunning in this powerful movie about Ruben, a drummer who loses his hearing. Through imaginative use of sound, we enter his head to better understand how he perceives what's happening to him and why he reacts as he does.Ahmed is given excellent support from Olivia Cooke as his musical-and-life partner. Their scenes together are real and touching, even when the film's final act reduces the story's credibility a little. Also memorable is Paul Raci as the man who hopes to open Ruben's eyes to the truth of living without his ears.

reviews.review_title: This movie starts off slow but it finishes with such a refined ending. Emotional, powerful, beautiful. Absolutely worth the watch.
reviews.content: It was an okay movie. The acting was good. I'm not a deaf person but I could tell there were some things that were just kind of...off. Like he was so shocked at how the implants sounded but wouldn't the doctors have prepared him for that before he shelled out thousands of dollars and got his head torn open? And the deaf community he was at literally shunning him for wanting to regain his hearing seemed weird, too. Also I couldn't believe the supposed love of his life hadn't even bothered learning sign for him! Wow. She was awful.

This movie takes you through every emotion possible. I can't remember the last movie that has done that. Well acted and written. I will leave it at that because I don't want to spoil anything. Watch this movie.

reviews.review_title: The sound of silence is peaceful
reviews.content: What can we say about the drummer Ruben ( Riz Ahmed) who loses his sense of hearing and has to adjust with the handicap ? We can say that this film has a superb performance from this lesser known actor which should get him accolades. A difficult character to play and Riz has done well. Some films should be seen for the sterling performance of the lead actor. This is one such film. Go for it.Director Darius Marder has made a memorable movie on this subject and has extracted a superlative performance from Riz. After his hearing loss, Ruben's relationship with his steady girlfriend becomes turbulent and they separate temporarily. Ruben then joins an American sign language group run by a Vietnam War veteran (Paul Raci ) who attempts to rehabilitate him in the world of silence. Ruben however is keen to get his hearing back and sells his belongings including musical instruments and van to get money for a cochlear transplant.This interesting film has many scenes which will move you. There may be aberrations in the technicalities of audio tests or post surgery procedures or sign language classes but that does not take away the honest intent of the director in portraying the sadness associated with loss of hearing. We find that Ruben starts liking the peace which he gets from silence but is it temporary? He has the option now.

reviews.review_title: Had potential, but lost it on the cutting floor
reviews.content:
Riz showed off his acting chops. Olivia was very capable in her scenes. This movie has large gaps in the story-line. I'm sure large pieces were left out in editing. It started off great and the chemistry and pace were very good. AMazing few minutes when Olivia convinced Riz he needed help and then when she left for him to stay at the camp. The story then meanders along without focus. More "flesh" could have been added to the other characters there. Or more focus on RIz's character to do something positive. Or negative. DId he really achieve the entire amount in cash to perform the surgery? How did he go back and forth? Including scheduling appointments? After getting the diagnosis and being told about the surgery - they drove some distance to the camp...
Curious about the ending , but don't wish to give it away in the every the director wanted that to be the "big decision"... A good movie, but could have been so much better in the middle.

I find this to be a powerful movie on multiple layers. Firstly, it is a rare movie that delves into the lives of people living in a deaf community. Even though this is not the primary focus in the movie, we get a decent glimpse through the eyes of our main character. Then, we experience the journey of the main character's life altering misfortune through his, denial, decisions, regrets, self-hatred and acceptance with the help of some great acting by Riz Ahmed.It also has an exceptional cinematography that helps build that bleak, grey and depressing world that his world has become. But for me where the movie shines the most is the sound design (as the name suggests). The excellent use of dynamics turned this movie into a sonic roller-coaster ride. The amazingly loud and almost obnoxious opening scene which eventually makes way to their dead quiet rv is great introduction of what's to come. As we progress through the different stages of his deafness, the sound design is always is accompanying us with meticulously crafted silent moments as well as disgustingly distorted unpleasant ones.We follow Ruben, a heavy metal drummer who is slowly losing his hearing.
This movie isn't just about hearing and sound. It's about timing. It's about independence and love. It's about youth and wisdom.It's a movie that I won't forget anytime soon.

I'm disabled and I think this movie gets a lot of praise because it includes disabled (deaf) people. The fact that the movie raises awareness of deaf people is very nice, but it doesn't automatically make it a good movie. The story has big holes, it doesn't show much of deaf people trying to function in society outside of a community of deaf people, and it does a terrible job of explaining the process of cochlear implant surgery and post-op therapy.

reviews.review_title: You guys should watch The Diving Bell and the Butterfly
reviews.content:
It's definitely better than Minari but the movie still have its flawI will start off by writing the goods thing that I like in the movie the first act and the second act especially the bonding with the deaf at schoolThe things that bring down a few notch from the rating is the third act after the surgery where Reuben mentioned to John that his GF is rich and will give him the money and stuff which all just doesn't make sense if that's the case why go through all the hard work at the sanctuary, you might as well stays in the hospital for the surgery and everything will be all right secondly after all the money spent on the surgery the outcome seems to be just slightly better and why the doctor did explain to him throughly before the surgery
