"Sound of Metal" (USA, 2019) is a drama, directed by Darius Marder (Place Beyond the Pines) and written with the also director Derek Cianfrance (Blue Valentine, Light Between Oceans) that is the author of the story.The story follows Ruben, the drummer of a Death Metal band, that plays and lives in a van with his girlfriend and vocal Lou on small gigs, and is starting a career.. Suddenly he starts to lose his auditions, and the movie shows the struggle in his life to adapt to the situation and search for help, with the possibility of recovery with a cochlear implant surgery, but not having the money to do the surgery. All the stressful situation leads to a separation of the couple, with Lou continuing the gig and Rubin reluctantly agreeing to seek help in a deaf community to better learn to deal with the handicap.The plot is intense on emotions, and shows in a realistic way the drama of losing the sense that was essential to Rubin - all the story revolves around this character, and especially from the middle to the end of the movie, the personal drama intensifies, even with the contemplative silence that occupies most of the film, or the sounds of the implant that he acquires later. The scenes that show the adaptation in the community(that uses deaf actors) is absolutely great.The movie has Riz Ahmed as Ruben Stone (Rogue One, Nightcrwaler, The OA,The Night Of), Olivia Cooke as Lou Berger and Paul Raci as Joe (interesting that he had a deaf father in real life). Riz is just awesome on the paper, that involves showing the emotions, despair and anger to the silent parts of the individual learning, dealing and acceptance of the situation. Indeed something that deserves the prizes and indications for best male performer. The def community used deaf actors and that elevated the veracity of the story.The cinematography by Daniël Bouquet (Nothing persona, Kaubow) is pretty competente, taking a more realistic like approach, with a nervous camera, focusing very well on expressions and situations that are really important in the context. Another great detail is the sound department, with the sound of deafening sense and later with the implant sounds transmitting well the sense and situation of the protagonist that leads to such emotions that he feels.Overall a great drama, with an intriguing and engaging story, without the load of melodrama that depicts in a realistic way the situation and the study of the protagonist, with the help of an excellent performance and use of sound department on the production. A solid 7,5 out of 10.

It does not meet with the concept all around but I really find Ruben's path similar to the five stages of grief. Even, when we thougth he accepted the situation, he was still looking for his way back which is understandable given the circumstances. First, the denial of the loss of his hearing. Then, the anger. Later on, trying to learn to be like a deaf person while still handling the depression of it all along. Which ends up with the acceptance one and for all. Plus, he is always in a struggle whether it is to learn the language, to collect money for operation or to put everything back on track.Everything about the film is great we both see what he is going through as an audience and Ruben himself at times. Especially, where he recklessly plays drums in his van, the one he listens to Ruby singing to honor her mother and lastly the ending are all powerful scenes. Yet, the most powerful is probably, when Paul Raci's character Joe asked him to leave after operation because of possible consequences and the responsibility of other people in here. It was a really emotional and a geniune scene. What a great feature-length debut for Darius Marder.

reviews.review_title: So glad I got to see this!
reviews.content:
I didn´t know what to expect. But I think all facetes, the good, the bad and even the ugly ones where showed and never the less you can see the hope and the word worth living. Sorry I´m not a native speaker and so my rating isn´t as eloborate as it should be.

As a sound engineer I was hoping to see this film getting ready to face the same frequent frustrations I usually have in relation to the science involved in these often misunderstood and misrepresented situations. I was very happy to find an incredibly detailed and true depiction of these realities (deaf people, hearing problems, cochlear implants, etc.). And particularly as a musician the story spoke to me in a really intimate way about a fear that I always had. The performances are fantastic and the film doesn't try to be more that it is (a development of a very particular and potentially real situation instead of a universal truth about life or some other cheesy thing), which I think was a vey good choice. It may not be a great film for everyone, some people may find it boring, too slow or not relatable, and I understand them if they have never been close to a similar situation, if they aren't musicians or if they don't have interest on the subject. Otherwise I completely recommend it!
This film boasts incredible acting and sound design. I was riveted and wanted to know how Ruben was going to live through this tragedy. This was a great film and I recommend it.

The movie is an excellent story about a realistic story many have actually experienced in hearing loss. The movie does an excellent job of really making you feel what it is like to lose ones hearing, and come to that acceptance.I'm glad I watched it, and I would encourage others to do so, but I don't need to see it again.

The acting is amazing, Riz Ahmed simply destroys here, and Olivia Cooke is very very good too, in limited time she is on screen.But probably the main point I have to highlight about the movie is the sound mixing/design... like, this might be the first time I see a movie and go "holy cow the sound design is amazing". The way it helps the movie explore the struggle of hearing lost so well is unbelievable, you feel Ruben's pain, you understand what he's going through, and you want him to get better, but fist and foremost, you feel scare for him, thinking how hard that would be. Also, of course, you appreciate and respect the hell of the deaf community for fighting and prospering beautifully through all this difficulty.I love how the movie shows his evolution throughout, and also, the subtitles, where they only appear after Ruben learns sign language, so for half of the movie, those who don't understand sign language just have no idea what they are saying, like Ruben doesn't too. And the ending shows that evolution of the character perfectly, after trying to again, go back to something he already lost entirely, he just accepts life for what it is... and the result is a calm and beautiful world around him. So, the ending scene is greatAll that been said, I don't think the movie is perfect, I have a couple of problems with the story arc overall... like, the hearing implant, wouldn't anyone tell him beforehand the thing wasn't the same as the regular hearing? That's such a crucial point in the story, and the impact we as the audience feel, when we hear what he's hearing... but, in a real-life situation, how likely would it be, that the dude would spend 40k+ and... nobody would tell him that it wouldn't sound like his "regular hearing" sounded? I mean, c'mon.I also didn't understand what exactly did Lou's video made him think... cause it's once again, a big turning point in the story arc, he's fine, he's happy for the first time in a while, and then he sees the video... and wants to sell his stuff. At first, I thought Lou was like homeless or something, doing gigs in the street to pay the bills or something... but she's clearly not, and he knew that. So... what's the deal with the video? Did he just missed playing with her? Idk.Still, the movie is pretty, it's really immersive, and it gets you through this difficult and long journey alongside Ruben, which is amazing to see and experience.

reviews.review_title: Stunning performance, and a touching story
reviews.content:
Movie award shows here we go... The rise of Riz Ahmed is amazing in this Amazon original.It's clear now how the streaming platforms are taking over with their quality content, it started a lot with series, but as more streaming services are coming to existence we are now seeing fantastic movies created on this streaming services. Nothing can take away from you the cinema experience and I believe that never should never happen, but I also believe that the movie industry needs to adapt since there's space for both.Sound of Metal tells the story of a metal drummer that slowly starts to lose his hearing capabilities until he goes completely deaf, sounds interesting enough just by the concept, but the movie strives on how it approached the topic. First of all Riz has a fantastic performance, his posture, behavior and overall personality is so distant from what we see on interviews, you can spot from a distance the acting quality of this guy, adding to that, he prepared months before the actual filming in order to learn sign language and to be exposed to an unknown world for a lot of us, and it shows, the credibility of his performance is really good.It's an issue we all heard about but the majority of us doesn't deal with it at all on our life's, but getting a grasp of how horrific can be for someone to slowly become deaf, it wakes you to appreciate more your everyday life and the fact that you can experience the sounds of the world. The movie captures this beautifully, while presenting moments of deep silence followed by sounds of nature that we tend to ignore.
Adding to this, we also learn how someone with such an issue can accept the reality, not in all cases it can be reversed, and although I defend that if we can find a cure for it we should pursue it, the movie shows to us that it's about accepting and that actually you can even become empowered even if at first it seems that the world will crumble. Silence can be beautiful and in a chaotic world it can elevate us to a more peaceful state of mind.
Overall it is a touching story, a theme that goes outside of your everyday movie, and a fantastic lead performance.

Good movie, outstanding acting by Riz Ahmad, everything was almost perfect but I am little disappointed by the ending, but everyone has different mind set so some may find it " good ending". Else nice one time watch movie.

reviews.review_title: Emotionally wrenching, challenging film about hearing loss
reviews.content: Riz Ahmed is a drummer in a heavy metal band whose work is suddenly interrupted when he experiences drastic hearing loss. This film is a portrayal of how his life changes thereafter. Performances are superior all around. Olivia Cooke is sympathetic and compelling as his love interest and fellow musician. Ahmed is riveting in a starring performance that shows his true depth as an actor. If he was not widely known before this film, he will be now.The film veers back and forth between the protagonist's point of the view and that of someone with normal hearing. This binary narrative is alternately effective but also occasionally jarring. Although there isn't the smoothest narrative at work here, it does have a strong sense of realism in how radical a change deafness is for anyone and those closest, let alone someone in the music profession. It also conveys the raw heartbreak that comes with losing one's hearing as an adult and coping with the extreme changes that follow.It's a fairly difficult film to watch if you've ever known someone dealing with hearing loss. In that regard, the early part might be especially tough to get through, which shows the devastation of deafness becoming a reality. But a film this amazingly acted on such a delicate subject does not come around very often and thus is highly recommended.

What a movie!! Full of emotion. The sound playing along side the amazing performances makes this movie oscar worthy. I'm a fan of Riz career since four lions but now he step up the game with this crazy character full of deep emotion. Paul Raci is also another great actor with a great performance. During the filme I wanted to learn sigh language. Props to the director and everyone envolved in the movie

"The Sound of Metal," (2019). Starring Riz Ahmed and Olivia Cooke, and Paul Raci. Directed by Darius Marder. This is a structure film. The structure is linear, a downward spiral from the main character's successful rock career as a drummer to the abbysmal loneliness of disability...hearing loss. Ruben's journey is ma8rked by denial, fear, anger, betrayal, isolation, conflict, and finality and everything inbetween. Through each phase, we see Ruben strive to do everything in his power to regain and hold onto a life he's devoted to and loves. He learns to shift dependence on sound to dependence on sight. Eye imagery becomes dominant, and Ruben's expressions and visual focus enable us to take each step with Ruben as he has to undergo his illfated journey. He loses everything. His career, his girl, his home, his friends, his hearing. At the end of the film, he is standing alone in a strange place with no prospects. No hope. What will become of him? Will he be relegated to sitting alone in an environment stripped of anything recognizable, writing on a new blank page every day? Like the guide who trained him to adjust to his new handicap? This movie teaches us to have charity for those with handicaps and to be thankful for our blessings. Because but for the Grace of God, there go we. This movie is depressing but well done. I give it 5 of 5 stars. It's on Netflix.

reviews.review_title: A pleasant and emotional viewing experience
reviews.content: Sound of Metal is a uniquely enjoyable movie about a heavy metal drummer (played passionately by Riz Ahmed) instantaneously losing the one thing his livelihood depends on: his ability to hear. And while the direction of the story hereon is somewhat predictable, this doesn't hinder its impact and originality nor its ability to communicate a universally humble story of acceptance.

"It's not abnormal, living as deaf is normal", this is the point deciphered from the haranguing of Joe while he is in confronting Ruben. Ruben becomes deaf all of a sudden and doesn't want to be in that stage because of the music that he carries and also for the enamored to his girlfriend. So he just toned deaf peoples are handicapped and it as an illness but Joe clears this point that we stated in the first sentence. Sound of Metal is not only just about the problem of losing hearing capability it is far beyond the concept of sound and silence. For a musician, sound is important. Ruben cannot accept his decreasing variation of hearing ability so he wants to get it back through cochlear implantation. His only motive is to get back his hearing ability. But for this recovery, he is supposed to spend some days in a Deaf Community and indulges there. He goes through various lives of mute and deaf, experienced, and probably gets the position to learn their sign language. He just builds up a good relationship with the people there but his thriving to get back his hearing ability compulsive him to sell his kit and van. After the implantation, he goes to her girlfriend but there he realizes this artificial ability doesn't work on his way. He just leaves and throws away that device. This is the fragment about Darius Marder's Sound of Metal. In a simple way, the subject is so small but in actuality, the director finds a way to put something fresh here. It travels through the inner struggle of Ruben (the protagonist), his thrive and dedication to get back his hearing ability. The film also provides new learning to the audience also, about sign language. The most important thing about the movie is its sound design, that is for the film got its Academy Award. Both the director's point of view and the character's point of view leads the designers to design the sound. When it shows the profile close-up of Ruben, we hear in the way like Ruben. This kind of making projects a new technical perception and a good experience for the audience. And at the end, before the end credits showing up there is a silence longing for about 2 or 3 minutes was an absolute strategy of making and I appreciate that. Special mention for, Riz Ahmed and Paul Raci.

I truly feel that the main message of this film is YOU KEEP LIVING, it makes you meditate, Riz said that he hoped people would get inspired to learn sign language well Riz you inspired me and i know you inspired others too.Ruben looses and he does not accept it and that´s the first mistake.This movie makes you analize and appreciate life and YOU SHOULD SEE IT. I was expecting other thing but it did not disappointed me.I don´t believe this film will win best picture, it´s just not the academy taste and that´s what i like about the oscars, they give you great movies to add to your list and they might not give the award to the best but they introduce you to more cinema and i love that
one more thing riz you were outstanding.
Loved the guy's work. The silence, muffled sounds, how he could hear through the implants, when he couldn't before having them.

reviews.review_title: A solid movie worth your time
reviews.content: Having once been a professional musician I can't image the shock of losing my hearing. It would be like walking off a cliff. Riz Ahmed gave a great performance. In fact, the entire caste really delivered the goods. A classic story of tragedy -> denial -> acceptance.

At first glance, the movie is about the struggle of the main character to deal with his deafness while being a musician. In the end, it turns out his struggle was much larger than that - he has to deal with his desire to chase after something he cannot reach, be it romance, a music career, or a normal life. When fate seems to be so powerful that we can do nothing about it, should we accept it or try to fight it as much as we can? And at what point is trying good or simply an "addiction"?The movie leaves the ending open and I think that's the best way you can end it, because ultimately this is a question that no one can tell you the answer to.

Life before and life after - that is the question?Do we accept our fate or do we rail against it?Our protagonist rails against it, until suddenly, at the end, doesn't.He is successful, and along the way he meets deaf people who assist him in acceptance and growth. And he learns and grows with the experiences contained. Yet, he wants his old life back. And so he goes through the steps to do so. And yet when he succeeds and attains his previous life, he changes his mind and decides that deafness is perhaps, better?Quaint notion, that barely takes in the possibility that his past life may have changed too, and could adapt along with him. Like, you know, life does? Gives nobody a chance when all along his aim was to reunite with his supportive partner. Who is seemingly dismissed.Good acting but a let down in plot.Isn't life about change and recovery and growth? And if science is helping, why go back? We don't see anything of a past life to make the decision acceptable, other than a "cool" movie choice.Seems contrived.

Sound of Metal is a movie that starts with a feel of eternal silence. Riz Ahmed acting in the movie ages like a fine wine and you keep on connecting with his character. The way the story and the screenplay are written gives the film a big advantage of grasping the audience in the momentum of suspense. Director Darius Marder created a situation where every element of the film works in perfect harmony and pushes each other up to make the whole thing more relatable so that the audience can connect. The cinematography is as good as it can be for this film. The ending could have a little bit better. Overall it's a movie that can soothe your heart, or at least try to with all the potential it has to offer.

Sound of Metal is all so heartbreaking and heartwarming, it's very conflicting in its tone for me. Should I feel bad? Should I feel happy for Ruben?As of right now it's nominated for Best Sound and it one hundred percent deserves that award. The sound design on this is top notch and something i've never heard in a film before. The silence is deafening but the noise is more so.
Riz Ahmed has a stellar performance too, i'm really excited to see more from him in the future and wouldn't be mad if he won the Oscar for Best Actor.
I was enthralled in this film from minute one. Usually i'll be checking how much time I have left by the hour / hour and a half mark but I didn't check it once. I was totally in for the ride that was Rubens coping / rehabilitation as he learns to deal with his deafness and everything that comes along with it. I do, however, think this could've been maybe 10 minutes shorter.
But oh man that ending ... it leaves me wanting more, asking questions, and speculating on Rubens future ... but i'm also okay with not knowing anything at the same time.

At first description, this film may sound uninteresting....speed metal drummer starts going deaf. You can hear the reactions by non-metal fans: "Serves him right for making such noise!" But this film is much more than that. More than any film, with the possible exception of Children of a Lesser God, this one creates an incredible about of empathy and understanding towards those with hearing impediments. Ruben (Riz Ahmed) and his lead singer/girlfriend (Olivia Cooke - a long way from "Bates Motel") live in an RV that serves not only as their home, but their studio. They travel and perform and sign records, and this is their life, until Ruben starts losing his hearing. That begins an odyssey for the initially unsympathetic Ruben, which begins when a home for recovering drug addicts with hearing loss welcomes him. The movie could have spent more time explaining his girlfriend's history (she was a recovering heroin addict when she met Ruben and after he leaves her, it is hinted that she returned to using). But then again, this is Ruben's story, and it is ultimately believable and very touching. Ahmed may score an Oscar nomination and deserves it - it is a juicy role and he dives head first into it, much as JK Simmons did for Whiplash.
This movie makes me appreciate hearing so much.Beautiful piece.Surely this movie has an award for best sound.

First off I'm an old school metal fan so grunting like the singer's having a hard time giving birth doesn't work for me, I like the screamy stuff. Second off, even if you're a new school metal lover, you might like this if you can swallow the idea of this metal band only having 2 members. That'd be the groaning leading lady and the deaf drummer, no bassist, no lead, just wasn't even taken into consideration in the script.However if you don't mind that and you're after a simple movie about loss and adjusting to it, then sure this may be for you. Still, it's nothing we haven't seen before.
Perhaps my main complaint is that neither band member was remotely likeable, just arrogant fake rockers. Yikes. 2 stars.

I really liked this, enjoyed probably isn't the right word but it is very well made. It is simply to dramatic and sad to enjoy. The start and the end are really were this movie is the strongest. It starts by introducing the problem and the characters. The acting is excellent and really elevates the characters development to the next level. I don't think that the whole metal genre or drumming has any real reason to be in the movie. I think this could have worked just as well with a different music genre and/or instrument. The middle section, while still good, is just really slow and can get a bit boring. It's very sad to watch how the character reacts to the situation and is probably the most real part of the movie, but it all happens too slow. The ending, I thought was going to be a let down just because of how the movie was going, but I was surprised... I really really loved the ending, it was perfect. Very satisfying although it still makes me think on all that has happened, is in reality the ending really isn't that good of a turn out. Anyway a very strong drama, 8/10.

reviews.review_title: I've missed this kind of film

I learnt from it. Wish that I'd written this but I never could have, it's far too good, because I'd never have imagined it could've been executed as well as it was. All the actors are excellent but Riz Ahmed can do something better. Reminded me of the first film I saw him in, Shifty.So glad I watched this, it'll stick for a long while.

reviews.review_title: If you're a performer, please protect your hearing
reviews.content: "Sound of Metal" is directed by Darius Marder and it explores the tragic story of a rock drummer and recovering addict who begins experiencing hearing loss. I went into this film expecting a musical drama in the vein of "Whiplash" but there is very little music. Rather, it is a psychological drama that follows Reuben, our protagonist, as he comes to terms with his terrifying new reality.Riz Ahmed has been hit and miss for me since "Nightcrawler" but his performance in "Sound of Metal" is the best I've seen all year. As a musician, I could feel the turmoil he was experiencing as he pounded his drums to nothing but muffled tones. Not only is this a musicians's worst nightmare but as an addict, he lacks the mental capacity to cope with the situation and Ahmed conveys this to perfection. Olivia Cooke and Paul Raci were also fantastic in their supporting roles.The sound design in "Sound of Metal" plays a crucial role putting you inside Reuben's perspective and the technical team knocked it out of the park. It is haunting listening to his hearing deteriorate throughout the film. Often, the sound switches between a clear audio perspective to Reuben's and the juxtaposition is quite shocking. Their work enhances the emotional attachment to the character and absolutely deservers Oscar recognition.The only issue I have with the film is some of the pacing drags and often there are jumps in time that are not clearly identifiable. A better balance in plotting the story elements could have led to a more cohesive viewing experience but this is still one of the best films of the year. "Sound of Metal" is available on demand and it is a cautionary tale that is worth seeing for all of my live performing friends.Grade: A

Acting is great, story is decent. A real life drama about a drummer, Ruben, suddenly losing his hearing (happens but it's super rare and usually this just happens gradually, but I give the movie the benefit of the doubt) and needing to get grip about life without hearing. It's all shot pretty well, video editing is excellent. Riz is THE best actor for this with his wide eyes.However, for the most part of the movie it wants to believe that you MUST then join a deaf community to come to terms with your new disability. And I use this term lightly because the deaf community likes to think they are not disabled and just a minority - which is where the movie goes entirely wrong. Should you really cut yourself off from your previous life just to adapt to your new issue? I don't believe that to be true. Why not just do some online research "what to do when suddenly deaf" to find that there are help sites. Learn to use sign on your own, get someone to help - but just ditching your life, your phone, your job (how does he make money if not touring anymore?) seems ridiculous. Especially as it's obvious Ruben doesn't want it and that ever wise owl Joe who took him in should have seen that, and then later he gets super upset about him not being one of those "cult" members he is looking for to keep around.So even if that IS how it has to be, how long, and forever? Why? No real reason is given that one must inclusively stay in the community and be totally shut off the world - like a Native American preservation that doesn't want the world around it to exist. Once you learn sign and have accepting your hearing is gone you would think you can join the "evil" rest of the society that he doesn't seem to be allowed to communicate with. The entire "sit in a room and write" part seems totally useful apart from some kind of rage inducer that he could have done in his RV as well. Why not just read a book or something... Also home videos have these great SDH subtitles these days.Second problem is the total dismissal of the implants. For one they ARE covered by medical insurance so that's already total BS the movie throws at you. That means no need to sell off your life's belongings to afford it, plus his girlfriend could have easily asked for the money from her dad which isn't really addresses - but I suppose he's not a fan of him and wouldn't just fork over that kind of money. Anyhow, seeing that it would be free this point is moot.Continuing from that, the implants are seen as totally horrible, distorting sound and not being able to have a proper conversation if there are too many sounds going around the room. That's not true. And think about this: you are blind and given an implant but the implant give you only grey-scale view of the world - are you going to complain and just prefer to be blind? The movie makes it think that silence is better than than hearing "annoying noises". With that they also claim that Nate is totally surprised by how the implants work out - as if NOBODY would have told him about this but in actually there are extensive tests before the operation, numerous consultations to explain what the result will be like - nobody goes into a clinic and says "I'd like a metal arm because it won't break that quickly" and the staff will be like "sure thing" without explaining the downsides of it.Lastly I find the girlfriend super irritating. If she didn't enjoy her previous life with Ruben she should just tell him rather than always following his lead. I know it's a theme of the movie but that goes against any kind of female empowerment - speaking your own mind and just scratching your arms instead. It makes her look weak and pathetic. Also those eyebrows at the start look fiendish.

I didn't want to watch this, but I sat down and thought 15 min and I'm through. But the film reaches out and grabs ahold of the view and Riz Ahmed will not let go. This is one of the best performances of the year if not the best. He says more with his facial expressions than most actors say with compelling dialogue in an entire film. This is his film to say the least. The mood is diametrically opposite of WHIPLASH but every bit as powerful. I will definitely be watching this at least another one or two times.

reviews.review_title: The best film I've seen all year!
reviews.content: When I saw the trailer for Sound of Metal I knew it was a film that was going to be right up my alley. But this film ended up being so much more. It's thought provoking, beautiful, insightful. This film will make you take stock of your life and realize how special everything is. Riz Ahmed is amazing in this film and deserves an Academy Award! If you see one film all year see this film!

Exceeded my expectations! This was a great film with a unique story. Don't expect a film about metal, nor is this really a movie about music. Instead, it is a moving drama with excellent performances, especially by the lead actor.It left me wishing it was a bit longer to fully wrap up the ending (it was left a bit ambiguous), but it accomplished its aim of showing that the little moments in life hold so much value. Great message that was delivered through a great story.

reviews.review_title: Boring and predictable with a weak cast
reviews.content: First of all, the cast is pretty weak. You don't care about any of the characters. The story itself is nothing new. The Wrestler (2007) is a much better take on these problems. But of course it had Mickey Rourke. Here none of the actors can match his talent.
Deeply moving and just an all around fantastic film! Riz Ahmed did it again with another great performance! Can't wait to see what else he does in the future🙌🏼

Is it Oscar worthy? I'm not even sure, looking at the list of nominees it's pretty hard to tell what that even means any more.An oscar worthy performance from Riz Ahmed though.The movie could do with losing about 15 mins. It did feel like it was going off on a tangent in the last 30, but to be fair they brought it round.Would have worked better as a 3 episode tv mini series, but it was better than most movies that are released now.Fairly emotional at times and Ahmed really draws you in.

This movie hit me hard, I already knew what it was about, but if I didn't know, maybe it would have hit even harder, it's the first fiction film by director Darius Marder and he started very well, the whole story of the protagonist is distressing without forcing, the frustrations are completely shared and the film brought me into it like no other did in 2020, maybe seems too real, I found myself in this protagonist brilliantly played by Riz Ahmed, even though I have no relation to the subject, it brought me sadness, it made me thoughtful, a film like this deserves to be highlighted. And Paul Raci do the best supporting acting that I watched in 2020.
A subject that probably hasn't had enough mainstream coverage. Lead actor is truly excellent. Well done 🙏🏼
Unforgettable sound design. Makes you feel and live the conflict of the movie from the beginning to the end.

The way the director used different mics to give the viewer as sence of loosing your hearing i myself am 90 % deaf in my left ear i have never had much hearing in that side so to loose both would be a hard thing to over come!!! The less you go in knowing the better really great story i didnt like the ending but it didnt ruin it for me but i think i may for some sadly.
This movie was absolutely dreadful, Depressing, Never ending, Do not watch this movie, It's the most depressing movie I have seen in years.

reviews.review_title: Great representation of an overlooked group
reviews.content: In his directorial debut, Darius Marder addresses a subject to which Hollywood hardly pays any attention and which is also not given enough awareness in society. Sound of Metal tells the story of the young drummer Ruben, who is on tour with his girlfriend and pursuing his dream of becoming a musician. Of all things, this passion becomes Ruben's undoing when he suddenly loses most of his hearing. As a result, his life is no longer the same and he embarks on an adventure for which he is not really ready.Ruben is embodied by Riz Ahmed. He is the clear protagonist of the film and appears in every scene. His journey from a dreaming drummer who has the seemingly perfect life with his great love to a deaf depressive who wants to return to that life is fascinating to follow. Ahmed plays this complex character with great subtlety. But he can also boil up from 0 to 100 in some moments and give free rein to his feelings. His multi-faceted performance makes it easy to understand his situation and to sympathise with him. Ahmed totally captivates you and represents people who have suffered the same fate with a lot of dignity. Olivia Cooke, as Ruben's girlfriend Lou, only has a few scenes at the beginning and at the end. Still, it's enough time for Cooke to introduce us to her equally complicated character in a way that we can understand her as a relative. Another terrific performance is delivered by Paul Raci as Joe, Rubens' also deaf mentor. He runs an association for the deaf and acts as a sort of father to the members. He acts very calmly and emotionally, especially in the heart-warming dialogues with Ruben, though there is always a certain toughness and honesty in there. His chemistry with Ahmed is the highlight of the film. As a veteran who has long since come to terms with his situation, he sees himself in the newcomer and wants to show him that deafness is not a curse.Sound of Metal sends an enormously important message and is hopefully a wake-up call towards Hollywood. Over the 120-minute running time, it's clear that this film was a matter of heart for Marder and the ensemble. As a result, much of it lingers for days afterwards. This fact makes the film-experience all the more beautiful and real. Real is the word that best describes Sound of Metal. Every scene seems realistic and probably takes place in real life in exactly the same way. The slow, almost still pacing in the middle of the film can seem boring, but is very important for the film's authenticity. Sound of Metal is a film you have to see to get a slight insight into the life of this fundamental group of people.
I would have given this movie nine stars if Riz Ahmed's performance was the only asset to this movie. It is not. I hope it's not too unassuming to win Oscar attention.
Great sound design. The story of an irresponsible and entitled young couple who would be wasting the tax payers money. Average acting. Shallow screenplay. Could have been a good book.

Superb acting, great storyline. The character development is so well done that you feel invested and have so much compassion and empathy to all characters. But the thing they nailed with this movie was the great use of sound to let the audience experience what the main character is going through. Combined with his amazing acting, when soundtrack goes dull and muted to simulate the sudden hearing loss, you also experience the frustration, fear, and confusion that he is feeling. It was so very well done that the opening 15 min alone is worthy of your time.
Why did anyone think that this would be a great idea for a movie? Not for a mainstream audience? It's very niche! Performance was excellent but overall would not recommend
PLEASE if you are thinking of watching this film please watch with headphones or like me with Airpods. You truly won't regret it. It's kinda phenomenal

Sound of Metal is a powerful film, anchored by a powerhouse performance from Riz Ahmed and sturdy direction from first time filmmaker, Darius Marder.The film follows Ruben, a punk rock drummer, as he suddenly begins to go deaf. Ruben must struggle with his inner demons while trying to find meaning in his new inaudible world.Riz Ahmed, from Nightcrawler and Venom fame, is heart and soul of this film. He gives one of the best performances of the year as the toiling drummer. You can see the pain behind his eyes as he watches his dreams pass him by. The anger, the frustration, the hurt, never too far away as he deftly navigates emotionally complex scenes. Ahmed should be an instant lock for an academy award nomination for best actor.Director Darius Marder does a fantastic job keeping the film centered around Ruben's world. The camera never straying too far from him and keeping his face in focus even when he is not the fulcrum of the scene.Sound plays a huge part in fully understanding Ruben's journey and the sound mixing and design in this film is outstanding. Switching between muted audio and over exaggerated sounds, the mixing takes you in and out of what Ruben hears. Besides diegetic music at the beginning of the film, there is score and it helps immerse the audience even more in the deaf community.The third act struggles to be as important as the first two and film slows down a bit. It feels almost out of left field with a new location, new characters and new story direction. It is, however, just a minor blip on a fantastic film and one of the year's best.

Unique storyline with such a deep meaning behind it. The movie starts off with the main character being a bit rough and hard to sympathize with, but as the movie goes on it's easier to relate to his struggles.

As cheesy as it sounds, after watching this film I felt stunned with emotions of heartache, beauty, and hope. you know a piece of art is great when you think "I wish I could have made that!"-
You know it's a masterpiece when you're just perfectly thankful and content that it exists as is.
Like seeing a couple where you think "aww she's too good for him, I bet we'd be happier if she were with me". But then sometimes you see a couple that seems so happy and connected and right for each other that you're just happy for them and wouldn't dare try to come between them. Watching this film felt like seeing that couple. It reminds you of your own lonliness and past failures, but it also reminds you of how much beauty and love is in the world.I'm not an overly sentimental guy, but this movie just put me in that headspace. Cianfrance is one of my favorite working filmmakers, but the fact that this is a first feature for directer/co-writer Darius Marder is incredible- I'm so excited to see what he does in the future. And of course Riz Ahmed is astounding, he really just nails this one so hard it's incredible to watch. Olivia Cook was great as well, truly believable in her dual personalities. And it was a nice treat seeing Mathieu Amalric pop up unexpectedly.As a musician who spent a lot of time playing in bands, as well as a recovering addict/alcoholic, maybe this film was just tailored for me personally, but I haven't been hit this hard by a film in a long time.

Sound Of Metal is a drama film released in 2020 distributed by Prime Video and directed by Darius Marder.First, it is essential that the film is watched at a very high volume and in total silence, because, due to the protagonist being deaf, the feature focuses a lot on the noises and sounds around him.
Sound editing is great and gives a very realistic tone to the story, there are times when you get a little distressed by not hearing or understanding some things, and this is great, because it makes the viewer feel like the character. In fact, speaking of the protagonist, he is one of the best things in the film, without a doubt it is the best work of Riz Ahmed's career and can even earn him an Oscar nomination, all the characters are very well developed, with the character of Olivia Cooke , who plays the girlfriend of the main character, the actress is very well in the role, but she is not as well worked as the others, in the third act they even try to give her a greater depth, but nothing much. The film's photography is good, it has very beautiful plans and the director knows what he's doing. The feature also braces with some comic reliefs that work well, help to lighten the film a little. After all, it is very pleasant to follow the character's trajectory, you really care and support him a lot.I think the third act is a little less than the first two, it is good, of course, but not as good as the others, but the film gets it right at the perfect moment, the final message is very good.
" How can you label me as a winner or a looser when I decide not to be in the game anymore."

A great movie to use for substance abuse facilities and hearing impaired facilities. The ending sucked but it opened up for a sequel. I was hoping Ruben returned to the program where he left just to help out. All in all it was a excellent movie.

Just watched Sound of Metal and i'm in tears, beautiful is an understatement.I'm genuinely speechless as to how incredible, scary, and beautiful this film is: from the acting to the storyline.Being put in Ruben's perspective and hearing what he hears sent chills down my spine, i had goosebumps.This movie is about acceptance and that's what i loved:
learning to make good things out of bad situations.When i heard about this film i for some reason thought it would be similar to Whiplash (one of my favourites) but it wasn't, again like i said, the film is about acceptance and is a life lesson for the spectators.An absolutely stunning film, supported by an incredible plot and phenomemal acting.

We sometimes think this/that solution is the best, but it isn't. The movie reminds me of myself when I was used to in the same situation as the character even I'm not deaf, but my back is scoliosis. I don't accept the truth that I need to spend more time on taking care my back. I shouldn't carry things too much heavy to protect my back, or sit many hours without breaking and listen to my body more when my health is diminished due to my weak back. The more I try to do normally, the more my back get hurt, making me feel terribly exhausted. Then, I finally need to accept the truth and do more healthily for myself, especially my back unless wanting to stop with what I'm currently following. The movie exactly describes the confusing and hopeless feeling when you have to encounter one of the most obstacles in life. Importantly, whatever many obstacles take place we should ACCEPT it first and mindfully battle with it. It's easy to talk, but it's super difficult when you have to ACCEPT some terrible things happening in our life.

reviews.review_title: Riz Ahmed likely won't be heard by Hollywood.
reviews.content: This guy turns in an amazing performance and as such, he should be playing really interesting parts like this in the future. He rocks in this. Unfortunately, Hollywood is so full of twisted, depraved and idiotic people on the buisiness side that they'll simply attempt to get him to take the terrorist roles instead. My advice to Riz: march to the beat of your own drum!

To transport you to a different reality, a reality that affect so many people requires perspective and understanding. This is where Sound of Metal excels, and its thanks to the brilliance of Riz Ahmed. He truly is one of the best actors going around today and we are blessed to witness it.Reuben Stone a drummer of his Girlfriend Lou's (Olivia Cooke) metal band realises he's quickly losing his hearing. Frightened and angered about his future Reuben wants a quick and expensive fix. He meets Joe (Paul Raci) whom owns a ranch that helps deaf people fit into their new reality. Here Reuben adjusts and understands his new life.There may be a few distorted facts around the waiting and avenues of obtaining Cochlear implants, but really that's a minor issue to what is a great film.

Riz Ahmed is exceptional in this film, and truly gives a fantastic performance as this drummer and recovering addict named Ruben. Additionally, I thought that the hearing loss element was shown in the film very creatively, and that the deaf community was portrayed in a very sensitive and respectful manner that made me really empathize with all of them. That being said, it wasn't enough for me to get past the 65 minute mark.I was gripped as soon as Ruben's hearing went out, and I was intrigued to see how his life would transform because of this. However, the movie just turns into a series of events in which Ruben is incredibly angry and frustrated with what's going on, and it becomes incredibly dull. No opponents, no desires being pursued (apart from him wanting to buy hearing aids, which is more of an abstract idea and something he didn't really have a plan for, from what I saw). Maybe I missed some stuff. I fell asleep three different times, then decided to turn it off with 40 minutes left to go.The cinematography is fine. The sound design is great. The acting is great. However, the movie really lacks an interesting story and interesting revelations. Maybe it picks up in the last 40 minutes, I don't know. Honestly I was so bored by it I'm not really inclined to find out. Riz Ahmed killed it though, so major props to him. I will definitely be looking out for his performances down the road.4/10.

The movie goes in its own pace, taking into the consideration of each part of life, explores the reality of failure and something not going your way in life and with the acting of Riz Ahmed, and his expressions, he makes you feel the pain and agony he goes through.
The agony that everyone goes through of screwing up in life again and again, and picking yourself up, and one day you finally learn with all the lessons.

reviews.review_title: Impeccable sound mixing & Riz Ahmed's soulful performance makes it a must watch
reviews.content: It's a unique experience watching this movie thanks to the impeccable sound design. Riz Ahmed is at his best in this tale of self discovery. The variation in sound mixing let us viewers to feel what Ruben was going through. Kudos to the director, fantastic debut.
What an amazing movie. Impeccable performances, beautifully written script, magnificent direction, and exceptional sound mixing.

This was an excellent movie and one which really makes you appreciate being able to hear and gives you the respect for those people who are deaf. I really liked how they told the story and how it all unfolded in the end. It made me really understand the difficulties of someone losing their hearing and what they go through and what it is like to be in their shoes. Very enjoyable movie, sad, but enjoyable.

Not only is this a great movie in reflecting the psychological difficulties of hearing loss, it can be taken into consideration to all people struggling with some sort of mental issue. The dedication Riz Ahmed showed to the role as well as his character did in the story can be very inspiring.
-SPOILERS FROM THIS POINT FORWARD-
It would also be worth noting the amazing directorial details like the fact that for the first part of him going deaf we have no subtitles, allowing us to merge with Ruben's mind and see the things he sees, we can't know what they're saying because neither does he, the exact moment we see him signing for the first time we get subtitles and now we're all part of the community and understanding each other.
The fact that he achieved what he was hoping for and it didn't really turn out the way he thought it would also gives a very realistic view on the problem, the relationship between him and Lulu was a nice touch as well, he did it mostly for her but even though she still loves and cares for him, she can never tell him that she's just not into it anymore, Ahmed's facial acting shows us clearly that he has figured it out from long ago and is in denial for a while up to the point he takes the big leap and decides to make the move and tell her that "It's okay" and move on.
Overall, great acting, great writting, great directing. One of my favourites this year.
Beautifully shot and directed. Simple movie with excellent actors. I can't recommend it enough!

reviews.review_title: A beautiful tale full of empathy and love with one of the best leading performances
reviews.content: Imagine losing that one thing from your life that drives your passion and also supports your livelihood. You will be devastated and embittered by how life has treated you unfairly. This is exactly how Ruben (Riz Ahmed) feels when he starts losing his ability to hear. Sound of Metal is a 2019 American drama directed and co-written by Darius Marder which tells us about a heavy-metal drummer named Ruben who is one half of the metal duo Blackgammon along with the singer, his girlfriend, Lou (Olivia Cooke). His life starts going into diasarray when he starts losing his hearing ability. To overcome his hearing problems, Riz seeks help from a place for deaf recovering addicts. This movie is thought provoking and displays a plethora of emotions. It gives us a sweet message of embracing our imperfections and living a lovely life along with them. Riz Ahmed delivers his career's best performance and should definitely get an oscar nomination for this spectacular performance. Paul Raci also deserves a great credit in supporting Riz Ahmed with his role as the person who runs the rural community from which Ruben seeks help from. Go watch this movie to see one of the best lead performances of last year along with a moving and heart aching story.

Well made movie. My ratings are Horrible (1 star), Bad (2-4 stars), Mediocre (5-6 stars), Good - Very Good (7-8 stars), Excellent (8-9 stars)This was a nice story that was very well acted by the three main actors. Loved the deaf community and that entire part. Paul was fantastic.The backstory at the end felt a bit tacked on but not enough to make the move unenjoyable. Would've been nice to see Ruben return to Paul or perhaps we are to assume that happened anyway?The movie was better than I imagined it would be. Recommend seeing it.

reviews.review_title: Imperfect, but a powerful story and great performance.
reviews.content: Sound of Metal is a very powerful story. A young musician loses his hearing. Completely. No, not like Beethoven. It wasn't a mysterious ailment, but most likely years of daily heavy metal abuse, even if the doctor tactfully allows for a possibility of the former. And Ruben (Riz Ahmed) ain't no Beethoven by any stretch of imagination. The movie lets us hear what Ruben hears and it is most effective in those moments. There are rich elements added, such as the fact that the place Ruben finds himself at is a sort of halfway house for deaf addicts, which he also is. There's a big question about people choosing to live deaf. And at its core the movie is a sweet love story.I think it would have been better if the filmmakers allowed us to stay in Ruben's head and thus in silence instead of rather arbitrarily switching back to sound. The addiction part is glossed over. I would imagine a catastrophic, life altering event could spell double the catastrophe for an addict. The big question is never really addressed. And there was something about that love that just didn't feel strong enough. Both Ahmed and Olivia Cooke who plays his girlfriend are excellent actors, but something is missing. I don't usually judge chemistry or lack thereof, as it is such an hazy concept, but I can't think of any other explanation.In spite of shortcomings the movie ultimately works - on the strength of the story and Riz Ahmed's quietly anguished performance and magnetic screen presence.

reviews.review_title: Riz Ahmed Tour De Force In Acting
reviews.content: Watch this film. It is so genuinely good and Riz Ahmed is so phenomenal that you should watch the film just for him and him alone.

A great movie about something we take for granted. Just losing one of your senses like your hearing. Im work with music just as the main character and I don't know what I would do without being able to work with whats most important for me. Losing my hearing like this would break me. This is about a struggle to find something else in life from the only thing you thought you would do. This movie got under my skin and it's not lot's of movie's that dose that to me. That's why I'm giving this movie a full score! Great characters and story telling and loved the sound mixing it made this movie real.

reviews.review_title: A Flawed Gem Well Worth a View
reviews.content: The stellar performance by Riz Ahmed, along with sound design of such high caliber that it serves as his co-star, have rightly won much acclaim. The first two acts are compelling, as we see and hear Ruben's sudden and profound hearing loss before following him to a sober house and school for the deaf. His "owl eyes" take in all they can as Ruben tries to compensate for the new and challenging silence.Once Ruben raises the money for cochlear implants, the script lurches forward burdened by some heavy-handed messaging and a woefully underwritten Lou. Olivia Cooke, so captivating on stage and in the RV, is reduced playing a plot device, as Lou's character development is not a priority. This is a missed opportunity, as Ahmed and Cooke are so good together in the early scenes.Recommended despite the limitations of plot and character development, Sound of Metal has so much going for it that it is a shame more care wasn't taken with Lou. This and the anti-implant theme mar what is often a riveting film.

I have no words for the beauty that I just witnessed. Everything from the cast, sceneries, story, Riz Ahmeds stellar acting, music, everything about this movie is heartbreakingly beautiful. Happy tears fell from my eyes at the end. Wow to the hard work and determination in making this movie that was such a rough process. I am glad that Darius chose Riz over the original cast of Dakota Johnson and Matthias Schoenaerts. Riz and Olivia owned their roles. Masterpiece.

As a metal fan, this film doesn't represent the music as much as i expected, i mean...the music that the nand is supossed to play ain't really good. But that doesn't matter, and maybe that adds to the plot, which make for a pretty solid drama.

Solid. Staggering performance by Riz Ahmed (aka Elias Rahim, obviously). Amazing camera work, art direction. Sound design and mixing are on another level. Somewhat educational too. "And how's the drummer? - The drummer is 'fein'..."
Watch and learn. And turn your volume down for Christ's sake!
7.5/10 from me.

reviews.review_title: Remake of Its All Gone Pete Tong
reviews.content: Lovely film no doubt. But watch the original first. Paul Kaye is superb in it and as much as I like Riz Ahmed (if you havent watched The Night Of, shame on you, its is astounding) the original cannot be beat.

Riz Ahmed delivers the best performance of his career in this emotional and powerful film about a man who has to come to terms with a change in his life. It's captivating, it's realistic, it grabs you and never lets you go. If I was on the Academy, this definitely would've had my vote for Best Picture.
Welp I'm depressed. Seriously tho, do you want to be depressed for 2 hours of your life ? If yes go ahead and watch this movie, you'll love it.

....the scenario surrounding the cochlear implants. The doctor, the appointment, the surgery just happened too fast and too easily. I couldn't see how/where he got the money. But otherwise, what a phenomenal film. And what a stellar and powerful portrayal of Ruben by the lead actor. The sound editing was brilliant, switching from actual noise to Ruben's hearing. Just brilliant.

reviews.review_title: On Par With An After School Special
reviews.content: This movie was like a really good ABC After School Special. You remember those films that featured a theme like "say no to drugs." But even that particular special where the girl high on pcp jumps out of the second story window of her high school English class was better than this movie.Sound of Music is not transcendent or enlightening. It was essentially a remake of Helen Keller but not as good.The switching back and forth between hearing and silence was cool but not very gripping much like the plot which was thin.

reviews.review_title: An attempt at understanding deafened people but failed.
reviews.content: Deafened people are hearing people with no ties to deaf people, and in a short space of time, a hearing person could lose all their ability to hear. Such the only solution is a cochlear implant (CI) or two. After that a deafened person would, for intent and purpose, become partially hearing. It is rare for a deafened person to interact with the deaf community, or learn sign language, since they are not solutions.The idea that one would sell everything to buy 2 CIs for $40,000 to $80,000 without researching for a lower price is stupid. Surgery center of Oklahoma does CI $10,510 each making the total of $21,020.As for the rest of the movie it was slow, mind numbing, boring with average acting.Watch Coda which is miles better in every way.

reviews.review_title: It's important to have a good ending
reviews.content: The ending was bad, and it made all the depressing things that happen throughout the movie pretty pointless. The rest of the movie has nice moments where the main character learns to accept being deaf, but the whole movie is overall very bleak and boring. Also the final scene is incredibly predictable.Edit: This is just one of those trendy oscar bait movies that are popular for one year and then nobody ever talks about them ever again. Sorry if it's your favorite movie, but it's mediocre.

reviews.review_title: The isolation and quietude of hearing loss
reviews.content: "Sound of Metal" is the tragedy of Ruben (whose hearing is a casualty of his love of music) and his girlfriend, Lou. It gives a unique insight into the sensory experience of sudden and pervasive hearing loss. It chronicles the catastrophe of his disorder's onset, and his attempt at adapting to his new condition through a deafness support community. The reaction shots, closeups, space, and acting are extraordinarily good. As film is a medium of sound and vision, we get to - in a sense (no pun intended) - experience the isolation and quietude of hearing loss first-hand.

Going into this movie, I knew I was going to bawl my eyes out and I freakin' did. This is an amazing, heart-wrenching film.This movie is also very educational for people regarding the deaf community. The sound design is brilliant, it helps the audience empathize more with the character.Best thing about the movie are the characters, Ruben and Lou. First of all, the actors have amazing chemistry and you could feel the sincerity of their performances. They perfectly portray how people who love each other could still heal even without being together, it might even be the best and healthiest way. I think that's a really great takeaway from the movie.

Sound of metal. Today, we will talk about that film. First of all, This movie is based on drama/music. Metal drummer Ruben begins to lose his hearing. Ruben thinks his career and life are over when a doctor says his condition will worsen. To keep him off drugs and adapting to his new life, her boyfriend Lou contacts a former addict about deaf rehabilitation. After being accepted there, Ruben is forced to choose between two lives. The progression of the story is steady and feels profoundly sensible, which kept me completely secured on the characters and pondering where the plot was going straightaway. With Riz Ahmed's character at the focal point of the film, he flaunts some top-level acting while at the same time depicting the crude feelings that Ruben is going through, causing the crowd to feel all of outrage, dissatisfaction, and different feelings on this rough street on the way to endorsement of his hearing misfortune. The topic of acknowledgment is the place where the film truly dominated since it hammers home that being hard of hearing isn't an issue by any means, it is our musings about it, wherein lies the genuine issue. The main thrust of this incredible message surely must be Joe (played by Paul Raci), who is an instructor at the hard of hearing local area that Ruben joins. His quiet, gathered, and relieving persona furnishes the film with the ideal guide for both Ruben and anybody watching the film on the way to edification. Changing the way that Ruben considers his 'issue', was the lone answer for tracking down his inward tranquility, and relinquishing every one of the negative feelings he was managing. With these all inferences, My review is 9/10.
Makes you think, makes you feel....makes you wonder about the simple things we take for granted.

reviews.review_title: A must see Oscar buzz movie with unique sound direction about a musician going deaf
reviews.content: "Sound of Metal" focuses on a drummer Ruben, whose entire existence revolves around music, and by going deaf his losing that which defines his life. The movie focuses on the destructive nature and high cost of self-deception in the face of hard truths. Riz Ahmed in the leading role is wonderful, with his struggle to find meaning and peace in chaos. The most unique about this is the sound direction. It goes from pounding in-your-face metal music through the muffled reality as Ruben loses his hearing to the sense of peace in the moments of silence. It sounds best when it is quiet, but shines bright from start to finish.

First of all, it's not a movie about music. It's all about hearing and psychology. That's why, the name and the poster of the movie is a bit misleading the audience as many people said after watching it.The storytelling is quite boring and disturbing in many ways and you even don't want to keep watching this movie while watching some scenes.So, the narrative has an absolutely disturbing vibe from start to finish. Also, we did not get any clear message in the end of the film, it was very predictable.Despite this, the acting was really great. reviews.review_title: Much more than just "a film about the deaf".
reviews.content:
Oscar nominations prediction:
(5) Picture; Leading Actor (Riz Ahmed); Supporting Actor (Paul Raci); Original Screenplay (crazily enough); Sound.If you liked:
The Great Gatsby
La La Land
Stronger"Sound of Metal" (2020) is one of the best films I've seen this year. Ruben, a young drummer (Riz Ahmed) plays heavy-metal in a band of two, with his girlfriend Lou. His life revolves around the love for music and the love for Lou. They have a somewhat peculiar, but genuine and sweet relationship, and even though their gypsy-like trailer life seems chaotic; he feels happy and at piece.
Then something happens to Ruben. He doesn't just start to gradually lose his hearing; he goes almost completely deaf at a snap of a finger for an unclear reason. He bargains, he gets angry; but just like that his whole vision of life, the idea of where it's headed and how he manages it has to change radically. We focus on someone, whose entire existence revolves around a world of sound, lose that which defines his life; a change so sudden and radical, it seems impossible to adapt to. An entire Lost Generation in one man. Still hoping to immediately get himself an operation to put implants in, he goes to live with a "deaf community" for a while, trying to re-learn how to function in a society in these new circumstances. And this is where the magic begins.
He arrives at the house at around 20 min mark into the film, and for about 40 minutes there isn't a single word spoken. The film turns into a fully visual experience as we gradually get subtitles the more sign language Ruben begins to understand (don't forget to turn on the subtitles!). For the most of the time, we acoustically perceive the world as Ruben perceives it: distorted, muffled sounds; I've never heard it done like that in such detail in a movie before, hence the Oscar nom for Sound. With Ruben, we get to know a whole other universe that's always out there and that we are rarely ever aware of. It is incredibly interesting to see all the unusual ways humans can interact with each other. And I have to give credit to the incredible determinations of Riz Ahmed preparing for this role: he spent 6 months learning the drums and he learned American Sign Language specifically for this film. Initially, to immerse himself in the deaf culture, he wore auditory blockers deep inside his ear canal that emitted white noise so that he couldn't hear even the sound of his own voice; and after some time, he decided to forego the blockers and simply communicated with the director and deaf cast almost exclusively through sign language. All of that contributed to his spot-on, subtle performance, and he truly deserves an Oscar nomination as well. Already at that point of the film I was going to give it an 8/10; but it got even better.
I would have to give up the ending to explain why, but I will say this: the movie turns into as close of a modern version of "The Great Gatsby" as it gets. It is a deeply, profoundly sad film that I keep thinking about more and more long after I finished it. It is much more than just "a film about the deaf".

Riz Ahmed, Olivia Cooke, and Paul Raci feature in the drama Sound of Metal, which was directed by Darius Marder and is directed by Marder as well. The protagonist of the movie is Ruben, played by Ahmed, a heavy metal drummer who has a loss of hearing and must learn to adapt to his new environment.Cooke is just as great in her role as Ruben's fiancée Lou as Ahmed is in his role as Ruben, which is a dramatic and heartbreaking performance. Raci is particularly outstanding in his role as Joe, a recovered addict and former drummer who assists Ruben in adjusting to life in a community of deaf people. Both the cinematography, which was done by Daniel Bouquet and the soundtrack, which was written by Abraham Marder and Nicholas Britell, are really impressive.The examination of themes such as identity and community, as well as the transformational effect of grief, are what really set this movie apart from others. The screenplay, written by Marder and Abraham Marder, is powerful and well-written, and it encourages the audience to reflect on the ways in which we identify ourselves as individuals as well as the role that community plays in our everyday lives.Sound of Metal is a noteworthy picture that is heightened by its outstanding acting, breathtaking photography, and thought-provoking narrative. Overall, the film is a highlight. It is an absolute need to see for everyone who enjoys dramatic works or is searching for a movie that may stir both emotion and mind.

reviews.review_title: What the movie says:- ACCEPT, FORGET AND MOVE ON
reviews.content: The story of the film is about a drummer(Ruben) who works with his girlfriend(Lou) who is the lead vocal in the band of two of them, ruben's ears got damaged to a point in which he can't hear anything anymore due to extremely loud noise the drums creates when he plays it.This film is telling viewers to accept whatever comes in their life, forget it and move on.Riz Ahmed's performance as Ruben Stone is so good, his emotions are solid, we can identify the emotions just by looking at his eyes, he successfully depicted the situations of frustration and stress of Ruben Stone as a deaf man. The sound design is another major area in this film. It is done so wonderfully that it was well done in terms of depicting the situations of deafness.Well-worthy of your time... Recommending...

I've recently become familiar with the actor Riz from watching Encounters. He was so amazing that I decided to see what else he's done. So of course I had to check out the movie that landed him an Oscar nom.This movie didn't disappoint at all with regards to acting. Absolutely great performance by Riz and the entire case honestly. Riz so masterful in scenes where he doesn't even have lines. He emotes so well with his facial and eye movements. The actor who played Joe also deserves a mention. I thought he gave a lot in the little screen time he had, especially his last scene which had me on the verge of tears.I loved the plot of a person becoming hearing impaired and their journey with coping and life after. My mom is blind, but wasn't born that way. So I have some familiarity with living/loving someone with a disability.I thought the script was good even while minimal. And giving us just enough of a love story without being too soapy or cliche was sooo appreciated. It may have even elevated the movie leaving all that out.The sound engineering was spectacular because it gave the audience a glimpse into the distorted sounds and even complete silence that a deaf person would experience. Many times throughout the movie, this coupled with Riz's performance brought me into these moments of intense frustration and mental anguish that as Ruben battled while trying to communicate with people.My only critiques of the movie is regarding the character development, some plot holes and pacing.For a movie this long, there was a lot that felt rushed, especially in the second half of the movie. Perhaps too much time was spent on overused and mundane scenes in the beginning... the couple laying around or just eating. Conversely, the transition from acclimating with the deaf community to the ear surgery seemed so sudden and rushed. I had to rewind the movie because I felt like I had missed something.We also have no idea of timelines. So this too gives off a feeling of being rushed towards the second half of the movie. How long was he in the retreat? We have no idea how he amassed $80k for the surgery while at the retreat. Sure musical equipment is expensive, but he absolutely didn't have $80k worth in that RV. Additionally, he has the $80k for the surgery but not $3k to get his RV back? He can't afford to stay with Joe, but he has enough money to stay at a hotel for 3-4 weeks until his earring activated? Also, later in the movie we find out the girlfriend is basically a rich kid who intentionally likes living the poor struggle bus lifestyle. If she truly loved him, why didn't she ask her dad to help pay for his surgery until their career aspirations afford them enough to pay him back? There is just so much not tied up with this. And you can say that I'm nitpicking, but these issues for me hurt the cohesion and believability a the story.We are also robbed a little of Lou's transformation. Sure the movie isn't about her, but she's a critical person in Ruben's life. So maybe a scene or two to give us more on her journey. We see her as this high strung anxious disheveled person (who self harms) in the beginning, to this balanced well presented woman in the end. So was Ruben her issue, and getting away from him allowed her to heal? Was she on drugs and got clean? Her dad mentions that she's better, but never truly says how/why. I'm ok with leaving it up to the audience to figure out, but I would have liked this tied up a bit better.I also felt the movie rushed Ruben's realization that his past life with Lou and music was no more. Riz did amazing so it's not his fault. I'm thinking it's the writing and directing of those last several scenes that make it feel too sudden to be believable. This is a man who spent all that time (lol well it could have been a couple weeks or couple of years; we have no idea) at the retreat bonding with everyone, especially the children. He abruptly abandons them for the hope of regaining his hearing and reclaiming his previous career momentum with the love of his life. Then he suddenly abandons all of that after one night with Lou? Was it one night? We have no idea! I get the overall arc, but it could have been done so beautifully with the appropriate pacing.I did like that tender moment in the end where he removes his hearing device, but again it felt rushed. To give you an example of what I mean: At the end of Forest Gump after little Forest gets on the bus, we are left with this very sentimental, beautiful moment of clarity and peace with Forest just sitting there waiting for his son to return, as the feather from the opening scene floats away. The director allowed the scene to breath. The ending of Sound of Metal could've had this, and I think it tried to have something like it. Instead we got too much time of them laying around eating eggs and this critical scene was over so quickly.Overall it was a great movie in-spite of my issues with it. I will definitely watch it again.

reviews.review_title: Some of the best immersive storytelling I've seen.

reviews.review_title: Superb+ Moving wonderful acting by Ahmed-and everyone else

(3) I was incredulous that the two of them did not communicate more during Ruben's stay at the house or that letters would not have been allowed.Enough of the negative though!I am glad this highlighted the deaf community and I thought the people who played the residents, teacher, student, and director there were great.In the end, this is relatable and moving on so many levels: the loss of identity and a way of life, the pain of feeling different, and the struggle to create a new life. reviews.review_title: Weird woke messaging, no character dev
reviews.content: It's like this movie assumes you have a connection or understanding of the characters already to start off with, so it doesn't bother to develop one for the viewer. I like slow - but this is slow with no reward. Bizarre messaging that shames a man - a musician - who loses his hearing suddenly and severely - when he pursues quality-of-life improving medical treatment. He gets rejected from his small support deaf community for pursuing surgery? Because he came up with the funds and it was a good option in his case? Stunned by all the accolades for this film - for one, it should have been a short film if they weren't going to bother to build nuance and complexity in the few main characters, and second, pursuing a medical treatment that may be right for you doesn't make someone 'ableist' which is what is implied.

TSOM is a study in the adaptability of the human race. Presented in a stark, realistic manner, this movie gives us a glimpse of one man's journey from deafness to the overwhelming world of sound and back again. Where the movie fails in the slightest manner is how the journey unfolds in some not so believable ways. For example, it makes getting cochlear implants about on the same level as getting mini-dental implants. W/o real knowledge of this procedure, I'm guessing it is a lot more complicated and drawn out than this movie makes it seem. The cast is outstanding with just enough nuance without becoming maudlin. The sound editing verges on the spectacular. You may never again think of sound in the same way after seeing this movie. If you don't mind diving into an experience that on some level may make you feel uncomfortable, then this is a few hours well spent.

In an age of yet-another-reboot, I deeply appreciate this poignant and thoughtful journey. Not everything is spelled out and dumbed down, which allows the viewer to more fully engage and be truly transported. The story is gritty and full of gaps and that's just how life is. There are layers upon layers here and I can tell this won't be leaving me for a long, long time.The "metal" part of "sound of metal" transformed meaning from the heavy metal musical genre into the metallic scraping Ruben heard in his head after the implants. And that's just one example of the beautiful tapestry found here. Thank you for this work of art. It is a treasure.

A worthy addition to the growing list of films about the deaf and deaf culture. Here, a heavy metal drummer named Ruben loses his hearing and embarks on what begins as a very sad and very lonely journey: to a deaf community out in the wilderness, to ear specialists...but mostly, to the innermost regions of his soul. Should he join the community (he's more than welcome), or (big leap of faith) try to resume his career and release that album he's been talking about? (He hopes to pick up his musical cues from the lead singer, who also happens to be his girlfriend; a tall order, to be sure.) Or should he agree to that cochlear implant he's been told to get? And if he does, how will he ever be able to afford it? (According to one doc, the surgery would cost $40,000-$80,000.) The film charts his successes (and failures) as he claws his way from one stage of his new reality to the next. As Ruben, Riz Ahmed is frustrated in some scenes, triumphant in others, often as raw as a freshly-opened wound, and always wholly present; his large, expressive eyes speak volumes. Olivia Cooke as his girlfriend Lou, and Paul Raci as Joe, his warm but no-nonsense mentor, are also terrific. Chalk this one up as yet another of the subtle, heartbreaking, and never-less-than-watchable dramas earning praise this year. It's well-deserved.
