reviews.review_title: Very good but I feel like it could have been even better
reviews.content: Overall this was a very good movie. There are two things I'd like to highlight on the positive side: Ahmed's acting and the way the sound was edited, which makes you experience the same feelings the character feels. These points really elevated the movie to a different level. However, I believe that the ending felt a little too rushed and that it could have been better with just some 10-15 more minutes.

A few movies have made me feel this way. I had initially thought it would be just another motivational story with a protagonist who beats all odds and makes it big in the industry and gets the girl in the end. I knew the loaded gun of the implant surgery would be fired eventually but it was a bit unexpected to see how that fit into the story.The plot was deceiving as it had me initially convinced that Ruben would get the surgery done and would get his life back together and meet Lou. When the surgery was unsuccessful I was still convinced that it would all get well and Ruben would get his hearing back, and maybe he would have some romantic problems with Lou in the end. It wasn't until the last few minutes of the movie that I realised it was never about Ruben getting his hearing back but it was about him, an agitated and disgruntled person finding peace in the cacophony of life.The movie sends a very powerful message and I loved the connotations and symbolisms. The plot developed so subtly that when the sound of silence engulfs Ruben's world and he looks up to the sun with the two lines of clouds making it seem like someone was watching him from above, it all came together so well. The ending was amazing as it showed nothing unrealistic. The story seemed believable and real and I love the way they tried to keep it that way consistently throughout the different phases of the movie with different sets of people.The acting was great, the portrayal of the lives of people in the movie was well executed. The way the realities of different people of different backgrounds was exposed makes one feel privileged about what they have, and respect toward the people that don't. The execution of showing that perspective was great if not flawless.

I've had a moderate hearing loss my whole life, so I'm used to straddling the hearing world and deafness, without having the benefit of the deaf community portrayed in this movie. Therefore, I understand some, but not all of Ruben's struggles. Most importantly, I understand the difference between hearing music with my ears and hearing music through hearing aids, and there is really no comparison. I always take my hearing aids out to enjoy music, and whenever I have no need to listen to people talk. They are necessary tools, but they are kind of awful.For a musician, or anyone for whom music is a central joy in life, hearing loss is an absolute tragedy. I have often thought how grateful I am that at least I can hear music, even if I miss some of the sounds involved, and the idea of never ever hearing music again is unthinkable. And this is what Sound of Metal explores - how hard it is to accept that loss and conceive of another way forward. I loved that in the beginning, it is made clear how much Ruben loves all music, dancing to delta blues and singing to classic soft rock in the space between his and Lou's passionate metal performances. Ruben and Lou's relationship was also quite beautiful to behold.The only drawback to the immersive experience of hearing loss is not acknowledging that he can still communicate through text messaging and chat. Also, Joe's reaction to Ruben's decision I thought required a bit more exploration of the reasons and consequences.The acting by all was superb, and the soundscape was excellent and effective.

reviews.review_title: An Inspiring Story Promoting Inclusivity in the Film Industry
reviews.content: Ian and I are continuing our effort to watch every Best Picture nominee for the upcoming Academy Awards, and this week we watched Sound of Metal. This was a film that had been on my radar - albeit as a lower priority - for a couple of months now. Riz Ahmed first caught my attention back in my freshman year at Purdue, when I watched Four Lions (2010) - an incredibly underrated black comedy film about a group of amateur terrorists in England. He also had a notable role in the excellent film Nightcrawler (2014), for which he received well-deserved attention alongside co-star Jake Gyllenhaal. I was excited to see what he would do next, but was nervous after seeing him get rolled into minor, forgettable roles in the franchise-driven blockbuster films Rogue One (2016) and Venom (2018). So, I'm that much more thankful to see him absolutely crush his starring role in Sound of Metal, for which he rightly has received a Best Actor nomination for. It was a film that surprised me, and I hope this review can encourage more people to give the film a watch.Sound of Metal is a drama film about a heavy metal drummer, Ruben (Riz Ahmed), who loses his hearing presumably due to the environment of dangerously loud noise that he consistently subjects himself to. After realizing his life is likely to be permanently altered, he begins to search for ways to regain his hearing and eventually seeks solace in a secluded deaf community, where he learns sign language and gains an appreciation for his new life. Riz Ahmed drives the heavy-handed story with an emotional, gripping performance as the troubled drummer. He compellingly portrays someone struggling to cope with the loss of his most prized sense, showing how the incident impacts his psyche, his relationships, and his perspective of his own life. At its center, the film is a character study on how something so fundamentally life altering can change a person, for better and for worse. It allows Ahmed to really show what he's made of as an actor, and it makes me eager once again to see what else he can share with the film industry.One aspect of Sound of Metal that's been getting much attention is its innovative sound mixing, sound design, and sound editing. Since the film is about someone losing their hearing, you'd expect it to go to some lengths to illustrate what the experience is like for viewers unfamiliar with the feeling. The film executes this brilliantly. When Ruben first realizes what's happening to him, we are taken inside his head, and the sounds of the world around him are replaced with something similar to what you'd hear when you plug your ears. You hear the blood rushing through his brain, the faint muffles caused by people trying to talk to him, and the audible vibrations generated by loud noises and forceful movements. The decision to do this, and the flawless implementation of it, creates a uniquely immersive viewing experience. Adding to this immersion is the filmmaking and editing decisions made to demonstrate the steps in Ruben's journey. For instance, during his early days as part of the deaf community and initial visits to a school for deaf children, American Sign Language (ASL) is seen and used prominently among the supporting characters. While subtitles are eventually employed to help viewers follow conversations, they are initially neglected to help convey the confusion and unfamiliarity that Ruben is experiencing in his new life. Small decisions like these make the film that much more engaging, enhancing the story being put to screen.Finally, Sound of Metal succeeds in its ability to portray a realm of life that most viewers know little about. The stylistic and editing choices made to support viewer immersion helps greatly in this respect, but the remainder of it is accomplished through the writing. In this respect I found the film very similar to Nomadland, which explored the lives of van dwellers and offered a poignant exploration of their lifestyles. The difference here is the characters portrayed in Sound of Metal are thrust into their lifestyle more out of necessity and less out of choice. We see throughout the film though that, despite the differences in everyday actions like communication, these are people who live life with the same fervor and passion as everyone else. We're all human, after all. I love the way it shows Ruben overcome and adapt to his difficult situation; it's motivating to see how he comes to accept his deafness as an empowering quality that defines him rather than a disability that holds him back. It makes me happy to see a film that so notably depicts ASL and the deaf community receive so much attention, as it contributes to the increasing diversity and acceptance of the film industry. I suppose the film is in the same realm as A Quiet Place for that reason - perhaps we have that film's success to thank for the attention this film is receiving.Sound of Metal is a film I supremely enjoyed. Of the four Best Picture nominees I have watched so far in preparation for the upcoming Oscars ceremony, I'd say it ties with Nomadland for my favorite one. Among other things, the film features a phenomenal performance from Riz Ahmed, innovative and creative use of sound, and an inspiring story with an emotional core. I hope we keep seeing films like this in the coming years: films that enlighten general audiences to lifestyles they are unfamiliar with and films that promote increasing diversity and acceptance in Hollywood. I'm happy to have watched Sound of Metal, and I'm giving it 10 out of 10 stars. Definitely check this one out if you have an Amazon Prime subscription.

This film can be simply viewed as a straightforward story of a heavy metal drummer who is thrown into turmoil when he loses his hearing, but it's so much more than that. Underneath the matter of fact narrative lie of jumble of greater and more profound musings on the purpose of life, the perceived limits of disability and the transitory nature of love and relationships. It's all very skilfully crafted and constructed by the filmmakers and is dominated by a powerful and compelling performance from Riz Ahmed, who conveys the chaotic and disorienting inner turmoil of his character quite brilliantly. The ending wisely avoids presenting a neatly wrapped up, crowd pleasing transformational moment and opts for something much more ambiguous which only lends the preceding events even greater poignancy and leaves you pondering various aspects and events from the film for some time afterwards. A very smart and intelligent piece of filmmaking all round.

reviews.review_title: Good movie, great sound, badly wrong messages
reviews.content: Note: I was born with a bilateral moderate/severe hearing loss, corrected with hearing aids.I overall really liked the movie, and Riz Ahmed did an astonishing job in highlighting the pain and emotions that you may feel in his situation. The sound was impressive as well, as is manages to convey the sort of muffled sound that a hearing impaired individual usually experiences: is not just volume down, it's blurred and indistinct.There were a couple things that disappointed me quite a lot, though:I totally disliked the portrayal of the Deaf community. It should all be about acceptance of a disability and trying to get the best out of life notwithstanding the hearing impairment. There should be neither glorification of deafness, nor hate towards who decides to live with it and communicate with sign language, nor hate towards who can and decides to get a hearing aid or a cochlear implant. Everyone should be accepted as it is and not rejected on the basis of a personal choice.I didn't like the movie ending conveying the message that no hearing could be better than bad hearing. Any level of hearing, even if muffled and distorted, is better than anything. You can still communicate with Deaf people, but you also open yourself the possibility of communicating with non sign language speakers, not to mention safety reasons. I myself like silence, and I understand that peaceful feeling of removing the hearing aids, which I often do while at home. But denying myself the possibilities that my hearing aids offer me, just to be accepted by the Deaf community, sounds insane.

reviews.review_title: Musing on effect of sound on life
reviews.content: "Sound of Metal" is a profound musing on the effect of sound on the life of every individual, as well on the existentialism of hearing vs deafness in terms of the meaning of life. It does not take sides in the worlds of the deaf and the hearing, but when it comes to loss of hearing in the life of an adult, it may border on a trauma and require significant adjustments in how the affected person deals with life - whether it provides a debate on cochlear implants or not.On an artistic and technical level, the movie is almost faultless in terms of photography, direction and acting, the latter being sensitive to dealing with loss of hearing and how it affects one's relationships.Magical moments in the film is the depiction of sounds without hearing them but vibrations from the floor (this may explain a Oscar nomination for Best Sound).Which the overall message (didactic or not) in the film boils down to, is the moments of stillness (and with them, inner peace/contentment) which one should strive to achieve in one's world of either silence or of sounds.In short, 9/10 (maybe more subjective than objective) for the movie journey through deafness, and may this film garner at least one Oscar out of the 6 nominations.

Kids should be taught about this in school. Before my hearing aids I would walk into a busy pub or restaurant and all sound would be obliterated. I couldn't make sense of any conversation unless the person in front of me was literally shouting into my ear. This movie delivers the message and addresses the disabling effect of hearing loss very well. I thought I knew all about it from my experience but how wrong was I. Please watch this film, and ideally with your teenage kids. And for goodness sake wear ear defenders when using your power tools and decibel reducers when you go to a gig. Riz did an amazing job here, very well done.

reviews.review_title: Quick fixes are not the solution
reviews.content:
To begin with, I see why this movie was highly awarded for sound and film editing. I really felt the quality throughout watching. AND the way the filmmakers decided to present the shock of losing your hearing to the audience was genius!But the moral for me was the main character running around after being diagnosed with severe hearing loss, not accepting his fate (which was bad but also good - he was a fighter), trying to keep living as if nothing had happened, instead of finding a new way to live, integrating his condition into his everyday. After he went to the deaf community, he received a task, which
in my opinion, life is all about. How many people are able to just sit in an empty room doing nothing? Sit there with a clear head (not under the influence of substances), alone, with your thoughts only. Many people, even perfectly healthy, would get a breakdown. They would be terrified because they have to deal with thoughts that they have been busy escaping from their whole life. This would be a perfect practice for every person, to wake up early and sit alone with your thoughts, only with an option to write them down. It is like looking in a mirror. And after a while people maybe have nothing to write anymore and they just embrace the moment, be in the moment.Ruben experienced full living while being in the community. In my opinion he experienced the most meaningful moments of his life there without even realizing it. And then he told the community leader that he will leave because life is running by... and he needs to "go out there" and start living again. But his previous life was a farce, revolving around a co-dependent relationship and ideals that he believed would mean living. Why was that self-destructing life better? In the community he discovered the beauty of giving. He discovered the beauty of listening to other people. He discovered the beauty of listening to HIMself.The actor who played him said after the movie that learning ASL made him communicate deeper than ever before. Deeper than he ever could using words. I think his character, Ruben must have discovered that too during his community life. And in the end of the movie he finally acknowledged it. It was the most beautiful scene in my eyes.The part of the movie was when the leader of the community told Ruben that in the community they won't cure his loss of hearing but they will teach him how to live with it was also important in my eyes. People tend to search for a quick fix, not only when something bad happens to them, but generally too. If a relationship does not work, I will break it up, this is a quick fix. The problem has to be the other person, not me and my own patterns. So it is very easy to find a new person as a quick fix, who at first, might bring out the best of us , but in the end we make the same mistakes as before. So instead of quick fixes we should look inside, work with ourselves from day to day...relationships are all about work.Addictions need work, not quick fixes; losing your hearing, sight, being diagnosed with something, it all needs dealing with it daily, not quick fixes. BUT people love quick fixes. That is the reason why health promotion is not popular... it is not a quick fix, it is a change of patterns, change of lifestyle, change of thinking. People do not like that, that rips them out of their comfort zones. So they turn to medicine, which offers you quick fixes. Take this pill and it will numb your pain as if nothing was ever wrong.So this movie actually is more about that pattern that runs in our society, not simply about hearing loss.
There is the kingdom of God right there in a beautiful film of facing the harsh reality of life with love, beautiful, stunning acting, leaves you wanting more!

reviews.review_title: An experience that makes you look within
reviews.content: For me this movie took me to a deeper place - a place of reflection and a place of stillness that heavily coincided with where I am at on my own personal and spiritual journey. An initial sense of overwhelming suffering that was transmuted into moments of true connection, play, joy and stillness. Paul Raci was phenomenal in his role as Joe - as the viewer I could sense the journey the character had undergone before becoming a leader amongst the deaf community. During the scenes filmed at the deaf community, we were given an insight into life without sound purely by virtue of these scenes unfolding - it is not often we are deprived of this constant sensory stimulation in our daily lives and I found it moving to navigate this change at the same time as Reuben. The 'kingdom of heaven' that Joe describes when Reuben is alone in the morning, left with only the glistening blue sky and the peace that passes all understanding. The deeper sense of connection Reuben forges with the community of deaf children, finding himself lost in periods of playfulness and joy beyond the image he has of himself.This unfolding allowed me to experience Reuben's journey of transformation also, which is why the movie connected with me spiritually in so many different ways. For those undergoing similar parallel journeys, I am sure we can all relate to that familiar false sense of self, constantly attempting to sabotage and pull us out of that place of deeper understanding. Through this, understanding that ultimately Reuben had to regress back to his former life to realise this deeper truth himself, beyond anything Joe could have ever told him. This was beautifully depicted in the final scene as Reuben consciously choose to return to that place - that place that will never abandon us.Beautiful and touching film.

Another film in competition for the Oscars 2021 with a great theme, but rather poorly realized, by an author completely unknown to me, Darius Marder.

First of all, let's clear up a few untruths that are presented in the movie, namely, most medical insurances, even in the US, cover operations in cases of hearing loss. Then, the implant placement operation is always performed first on one side, never on both at the same time. And most importantly, couples in such situations are most often encouraged to go through together e.g. learning sign language, and not being forbidden to do so for some mysterious reason.

On the other hand, criticism of the plot, according to which it is illogical for the main actor Riz Ahmed to continue making noise immediately after receiving the diagnosis (a couple of months of rehearsal is not enough to call even the most talented actors drummers), really doesn't stand, because it is natural for each of us, and especially the character as presented in the film, to need time to accept and face the new facts in our lives. It is these moments that are, in my humble opinion, the greatest value of the story. Unfortunately, the film did not go any further than that, and that is also the biggest complaint, because it has obviously long ago become a trend to shoot stories without any messages and conclusions.

The biggest praise goes for the supporting female role of Olivia Cooke, who, in addition to inspiring acting, allegedly performed all the music scenes live on her own.

In any case, the film deserves a passing grade, unlike some other nominated works, which did not manage to come up with the topics they set out to do. Sometimes it is better no ending at all, than one indulging in the mere commercial taste of the audience, with an extremely illogical plot and maximally stereotypical male characters, using "subverted expectations", as in the so-called revenge-feminist "Promising Young Woman", which is also in competition. We will see who will do better at the awards ceremony in April.

Movies about losing one of the key senses related to the art form intrigue me. Most commonly, from "City Lights" (1931) to "Bird Box" (2018) or "The Invisible Man" (1933 and 2020, among other adaptations), it seems at least, that sense is sight, as motion pictures are primarily a visual medium, but they've hardly ever been entirely silent--not even silent films were silent, accompanied as they tended and tend to be by musical accompaniment and occasional sound effects or live narration. I've been tagging such use of "sight-analogy" on Letterboxd, it's such a frequent reflexive device. All the better, then, when art is featured in the picture. In the case of "Sound of Metal," the art is heavy metal music (hence the title, which also takes on something of a double meaning when the protagonist later drums with his palms on a metal slide in a key scene that a deaf child feels, or listens, to). Similarly, this music is not entirely audial, as there is an unmistakable look to the rock scene. Shown stereotypical pictures of how one dresses--what sort of tattoos or blonde highlights, e.g.--one might do well at guessing what sort of music they prefer. Nevertheless, "Sound of Metal" is about a drummer who loses his hearing and at least partly because of playing music. The consequence of which is to focus one's senses on the distinctive qualities of the art, whether music or, by extension, cinema.

It helps that it's well acted, led by a standout performance from Riz Ahmed and a good supporting cast headed by Olivia Cooke, and well dramatized--even the drug addiction and scratching works--which makes for a nice conflation that the movie isn't just about what's important to art but also what's important in life--there being considerable crossover of both. If this doesn't get an acting Oscar nomination, it better at least get something for the sound. Few films feature such an acoustic focal point. "The Conversation" (1974) is an obvious exception, but not to compare this to what's probably the greatest exploration of sound design in film history, it should be indication enough of how good "Sound of Metal" is that the comparison even comes to mind. Featuring deaf characters, including some real-life deaf actors, draws attention to the picture's sound design, as well as to the image when the picture becomes silent as well. In general, I especially appreciate the shifts here between subjective and objective camera positions and the accompanying varying degrees of silence and sound and of seeing. The last silent scene is perfect. I don't think a better ending could've been made.

While there haven't been many (and I still have a few more to view), Sound of Metal is likely my #2 movie of 2020, only slightly behind Da 5 Bloods. What is surprising is that Darius Marder made his directorial debut with this thought-provoking, touching, and entertaining film. Stone is ½ of the punk-rock duo, Blackgammon, the other half being his girlfriend, Lou (Olivia Cooke). Ruben — with the punk adage "Please Kill Me" tattooed across his chest — is a drummer who suddenly loses 90–99% of his hearing. If this wasn't enough, Ruben is a recovering addict, 4 years without using, and therefore needs — to his chagrin — not only a deaf-living house but sober-living, too. Marder uses sound in a way I've never experienced before — maybe because it's never been done(?) — to portray Ruben's disability. There was a moment when I thought the entire movie might've been conducted in this manner, which would've made a powerful point, but definitely would've been difficult to complete, but instead switches between regular hearing and the hearing-impaired. The direction and acting also beautifully showcases the frustrations of not being able to communicate. If there's one shot to stick with you, it's when all of the deaf school-children are resting on the grand-piano, Ruben right there with them. This movie is still new, so I'll spare more details, but the last three scenes, upon reflection, is one of the best sequences I've had the pleasure of viewing for a long time. There weren't many must-watches from 2020, but this is absolutely one of them.

In a manner like few others, Sound of Metal drops you into the shoes (read: ears) of its protagonist with full perspective immersion. Riz Ahmed channels a powerful mix of pain and fear as Ruben, a heavy metal drummer and former addict who suddenly loses most of his hearing ability. Alongside the long, uncomfortably real takes shot by director/co-writer Darius Marder, the paling fright conveyed in Ahmed's performance comes almost entirely from his face, tapping into raw, crushing emotions solely from blank stares and the sporadic physical outburst. The film's innovative sound design further lights Ruben's experience, corrupting, completely fading out, or immediately reappearing with a chilling wide shot cut at Marders' cue. It's a keenly crafted character piece with jaw-dropping moments from minute one, and while the second act pulls into a slower, calmer burn that may drag in retrospect, the film's gut punch ending shines with a bittersweet empathy ranking among the best of the year.

With incredible performances, scripting grounded in realism, sensitive direction, and gripping sound design, 'Sound of Metal' tells a story that as many as 400,000 Americans each year may experience - the process of sudden hearing loss. Riz Ahmed's central performance as Ruben, a drummer who in an instant loses his hearing, is imbued with a deep emotional complexity that is complemented by innovative sound design - Ruben's panic, rage, despair, fear, and isolation are palpable as you watch him negotiate, and and eventually begin to grow in, his new reality of muffled silence. There are some scenes that make you want to reach through the TV and hug and comfort this man as his world falls apart around him, and again as he puts it back together. Olivia Cooke and Paul Raci are well matched with Ahmed in their supporting roles, the former as Ruben's deeply committed yet troubled love interest, and the later as a leader of an organization that supports the deaf. This film gives voice to a community rarely seen in film, and gifts awareness and empathy to it's viewers. It is certainly one of the most affecting, intimate films of the year.

While hanging out with musician friends at shows I noticed that before playing, they all put in earplugs. I wondered why since I thought this would make it difficult for them to hear each other. This was very much not the case. If you've ever been to a loud concert, it is way, way louder on stage. So, the premise of Sound of Metal, about a working-class heavy metal drummer whose world is turned upside down by sudden and profound hearing loss, is frighteningly believable. Thankfully, my friends still have their hearing. 

The path that Ruben, played by Riz Ahmed with one of the best performances of the year, finds himself on is abrupt and unexpected to put it mildly. Likewise, the film never quite goes where you expect, but you believe every moment and every emotion. I wasn't expecting Sound of Metal to receive 6 Academy Award nominations, including Best Picture, but I am very happy that it did because I cannot think of many movies from 2020 that I enjoyed more. 

Faced with the loss of his hearing, his livelihood, and potentially his relationship, Ruben also fears losing his four years of sobriety from heroin. In need of immediate and special help, his girlfriend and bandmate, Lou (Olivia Cooke), takes him to a sobriety house especially for the deaf. The house is run by Joe (Paul Raci), a deaf Vietnam veteran and recovering alcoholic who gives off the impression that his inner peace only came after a hard struggle. He takes Ruben under his wing but tells him that his program is about finding a solution to the problem in his mind, not his deafness. The scenes of Ruben at the deaf sober house and learning how to live without hearing are interesting and very engaging. Director Darius Marder's gentle approach to the characters and Ruben's journey gives us the feeling that we are getting a window into a real community with real people, not participating in a kind of cultural tourism.

As much as I admire the approach taken by Marder's direction and the screenplay he co-wrote with his brother Abraham, Sound of Metal works so well because of Riz Ahmed's performance. This is not a case of an actor showing off their talents by playing a character with a disability. Ahmed plays a full range of emotions but the real pathos comes from his facial expressions, especially his expressive eyes. Most important of all to the movie's success, he is not afraid to show big vulnerability on screen or show just how afraid and anxious someone in this situation would feel, especially if they were a musician.

Though we see Ruben getting on well at the sober house and with the larger deaf community, he still wants to have cochlear implant surgery which he believes will allow him to return to his old life. This is at odds with Joe's belief that being deaf is not a handicap or something to be fixed and leads to one of the most compelling and affecting scenes of the movie; one that likely earned Ahmed and Raci their Oscar nominations. It is easily one of the best moments in any movie I saw over the last year. 

I will admit that I was hesitant to watch Sound of Metal at first, despite its positive reviews, because a movie about a young musician going deaf seems like a heavy or even depressing movie. However, Sound of Metal ends up being an uplifting film without delving into melodrama or smarmy sentiment. Every aspect of this movie is low-key, allowing every moment to feel genuine. This is not the kind of movie with twists but it does have unexpected narrative turns which are best left to be discovered along with Ruben. All of the unexpected places, both physical and emotional, the story takes us are what make it memorable. The empathy in the performances from Paul Raci, Olivia Cooke, Mathieu Amalric, and, most of all, Riz Ahmed are what make it so moving. Sound of Metal is something special: a film so seemingly simple but deeply affecting. It is a character study so well executed that it transcends its premise and puts us so in tune with the main character that its final moments become spiritual, or philosophical, depending on your inclination.

This movie portrays the struggle of a hard rock drummer who lost his hearing from all the noise he exposed himself to.  He kept on thinking that he could get his deafness fixed until he realized that being deaf is not the handicap he thought that it was.

That said, I could not take my eyes off of Paul Raci. He simply is. His performance in this movie is so pure, and he is more than deserving of the Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actor. Of the big four acting awards, I felt strongest about Daniel Kaluuya winning for Judas and The Black Messiah, but this movie changed my mind.

This was my review in my ASL class.  First of all, this film as AMAZING!!  I absolutely LOVED it!  I had been planning to watch it but just hadn't gotten around to it. I felt the film was very respectful of the deaf community, and it seems like everyone involved made a big effort to really work together to portray what it would be like to suddenly go deaf and how that and subsequent actions taken would affect not only your own beliefs in what your identity is but also how it would affect other people's lives and perception of you.  The film of course reinforced the fact that people in the Deaf community can do anything they decide to do.  One aspect I hadn't really given much thought to was treatment and halfway housing for deaf addicts.  We've talked about deaf people having access to skilled interpreters during things like doctor appointments in my classes, but addiction recovery wasn't something I had specifically thought about.  That creates another set of challenges, as addressing addictions usually involve a lot of anger, doubt and fear.  If you don't have someone you can easily talk to with sign language to help you through that, it would really create a barrier to recovery and moving forward in life as a recovering addict.  I've had family members and friends who have been addicts, primarily alcoholics, and trying to overcome it was hard enough without an additional barrier of not having a common language to express yourself and get the help you need.  

I loved seeing the progression of Ruben's perception of himself and acceptance of being deaf changing.  I thought he portrayed the denial, fear and anger associated with the loss of hearing quite well.  I thought that was probably how I would react in many ways.  I was surprised he didn't seem to make any effort to discuss getting the cochlear implants with anyone at the halfway house...it was heartbreaking to watch him learn he couldn't stay there anymore and to see Joe's face after he got up to leave.  I was sad he and Lou had grown apart, but in a way I think it helped him finally and fully accept he is now a deaf person.   That last scene was pretty profound.  I think Ruben will perhaps find a way to help deaf children experience music and maybe form a deaf drumming group, perhaps one that incorporates addicts...giving back and helping others find a new creative outlet for themselves.  I hope he remains friends with Joe, Jenn and Shaheem.

The sharp, precise and smartly constructed manner in which Darius Marder's debut feature begins is rather remarkable. Not only does it tell us everything we need to know about Riz Ahmed's recovering addict/drummer Ruben and his girlfriend/vocalist, Olivia Cooke's Lou, but it plugs us right into Ruben's nightmarish experience as he becomes aware that his hearing has been reduced to a disorientating static buzz. Much has been talked about the film's inventive designs in sound mixing which manage the rare feat of actually propelling the narrative forward, and every word, and every award it's getting for them, is true and well-deserved. In an equally awards-worthy performance, Ahmed is expressive, vulnerable and raw, and you just can't help but fall hard for Ruben as he struggles to learn how to be deaf at a deaf community run by (now Oscar-nominated) Paul Raci's Joe. It's to the writers' credit that, despite the presence of addiction in the storyline, that it never goes for easy shots or the usual melodramatic tropes that you half expect to see along with a special appearance by Marlee Matlin (who's of course wonderful in her own right). In fact, the film's slow and singular drive towards an inner reconciliation for Ruben is both unexpected and so nicely orchestrated, I find myself emotionally drawn and drained watching this insightful and authentic drama tackling not just a rare subject-matter, but do so in this particular way; and it's 2hrs long but hardly feels it. The last shot may look like your run-of-the-mill elliptically abrupt indie-drama ending, but it's less about what happens next and more about how he finds peace within himself; and as far as the film's emotional arc is concerned, it finishes with Ruben arriving at exactly the right place he needs to be in his head.

"Sound of Metal" captures the essence of many forms of loss, and on so many levels that the end result is far more rich and complex than one might expect, even by the film's mid-point. Ruben (Riz Ahmed, Best Actor nominee, whom you might know from HBO's great limited series "The Night Of . . . "), a heavy metal drummer, discovers he's losing his hearing within the first minutes of the film during a concert performance with his girlfriend and fellow band member of their duo "Blackgammon." And with that loss, sound itself becomes another character in the film as Ruben fights to save what he can of his rapidly crumbling life. With music suddenly no longer a viable career path, one would expect melodramatic, over the top wallowing in pathos, especially given that Ruben is also a recovering addict. And while there are the expected and understandable outbursts of angry frustation and agony, they are few and far between as Ruben tries to piece together who he is now, and who he can become without lapsing back into addiction. Throughout his journey, the film's sound track mirrors the type and level of Ruben's hearing loss, placing us IN his experience. Muted, muffled, empty, painful, and many points inbetween, "Sound of Metal" takes the use of sound in cinema further than we have previously known. Sure, we have had the soundtrack reflect the muffled ringing in a character's ears following an explosion before, but no one that I'm aware of has tried to replicate the experience of going deaf like this, making it a probable shoe-in for the Achievement in Sound Academy Award. This is NOT a film designed to elicit sympathy for the deaf through cheap tear-jerker shots, but uses the deafness to explore loss, as Ruben's life and world crumble around him leaving him empty and desperate to find a future for himself. The majority of the film takes place in a retreat for the deaf led by the wonderfully calm and wise performance by Paul Raci (Supporting Actor nominee) whose uncompromising approach to teaching how to live as a deaf person offers Ruben his best hope for a meaningful future. I can't really say much else without spoiling the film's final act, but the inclusion of the divisive issue of cochlear implants within the deaf community provides the lynchpin that yields the amazing conclusion to this film. Watch this film in a quiet place.

While the craftsmanship of sound design is nothing short of excellent, it's nothing more than practical. It's by no means exceptional, but that doesn't take away anything from its value and efficiency that, in part, rendered this movie a truly immersive experience. It's Riz Ahmed's bravura performance, though, that gives Sound of Metal resonance that, in turn, made Ruben one of the most relatable movie characters I've witnessed in recent memory. 

His ability to reflect his fluctuating feelings throughout the movie and how he perceives every phase in his new life is simply astonishing. The aching experience Ruben goes through demands a real acting talent to make the audience emotionally connected to the protagonist, but Ahmed proved he's not just a talented actor but also one who's in a total command of his craft. For if it's hard to make the viewer feel what his character feels, it's even harder to transport its mental state to the audience. Here, we don't only get the sense of loss and being stripped of everything that forms every inch of Ruben in a flicker, nor only do we only understand his pressing need to regain what he lost—especially since the possibility hovering in the air—but we see him grappling with the dilemma of whether he should continue his journey of adapting to his new condition as if it was the norm or he should keep clutching onto the flicker of hope that definitely wouldn't help in case of it turned out to be a mere mirage.

Furthermore, the movie also excels in aspects other than its nuanced portrait of its main character, namely is its exploration of deaf community that truly offers new insights. That's mostly because of the effort shown in the meticulous attention to its essential components, most notably the sign language. However, Paul Raci played a major part in that by portraying the leader of this community and a mentor for Ruben. Through his facial expressions during conversations with Ruben, he delineates the professional duties such an occupation demands. We see him monitoring Ruben's progress and interfering according to his understanding of Ruben's character in particular. As for Olivia Cooke, she further proves she's a remarkable young talent that yet to bloom. Playing Ruben's bandmate and girlfriend Lou, she managed to prove how important she's to Ruben as his most great and precious loss and equally as a great help for him to get a better sense of what he has lost and how to cope with that.

The acting clinic these three immense talents put on here left an indelible impression on me, but disregarding the technical quality would make absolutely no sense. Besides the exquisite sound design, the highly-articulate cinematography truly adds up to the experience. If there's only one issue I have about this movie it would be its failure to maintain the same dramatic heft that was in its first half. As the focus on Ruben's progression through his medical recovery and its consequences slightly overpowered the emotional quality, and hence there was a bit of it lost that even the wrap-up failed to fully retrieve.

A powerful, enlightening and humanizing drama, Sound of Metal takes us through the arch of Metal drummer Ruben Stone's sudden hearing loss.  The sound editing brings the viewer into the experience of Ruben, complementing Riz Ahmed's performance to allow the viewer to empathize (as much as humanly possible through a screen) with the initial frustration and despair of his new reality and his mindset throughout the film.  So many choices throughout the film - from the visual shots, to the choice of when to subtitle, to the sound -  give power to the non-hearing community and truly help the hearing understand Joe's final dialogue with Ruben (a tremendous piece of acting by Paul Raci) and his terribly difficult choice.

As a drummer/percussionist with hearing loss of my own, this film hit me hard.  SOUND OF METAL, directed and co-written by Darius Marder, tells the story about heavy metal drummer Ruben (Riz Ahmed from ROGUE ONE, VENOM and the HBO miniseries "The Night Of"), touring in an RV with his girlfriend & singer/guitarist Lou (READY PLAYER ONE's Olivia Cooke).  One night he notices an abrupt hearing loss, and after a few days of devolving hearing Ruben goes to a doctor who tells him he's lost about 80% of his hearing in both ears.  Like nearly all hearing loss, the doctor tells Ruben his hearing can never be restored, and his best bet is to have an operation and get cochlear implants: devices surgically implanted that bypass the damaged ear canal(s) to deliver an electric/mechanized sensation that resembles what humans perceive as sound.  The doc tells Ruben this procedure is expensive ($40-80 thousand), and if you know ANYTHING about working drummers you know Ruben doesn't have that kind of money.

Adding to his troubles, we learn that Ruben is a recovering drug addict: four years sober.  Lou becomes increasingly worried that Ruben will be unable to cope with this devastating news and will relapse.  She contacts his sobriety coach who is able to hook him up with half-way type situation for deaf recovering addicts.

The bulk of this film is Ruben both learning how to live with deafness (Joe, who runs the rural deaf recovery house, stresses that deafness is NOT a handicap, and instead is something that Rueben needs to learn to adjust to), while also learning how to adjust to a new "him."  The direction is really well done: the situation isn't meant to feel like a super downer for Ruben (obviously the situation is, but the film doesn't dwell on it like some grand tragedy), and all of the performances are on point.  Ahmed's  drumming is done in a way to seem believable and to mask the fact that Ahmed is, well, an actor and not a drummer.  This is a minor point, of course, but if the movie is about a drummer the actor needs to be believable as a working drummer, and Ahmed, as well as the director and editor, accomplish that task.  Too often I get annoyed when movies about drummers feature actors who _barely_ look like they can convince non-drummers they're competent, let alone excelling (I'm looking at you THAT THING YOU DO, WHIPLASH, ROCKSTAR, and many others).  This is obviously my own (any likely other drummers) problem, but it should be commended that SOUND OF METAL does a good job of portraying Ruben as a good drummer through solid 'acting' by Ahbed and subtle (maybe not obvious to the laymen, but obvious to this dummer) editing and film shooting techniques.

I've lost about 25-30% of my hearing in each ear myself; while I'm fortunate currently to be able to adjust with hearing aids, I have some sort of degenerative affliction that is getting worse, regardless of what I've done/will do to maintain 'safe' listening environments.  I don't gig anymore like I did as a teenager/young-20 something adult but I am music teacher constantly around bands and percussion ensembles.  I'd noticed my hearing devolving for probably at least 15 years before I _FINALLY_ did something about it: I waited until I had turned 40, thinking "well - I guess 40 is kind of old so it's time to get a hearing aid like grandpa" or something.  This adjustment has been difficult at times, but easily one of the best decisions of my life.

I say this only to underscore the difficulties Ruben has, going from a nightly-drumming professional musician to suddenly unable to hear a conversation from his girlfriend, let alone continue pursuing his passionate work.  Riz Ahmed does an INCREDIBLE job portraying this character & his hearing loss.  You can feel the confusion, pain, and frustration every step of the way.  Ahmed is a music performer in his own right, releasing several wrap albums over the last decade or so.  I'm sure he was able to draw on his own passions as a performer in order to portray the pains and frustrations of Rueben being unable to drum.

But, really, the sadness and frustration is mostly the first Act of SOUND OF METAL.  At the recovery house Joe hooks Ruben up with a class of children, where Ruben interacts with kids, becomes comfortable learning American Sign Language (ASL), and starts teaching the kids basic drumming.  Seeing Ruben start to come alive in his current situation is a legit joy!  When Ruben catches up with Lou, and sees she's pursing her own music passions elsewhere, Ruben decides to sell off his drums and recording equipment to have the cochlear implant surgery.

The film centers around Ruben trying to find himself instead of chasing what is in the past.  SOUND OF METAL has (inadvertently) become an incredible metaphor for living in the COVID/post-pandemic world.  Those who are still trying to live with the habits of January 2020 in January 2021 are going to be miserable: lamenting what we used to have and what we used to be able to do.  Myself, I've gone from producing award-winning percussion ensembles, and co-producing various types of HS bands (marching, concert, jazz) to moving to a mostly virtual world.  My family used to go to Disneyland regularly, and we haven't seen any family members in person since Christmas 2019.  Like Ruben, it's normal, understandable even, to want to be down that we're in month 10 of a nearly nationwide lock-down from our norms with no end in immediate sight.

Rueben gets the implant surgery, but he essentially has to leave the deaf addict recovery house.  Joe stated Ruben shouldn't try to reduce his deafness as a disability that needs to be overcome: he should instead embrace it and learn to adjust.  Ruben defies this ideology, gets the surgery, and then flies out to Europe to see Lou, now living with her wealthy father in Belgium.  But of course Ruben learns quickly that the cochlear implants do not supply "sound" the way his brain naturally interprets sound: they "mimic" human voice in a metallic, almost robotic voice and there is much distortion for moderate volume sound.  He listens to Lou perform a song, hearing massive distortion throughout, and Ahmed brilliantly captures the moment Ruben realizes "he could never go back," so to speak.

Another technical aspect I have to give a shout-out to is the sound design.  Through merely sound the filmmakers do an incredible job of conveying the struggles Ruben is going through.  Portraying deafness can be difficult, as most of us are not stone-cold deaf, sitting in stark silence.  There is often some degree of distortion or white-noise (or tinnitus) when the film is portraying Ruben's point of listening, and later in the film after Ruben gets his implants activated, we get a sense for the 'metallic' and distorted (and still quite faint) sound Ruben is experiencing.  Often loud explosions and shootouts garner "sound effects" or "sound effects editing" Awards, but I think SOUND OF METAL (a clever pseudo-pun of a title, being both the style of music Ruben & Lou play as well as the types of sound Ruben hears with the implants) is deserving of recognition for its brilliant sound design and execution prorating hearing loss + life with cochlear implants.

The films ends just as the 'new' Ruben begins: when he realizes to let go of trying to hear the way he used to.  He unplugs his implants after hearing the distorted sound of church bells.  This is a great metaphor for what he ALL must do in a post-pandemic landscape.  We have to let go of how things used to be, and how we used to behave (for ex: I doubt I'll shake very many hands ever again) and embrace our "new normal."  As an educator, I've had to learn all sorts of new technology and teaching tools that I plan on implementing into my curriculum for the foreseeable future: regardless of when I'll be able to teach in person to all my students at the same time.  Ruben looks to be on the path to happiness again when he embraces his "new me," and only when we're ready to do the same can be begin our journey to contentment and real joy.

Spoilers: A layered and penetrating look at life, at adapting to change, and even a peek at why people are like they are. This is not just about heavy metal drummer Ruben (Riz) or deafness or addiction or his girlfriend -- his duo's singer, Lou, who more screams than sings. I almost quit the movie early on, as it was just loud noise. But it was just brilliant scene setting, suggesting there is too much noise for all of us and not just  aural noise. The noise did harm Ruben and made him deaf. And not just the heavy metal noise, but all the noise in his life, the heroin he kicked four years ago, the constant on-the-road in a big RV. He went from hearing to deaf in an instant. And a doc told him the hearing wasn't coming back, though a cochlear implant could bring back some hearing but was expensive. He opted to try a group home run by a deaf Vietnam vet, as Lou had to leave to let the program work. We find she grew up here after originating in Paris, as her parents split up not long after, and Mom took her to the states and Mom finally killed herself,  which apparently pissed Lou off enough to spend her nights in the tiny band, screaming at the top of her lungs, playing metal guitar loud as Ruben  played the drums loud, he also  pissed off, having been raised by a single mom and at some point gotten hooked on heroin. The vet who tries to get him to a quiet place, no noise, where he can be at peace with himself and therefore his god, cuts him loose from the program, where no one is seen as handicapped even though deaf, as Ruben opts to try to fix it with the implant, after selling all he has for the operation. He gets some hearing back, heads for Lou, now in Paris, and they agonizingly and in not so many words decide their relationship and indeed their lifestyle is over. At the end Riz decides to take off the implant, to remove the sound he gets from the metal appliance, and just sit in silence maybe for a long time. We all adapt as we age to literal hearing loss or hip malfunction or fighting heart or cancer ailments, some of which we contribute to  ourselves with our own noise. This asks the musical question: Can we adapt and live in peace with the way we are now? Maybe the best thing that happened to Riz, who should win awards for this, is going deaf. It made him take stock of his  angry, noisy life going nowhere, and find a more quiet, peaceful place to reside, in both his decision-making and behavior. The noisy lashing out in anger is no way to live. The deaf's saving grace may well be that they don't have to listen to all the literal and figurative noise out there.

After all the immense buzz and positivity surrounding this film, it still blew me away by how well-done and emotional it is. For a film that deals with mature and complex subject matters, it is just full of warmth and heart, and not in an overly sentimental and syrupy way, but more of in a well-meaning and incredibly respectful kind of way. Its representation of the deaf community is both empathetic and enlightening, and proves that there should be more high-profile films that focus on its members. Riz Ahmed absolutely owns this role in what is possibly 2020's best performance, and is perfectly supported by Olivia Cooke (who is one of my favorite up-and-coming stars) and a phenomenal Paul Raci, who absolutely deserves every trophy he wins this year. The sound design is also some of the most innovative I've ever seen (or I guess heard) in a film, skillfully and authentically recreating the devastating experiences of hearing loss. The direction and screenplay are also spectacular, as both are very minimalist and low-key but ultimately impactful and universally relatable. I sincerely hope that this film gets a lot of recognition not only during awards season but for years to come, because it is absolutely something that everyone should see.

Alright, so I went into this not expecting much. I've heard a thing or two about Riz Ahmed's performance but nothing else. The movie's about a drummer that loses his hearing after forcing himself to perform too much, and gets to know the world differently as a deaf person as a result. Let's get the first things out of the way, the movie is really well made. I really enjoyed Marder's direction here, providing us with some really good visuals. The cinematography is good, and the tone of the movie is direct and straight to its point. The acting is indeed really great, Ahmed showing his range in here, as well as his sign language, drumming and american accent. What this movie really nails is the mixing and overall sound. Since they worked with actual deaf people on set, they knew how important it was to get this aspect right, and so they did. The moments of silence and the muffled sound when the camera closes on the protagonist feel so real and it really puts you in the position he's in, which is great in this type of film, and hands down my favorite aspect here. The plot though, is a little bit messy to begin with. We get little background on our characters here, apart from a brief backstory for some of them. Our main character's past is an enigma, hell, we don't even know how old he is. That's not a big issue here, since the point of the film is the matter at hand and that is losing his hearing. Towards the middle of the movie there's a time jump, suggested by a few shots of landscapes and skies. With that time jump we lose a pretty big chunk of character development for our protagonist, seeing him go from being rejective to Joe to being in complete harmony with everyone. I wish we could've seen how he got to the point where he started to fit in, it would have given some nice depth to Ruben. One of my favorite characters in this movie is Paul Raci's Joe. We get some background on him, and he is established as Ruben's guide to understandng his situation. Again, the fact that this film used real deaf people made this all the more believeable and enjoyable to watch. I did enjoy this movie, despite the slow pacing and some things that went unasnwered and unmentioned. I would say this is one of the better movies of 2020, with a really good message especially with the ending, which I really liked. Sound of Metal is a good watch, one I'd recommend to anyone who likes a good drama. But I doubt the rewatchability of this, and for more critical people, the aspects I've mentioned might take from the overall enjoyment of this movie.

"Sound of Metal" (USA, 2019) is a drama, directed by Darius Marder (Place Beyond the Pines) and written with the also director Derek Cianfrance (Blue Valentine, Light Between Oceans) that is the author of the story.

The story follows Ruben, the drummer of a Death Metal band, that plays and lives in a van with his girlfriend and vocal Lou on small gigs, and is starting a career.. Suddenly he starts to lose his auditions, and the movie shows the struggle in his life to adapt to the situation and search for help, with the possibility of recovery with a cochlear implant surgery, but not having the money to do the surgery. All the stressful situation leads to a separation of the couple, with Lou continuing the gig and Rubin reluctantly agreeing to seek help in a deaf community to better learn to deal with the handicap.

The plot is intense on emotions, and shows in a realistic way the drama of losing the sense that was essential to Rubin - all the story revolves around this character, and especially from the middle to the end of the movie, the personal drama intensifies, even with the contemplative silence that occupies most of the film, or the sounds of the implant that he acquires later. The scenes that show the adaptation in the community(that uses deaf actors) is absolutely great.

The movie has Riz Ahmed as Ruben Stone (Rogue One, Nightcrwaler, The OA,The Night Of), Olivia Cooke as Lou Berger and Paul Raci as Joe (interesting that he had a deaf father in real life). Riz is just awesome on the paper, that involves showing the emotions, despair and anger to the silent parts of the individual learning, dealing and acceptance of the situation. Indeed something that deserves the prizes and indications for best male performer. The def community used deaf actors and that elevated the veracity of the story.

The cinematography by Daniël Bouquet (Nothing persona, Kaubow) is pretty competente, taking a more realistic like approach, with a nervous camera, focusing very well on expressions and situations that are really important in the context. Another great detail is the sound department, with the sound of deafening sense and later with the implant sounds transmitting well the sense and situation of the protagonist that leads to such emotions that he feels. 

Overall a great drama, with an intriguing and engaging story, without the load of melodrama that depicts in a realistic way the situation and the study of the protagonist, with the help of an excellent performance and use of sound department on the production. A solid 7,5 out of 10.

One of the most accomplished films in recent history, Darius Marder's Sound of Metal is the best iteration yet of a well-known premise: a musician going deaf. We have seen this subject before, most recently with 2004's It's All Gone Pete Tong, but never with the grace and wisdom that Marder tacitly bestows upon this film.

We follow the story of Ruben, the drummer of his and his girlfriend's heavy metal band, as his whole life is being shattered by his imminent, utter and complete deafness. The two of them are played by Riz Ahmed and Olivia Cooke. She is fantastic in one of the film's several remarkable supporting parts, but the true star of the film is Ahmed in a career highlight, effortlessly creating a compelling, relatable protagonist and  driving the story forward with his enormous emotional range.

In what is essentially a tale of transition, Marder delves into the actual truths of the deaf community with disarming realism, while the film's scope feels personal, yet universal. So unflinchingly honest with its real world subject, no one should miss this gem of a film, which I suspect will age like a fine wine.

When our dreams and the life we know evaporate in an instant, we may find it next to impossible to adjust, as is the case in this engaging drama about a heavy metal drummer who is faced with losing his hearing. While this offering has a little trouble finding its footing at times, it nevertheless takes audiences through the challenges associated with hearing loss and an addict's struggle to maintain sobriety in the wake of profound change. The film also skillfully delves into matters of adaptability and self-acceptance, as well as learning how to see "disabilities" as differences, not handicaps, qualities with the potential to give us new and unconsidered perspectives on life. All of this is brought to life through the fine performances of Riz Ahmed, Olivia Cooke and Paul Raci, as well as an inventive sound design that truly makes an impact on viewers. One of the year's best.

In his directorial debut, Darius Marder addresses a subject to which Hollywood hardly pays any attention and which is also not given enough awareness in society. Sound of Metal tells the story of the young drummer Ruben, who is on tour with his girlfriend and pursuing his dream of becoming a musician. Of all things, this passion becomes Ruben's undoing when he suddenly loses most of his hearing. As a result, his life is no longer the same and he embarks on an adventure for which he is not really ready.

Ruben is embodied by Riz Ahmed. He is the clear protagonist of the film and appears in every scene. His journey from a dreaming drummer who has the seemingly perfect life with his great love to a deaf depressive who wants to return to that life is fascinating to follow. Ahmed plays this complex character with great subtlety. But he can also boil up from 0 to 100 in some moments and give free rein to his feelings. His multi-faceted performance makes it easy to understand his situation and to sympathise with him. Ahmed totally captivates you and represents people who have suffered the same fate with a lot of dignity. Olivia Cooke, as Ruben's girlfriend Lou, only has a few scenes at the beginning and at the end. Still, it's enough time for Cooke to introduce us to her equally complicated character in a way that we can understand her as a relative. Another terrific performance is delivered by Paul Raci as Joe, Rubens' also deaf mentor. He runs an association for the deaf and acts as a sort of father to the members. He acts very calmly and emotionally, especially in the heart-warming dialogues with Ruben, though there is always a certain toughness and honesty in there. His chemistry with Ahmed is the highlight of the film. As a veteran who has long since come to terms with his situation, he sees himself in the newcomer and wants to show him that deafness is not a curse.

Sound of Metal sends an enormously important message and is hopefully a wake-up call towards Hollywood. Over the 120-minute running time, it's clear that this film was a matter of heart for Marder and the ensemble. As a result, much of it lingers for days afterwards. This fact makes the film-experience all the more beautiful and real. Real is the word that best describes Sound of Metal. Every scene seems realistic and probably takes place in real life in exactly the same way. The slow, almost still pacing in the middle of the film can seem boring, but is very important for the film's authenticity. Sound of Metal is a film you have to see to get a slight insight into the life of this fundamental group of people.

A film that deals with both the physical and psychological aspects of deafness without condescension or ridicule, Sound Of Metal is an acting showcase for Riz Ahmed, whose performance is full of energy and volatility but also a lot of quiet contemplation and empathy. Playing a heavy metal drummer who experiences rapid hearing loss, his initial reaction of furious denial slowly gives way to acceptance of the fact that his life will never be the same way it was before. The film is unique in its portrayal of a person on the outside working his way in. Many scenes have little or no sound in them, and none of the ASL used in the film is captioned, putting us firmly in our hero's shoes and highlighting what a struggle it is adapting to a different world of communication The film is done in such a way that the sound is virtually its own character. Sometimes its loud, other times its quiet Sometimes its slightly muted or slightly exaggerated, and on occasions it simply comes and goes. It flags somewhat in its 3rd act, which suggests to me that the filmmakers had a solid idea for a film, but weren't exactly sure how to bring it to a close. It's still ends on a satisfying note, but its overshadowed by what came before it. It has a strong supporting cast, most of whom are actual members of the deaf community, a decision that's a credit to the movie itself and its intentions, and while its artistic choices might alienate some, I was very happy to see a sensitive portrayal of deafness, done in a manner that makes it very relatable. Sound Of Metal is a movie I have no hesitation in recommending.

I don't think I've better empathized with hearing loss and deafness than with Sound of Metal, a moving and observant drama about a heavy metal drummer quickly losing his sense of hearing. Riz Ahmed (Nightcrawler) plays Ruben, a former junkie who is four years sober and worried about losing his girlfriend/band mate (Olivia Cooke) with his recent diagnosis. He's attending a treatment center meant to cater to a deaf community and transition others into this community. Ruben is defiant, depressed, angry, all the stages you can imagine with grief. The movie is at its best during its quiet and contemplative moments where we empathize with the terror and alienation of Ruben. When he first joins the center, we don't get subtitles for the many signed conversations between members. It's only after Ruben learns ASL, integrates into the community, and opens himself up to the program that we too get to be knowledgeable. The sound design is exceptionally utilized to illustrate Ruben's changing perspective, and some later choices with it might make you long for the peacefulness of silence. The movie is exquisitely thoughtful and considerate while maintaining a subtle, character-driven approach that keeps things grounded from wallowing in self-pity. For many of the deaf, hearing loss isn't seen as a disability but a community with its own culture and quality of life. It's understandable that Ruben is focused on loss but the movie doesn't dwell in loss, more so transformation and acceptance. Ahmed is fabulous in the lead role which requires him to rely primarily upon non-verbal expression for extended periods. His eyes are his best vessel for communicating Ruben's emotional state, and Ahmed is sensational. Paul Raci is also great as the leader of the treatment center and the responsibility and generosity he feels to those in his care. Sound of Metal is an immersive, sensitive, authentic and poignant drama with an Oscar-caliber lead performance and a depth of compassion for the many people of the deaf community.

I will also say that the lead actor did a wonderful job and his performance shined through even with what I would say was a lackluster script. First of all, this movie was supposed to be about metal music, but there was no metal music to be found which is not surprising because Hollywood wouldn't know metal/rock music if it was in front of their faces. Secondly, when Ruben goes to the doctor for the first time and finds out he is going deaf he never truly gets an answer for why. He gets multiple reasons for why he MIGHT be, but no definitive answers as to why he so suddenly lost his hearing. All he wanted and was fixated on was surgery to get his hearing back which he knew was very expensive and didn't even ask more questions about how things might sound after the surgery. He assumed he would go back to hearing the same way he did before. This is where I think the depiction of the deaf experience faltered. There would be more conversations between the doctor and patient. I also have a problem with the lack of dialogue about Rubens passion for music. The movie was supposed to be about a passionate musician losing his hearing. How come he never got a monologue where he spoke about wanting to hear again because of his love for music? All he kept saying was, I want to get the surgery. But why? Almost everything in this movie was left for the audience to infer. They barely let the girlfriend speak as well. In the end, I thought it was VERY predictable. I knew after he got the surgery it was either not going to work or he would taking the hearing aids off and that's exactly what he did and the movie just abruptly ends. What will he do next? More for the audience to infer. The critics love movies like this, but for me it was two hours worth of mediocre.

"With moderately high expectations, Sound of Metal genuinely surprised me. Darius Marder and Abraham Marder's exquisite screenplay is the absolute standout, at the same insanely good level as Riz Ahmed's impressive performance. The former holds a meaningful, enlightening story about not only the deaf community but also about accepting our limitations as something that's a part of us instead of taking it as a handicap. Except for a couple of unnecessary scenes that could have made the movie a bit shorter, the two-hour duration is quite fair, boasting a very captivating narrative.

Countless storytelling technical details elevate this film into one of the best of the year. From an apparently simple yet extremely clever use (or absence) of subtitles for sign language to emotionally compelling dialogues, an outstandingly realistic atmosphere surrounds the movie throughout the entire runtime. Never, not even for a second, the viewer needs to deal with an over-the-top reaction, cheesy conversation, or a typical Hollywood, overdramatized moment. Darius Marder has terrific control of the tone, keeping it exceptionally grounded.

Riz Ahmed delivers what I believe is his career-best display, incorporating his character's hearing disability in a seamless fashion. His subtle facial expressions and body movements are essential for the performance that can easily guarantee him dozens of nominations. Olivia Cooke (Lou) is also excellent in her role. Technically, huge praise to Daniël Bouquet's cinematography, which insists on an almost documentary-style composition by applying standard camera angles and shots often seen in this type of feature, helping to generate the before-mentioned authenticity.

One of my absolute favorite films of 2020."

Way better than I expected. Riz Ahmed delivers a powerful performance in a movie that gives a great look at the deaf community. It tells something of a heartbreaking story as a man loses what he loves and desperately tries to get it back even when he can't.

Evocative as hell, ‘Sound of Metal' gets high marks for using the medium to maximum effect in illustrating metal drummer Ruben's grapple with imminent deafness. The sound design is astounding; it captures the alienation, the disorientation, and the discovery of his circumstances in ways I couldnt've imagined and the effect is exciting, terrifying, and heartbreaking all at once.

Riz Ahmed nails the behavioral sand traps that keeps someone clinging and clawing at the bubble they're fixated on preserving. The tumultuous lengths to which he will go to combat his deafness echo his heroin addict past; I tragically saw much of Ruben in someone I used to know. We can all be soul-deep addicts in our own way to something or another in our lives and the pain and confusion when you feel like you are being ripped from your identity can be all-consuming. How do you battle for air when you're violently drowning?

This profound journey says a lot all at once and Darius Marder (alongside his brother and Derek Cianfrance) brilliantly scripts an arc that works on multiple levels - allegorically, spiritually, technically, humanely, all the ways. What often moved me throughout this was not necessarily what I was seeing directly on screen, but the implications of it all.

It's invigorating to see the thriving lives and relationships of a deaf community credibly explored and Paul Raci is memorably tender as Joe, the recovery leader and beating heart of the tight-knit society. His performance, alongside Ahmed and Olivia Cooke - who's coping with her own aching past - screams awards consideration.

'Metal' captures well that for Ruben, like so many of us, you can't be pushed to someone else's vision of acceptance; the truest form is a result of your unique, albeit stumbling journey, when you evolve organically from the steps (and missteps) you take. It's a long, difficult road, but Ruben shifts the narrative of his life from bemoaning what he's losing to embracing what he's gaining. Moving, eternal stuff. And the closing shot encapsulates a catharsis well-earned.

Change can be difficult.  So this is about a heavy metal drummer named Ruben (Riz Ahmed).  His life is about to be thrown through a loop when he starts to lose his sense of hearing.  He has no choice but to figure something out posthaste.  Now I went into this movie fully expecting it to deliver.  It's a morose premise for sure, but I had already heard rumblings about how great this was.  It has been a weak year due to COVID, so I was hopeful that this could be one of the best movies of the year.  Unlike a whole laundry list of films before it, Sound of Metal did not disappoint.  Now right away, I was vibing with this movie, and it is because it reminded me of one of my favorite movies of all time: The Wrestler.  They share several similarities: you have this skill set that gets shunned by the people who consider themselves refined, a protagonist who shouldn't be pursuing this career any longer for health concerns, and a desire to do whatever it takes to recapture the glory days.  There are also powerhouse leading performances in both films, and I will be shocked if I see acting that impresses me more than Riz Ahmed when I'm putting together my year-end wrap-up.  Even though the story doesn't spend a ton of time on it, you get a real sense of what kind of people he and his partner are right out of the gates, his partner played expertly by Olivia Cooke.  Not only is she his bandmate, but they are in a romantic relationship as well, so there are stakes presented very early on.  This problem is one that you can't ignore and hope that it goes away; you must take action, and you, of course, sympathize with his plight.  In true underdog fashion, you want to see him rise and overcome, but there are only so many options that you would have in this scenario.  You still want to watch how this will play out, and whenever I felt any lulls here, the story came back with an even harder emotional beat.  Sound of Metal is one of the very few must-see movies released this year.  You have to prepare to have your heart ripped out, and it is all too easy to put yourself into Ruben's shoes in this scary situation.  You will find energy and intensity in just about every scene, but even when it slows down for a quieter moment, the emotional charge is still palpable.  I thought the sound design to this was incredible, and you have to give kudos to how this movie handled deaf representation.  It only took twelve months into 2020, but I can finally recommend to you my first five-star movie of the year.

Darius Marder's "Sound of Metal" is an intimate, gripping and heartbreaking disability drama that sheds light on the experiences of marginalized deaf communities. With his directorial debut, writer/director Darius Marder has crafted an authentic account of a heavy-metal drummer that rapidly loses his hearing. It's the filmmaker's first attempt to humanize the lives of deaf musicians, but he pulls it off seamlessly. Using captivating cinematography, Marder draws viewers into the world of a musician that struggles to cope with hearing loss. From intimate close-ups to stunning establishing shots, the cinematography keeps viewers immersed in the film's setting. Marder uses impeccable sound design to recreate the experience of hearing loss, effectively shifting between deaf and normal audio. It is hard to not praise the powerful performances from the cast. Riz Ahmed delivers his finest performance to date as Ruben Stone. With mesmerizing expressions, he conveys the frustrations, disillusionment and self-denial of a heavy-metal drummer that struggles to come to terms with his loss of senses. The supporting cast, which includes the heartfelt Paul Raci, is also excellent and worthy of awards-recognition. Although "Sound of Metal" is undeniably an immense technical achievement, ultimately it is not a flawless film. If there's a minor drawback to the movie, it suffers from a slow pace that tests the viewer's patience. Moreover, its sensitive themes may not appeal towards everyone. Nevertheless, fans of disability dramas will definitely enjoy "Sound of Metal" and so will movie-goers seeking heartfelt entertainment. At a time when deaf communities are rarely represented in films, it's a stirring reminder of the power of Cinema as an auditory art-form for telling disability stories.
